{list-style-type: decimal} ul.ul1 {list-style-type: hyphen} ul.ul2 {list-style-type: disc} &amp;lt;/style&amp;gt; &nbsp;Disclaimer: &amp;lt;br&amp;gt;&amp;lt;ul&amp;gt;&amp;lt;li&amp;gt;This is for lunar.lab only and not intended as a guide for production environment. I’m aware that some configurations I use here are not supported configuration. &amp;lt;/li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;li&amp;gt;All deployed on vSphere environment. &amp;lt;/li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;ul&amp;gt;&amp;lt;li&amp;gt;I use nested environment. &amp;lt;/li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/ul&amp;gt;&amp;lt;li&amp;gt;The official documentation is here: &amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-NSX-T/2.1/com.vmware.nsxt.install.doc/GUID-414C33B3-674F-44E0-94B8-BFC0B9056B33.html&amp;quot;&amp;gt;https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-NSX-T/2.1/com.vmware.nsxt.install.doc/GUID-414C33B3-674F-44E0-94B8-BFC0B9056B33.html&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; &amp;lt;/li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;ul&amp;gt;&amp;lt;li&amp;gt;The documentation is quite clear, I just add some notes specific to my deployment. &amp;lt;/li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/ul&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/ul&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;Step-by-step:&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;ul&amp;gt;&amp;lt;li&amp;gt;Deploy&amp;lt;/li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;ul&amp;gt;&amp;lt;li&amp;gt;NSX-T Manager: &amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-NSX-T/2.1/com.vmware.nsxt.install.doc/GUID-FA0ABBBD-34D8-4DA9-882D-085E7E0D269E.html&amp;quot;&amp;gt;https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-NSX-T/2.1/com.vmware.nsxt.install.doc/GUID-FA0ABBBD-34D8-4DA9-882D-085E7E0D269E.html&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;li&amp;gt;NSX-T Controller (for lab purpose I only deploy 1 NSX-T Controller): &amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-NSX-T/2.1/com.vmware.nsxt.install.doc/GUID-24428FD4-EC8F-4063-9CF9-D8136740963A.html&amp;quot;&amp;gt;https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-NSX-T/2.1/com.vmware.nsxt.install.doc/GUID-24428FD4-EC8F-4063-9CF9-D8136740963A.html&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;li&amp;gt;NSX-T Edge (for lab purpose I only deploy 1 NSX-T Edge): Please note that PKS requires Large (8 vCPU 16GB RAM) size of NSX-T Edge Node. &amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-NSX-T/2.1/com.vmware.nsxt.install.doc/GUID-AECC66D0-C968-4EF2-9CAD-7772B0245BF6.html&amp;quot;&amp;gt;https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-NSX-T/2.1/com.vmware.nsxt.install.doc/GUID-AECC66D0-C968-4EF2-9CAD-7772B0245BF6.html&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/ul&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/ul&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a width="72"/&gt;&lt;thr:total&gt;1&lt;/thr:total&gt;&lt;/entry&gt;&lt;entry&gt;&lt;id&gt;tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-7374203414060321045.post-1185428970091841012&lt;/id&gt;&lt;published&gt;2018-05-27T18:37:00.000+07:00&lt;/published&gt;&lt;updated&gt;2018-05-28T08:10:57.158+07:00&lt;/updated&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="vSAN Sizer Calculator Online Tool"/&gt;&lt;title type='text'&gt;vSAN Effective Capacity - Quick and Dirty Sizer Tool&lt;/title&gt;&lt;content type='html'&gt;&amp;lt;style type=&amp;quot;text/css&amp;quot;&amp;gt;p.p1 {margin: 0.0px 0.0px 0.0px 0.0px; font: 12.0px &amp;amp;#39;Helvetica Neue&amp;amp;#39;; color: #454545} p.p2 {margin: 0.0px 0.0px 0.0px 0.0px; font: 12.0px &amp;amp;#39;Helvetica Neue&amp;amp;#39;; color: #454545; min-height: 14.0px} span.s1 {color: #e4af0a} &amp;lt;/style&amp;gt; &nbsp;&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;p1&amp;quot;&amp;gt;Found this &amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://kauteetech.github.io/vsancapacity/&amp;quot; target=&amp;quot;_blank&amp;quot;&amp;gt;online tool&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; to quickly approximate how much datastore capacity you can get from a certain number of vSAN hosts with certain configuration. I think this is very useful in the case where you already have certain number of physical hosts with vSAN compatible disks, and you want to determine how much capacity you can get from it, and the capacity of cache disk you need to provide to fulfil the 10% recommendation of cache capacity compare to consumed storage (&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://storagehub.vmware.com/t/vmware-vsan/vmware-r-vsan-tm-design-and-sizing-guide/flash-cache-sizing-for-hybrid-configurations-1/&amp;quot; target=&amp;quot;_blank&amp;quot;&amp;gt;reference&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;). In my experience, I have seen couple of customers where they already have considerably new server hardware with vSAN compatible components where they want to see what they will get if they use vSAN. Please note that VMware has &amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://vsantco.vmware.com/vsan/SI/SIEV&amp;quot; target=&amp;quot;_blank&amp;quot;&amp;gt;official vSAN Sizing Calculator&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; where you can get recommendation of the hardware specification you need to provide to accommodate certain number of workloads (VMs).&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;p1&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-AaUU0wXcDDw/WwqX3hZZj1I/AAAAAAAAjMY/KenZZnmmY2YMx7o5d7tNQJ-G69G18GATgCLcBGAs/s1600/Screen%2BShot%2B2018-05-27%2Bat%2B18.15.56.png&amp;quot; imageanchor=&amp;quot;1&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;img border=&amp;quot;0&amp;quot; data-original-height=&amp;quot;1376&amp;quot; data-original-width=&amp;quot;1486&amp;quot; height=&amp;quot;592&amp;quot; width=&amp;quot;640&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;p1&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div width="72"/&gt;&lt;thr:total&gt;0&lt;/thr:total&gt;&lt;/entry&gt;&lt;entry&gt;&lt;id&gt;tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-7374203414060321045.post-5480867707122934848&lt;/id&gt;&lt;published&gt;2018-05-12T12:05:00.004+07:00&lt;/published&gt;&lt;updated&gt;2018-05-12T12:05:51.528+07:00&lt;/updated&gt;&lt;title type='text'&gt;vSphere 5.5 End of General Support Reminder&lt;/title&gt;&lt;content type='html'&gt; &nbsp; &nbsp; &amp;lt;style type=&amp;quot;text/css&amp;quot;&amp;gt;p.p1 {margin: 0.0px 0.0px 0.0px 0.0px; font: 12.0px &amp;amp;#39;Helvetica Neue&amp;amp;#39;; color: #454545} p.p2 {margin: 0.0px 0.0px 0.0px 0.0px; font: 12.0px &amp;amp;#39;Helvetica Neue&amp;amp;#39;; color: #454545; min-height: 14.0px} p.p3 {margin: 0.0px 0.0px 0.0px 0.0px; font: 12.0px &amp;amp;#39;Helvetica Neue&amp;amp;#39;; color: #e4af0a} span.s1 {color: #e4af0a} span.s2 {color: #454545} &amp;lt;/style&amp;gt; &nbsp;&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;&amp;lt;h3&amp;gt;Maintain Full Level of Support by Upgrading Your vSphere Environment&amp;lt;/h3&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;p1&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;p1&amp;quot;&amp;gt;In 2016 I wrote a note regarding &amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://shirazerosagon.blogspot.co.id/2016/11/vsphere-upgrade-consideration.html&amp;quot; target=&amp;quot;_blank&amp;quot;&amp;gt;vSphere upgrade&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; because a lot of my customer at that time was doing upgrade due to vSphere 5.1 EoGS (End of General Support) phase. Well, it’s 2018, and this time you may already aware that vSphere 5.5 will enter EoGS phase in 19 September 2018. Which means, if you still have ESXi hosts 5.5 and/or vCenter Server 5.5, you’ll need to upgrade them in order to maintain your level of full support and subscription services as referenced &amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://kb.vmware.com/s/article/51491&amp;quot; target=&amp;quot;_blank&amp;quot;&amp;gt;here&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;.&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;p2&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-6PYudybsbMI/WvZz7SEgZ3I/AAAAAAAAjDE/H0q3C0wy8sUtGoczWshextTL_vrMjzQMQCLcBGAs/s1600/Screen%2BShot%2B2018-05-12%2Bat%2B11.55.25.png&amp;quot; imageanchor=&amp;quot;1&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;img border=&amp;quot;0&amp;quot; data-original-height=&amp;quot;902&amp;quot; data-original-width=&amp;quot;1580&amp;quot; height=&amp;quot;363&amp;quot; width=&amp;quot;640&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;p2&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;p3&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span class=&amp;quot;s2&amp;quot;&amp;gt;Source: &amp;lt;a width="72"/&gt;&lt;thr:total&gt;0&lt;/thr:total&gt;&lt;/entry&gt;&lt;entry&gt;&lt;id&gt;tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-7374203414060321045.post-603974458193885979&lt;/id&gt;&lt;published&gt;2018-05-06T10:55:00.001+07:00&lt;/published&gt;&lt;updated&gt;2018-05-06T10:57:55.455+07:00&lt;/updated&gt;&lt;title type='text'&gt;Maximum Supported CPU on Windows Server 2003&lt;/title&gt;&lt;content type='html'&gt;&amp;lt;style type=&amp;quot;text/css&amp;quot;&amp;gt;p.p1 {margin: 0.0px 0.0px 0.0px 0.0px; font: 12.0px &amp;amp;#39;Helvetica Neue&amp;amp;#39;; color: #454545} p.p2 {margin: 0.0px 0.0px 0.0px 0.0px; font: 12.0px &amp;amp;#39;Helvetica Neue&amp;amp;#39;; color: #454545; min-height: 14.0px} li.li1 {margin: 0.0px 0.0px 0.0px 0.0px; font: 12.0px &amp;amp;#39;Helvetica Neue&amp;amp;#39;; color: #454545} span.s1 {color: #e4af0a} span.s2 {font: 10.0px Menlo} ul.ul1 {list-style-type: hyphen} ul.ul2 {list-style-type: disc} &amp;lt;/style&amp;gt; &nbsp;&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;p1&amp;quot;&amp;gt;Even though Windows Server 2003 has gone into end of support since July 2015, I still find their existence in my customer environment. Last week, a performance issue raised by one of my customer, where it related with application running on Windows Server 2003. The application just migrated from physical to virtual about 2 weeks before the application team observed slower performance during end of month process. When migrated, they changed the configuration from 2 CPU socket x 4 cores/socket into 4 CPU vSocket x 4 vCores/vSocket. Related to that change, my first thought, do we hit any maximum CPU limit? What is the maximum CPU on Windows Server 2003? This article is a self note about maximum CPU supported on Windows Server 2003.&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;p2&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;p1&amp;quot;&amp;gt;Remember that Windows Server 2003 released in the era where the standard is single core CPU. Looking at the official document from Microsoft such as this &amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://technet.microsoft.com/pt-pt/library/cc758523(v=ws.10).aspx&amp;quot; target=&amp;quot;_blank&amp;quot;&amp;gt;document&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; shows the supported Symmetric Multiprocessing (SMP) each edition of Windows Server 2003. For instance, Windows Server 2003 Standard Edition support 4-way SMP. Now the question is what’s defined as 4-way SMP? I found this &amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://kb.vmware.com/s/article/1010184&amp;quot; target=&amp;quot;_blank&amp;quot;&amp;gt;VMware kb article&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; which says that &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;4-way SMP means 4 CPU socket&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt; (or 4 vSocket in vSphere environment).&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;p2&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://shirazerosagon.blogspot.com/2018/05/maximum-supported-cpu-on-windows-server-2003.html#more&amp;quot;&amp;gt;Read more »&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&lt;/content&gt;&lt;link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='https://shirazerosagon.blogspot.com/feeds/603974458193885979/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/&gt;&lt;link rel='replies' type='text/html' scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="advisory"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="automation"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="I&amp;amp;O"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="Vmware"/&gt;&lt;title type='text'&gt;Build a Case for Infrastructure &amp;amp; Operation Automation Initiative&lt;/title&gt;&lt;content type='html'&gt;This post is part of blog post series focusing on how a company might kickstart their automation or cloud journey.&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;Part 1: &amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;http://bit.ly/2Brgxnq&amp;quot; target=&amp;quot;_blank&amp;quot;&amp;gt;Improve IT Service Delivery Quality with Automation&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;Part 2: Build a Case for Infrastructure &amp;amp;amp; Operation Automation Initiative (this post)&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;Couple of days ago my newsfeed brought me to this paper from Gartner with title &amp;lt;i&amp;gt;“How to Measure the Potential Value of Your I&amp;amp;amp;O Automation Initiatives”&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;. You may get access to this publication freely through this &amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;http://bit.ly/2n6eIrD&amp;quot; target=&amp;quot;_blank&amp;quot;&amp;gt;link&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;. I found this paper is really interesting as it greatly summarized what I always try to told my customer when they want to start their automation or cloud journey. On my previous post &amp;lt;i&amp;gt;“&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;http://bit.ly/2Brgxnq&amp;quot; target=&amp;quot;_blank&amp;quot;&amp;gt;Improve IT Service Delivery Quality with Automation&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;”&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;, I highlighted some use cases taken by some company to kick start their automation journey, which happened to be aligned with what explained in this Gartner’s publication.&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;What initially caught my attention and makes me read the whole paper was the recommendations I quoted below:&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;&amp;lt;blockquote class=&amp;quot;tr_bq&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;times&amp;amp;quot; , &amp;amp;quot;times new roman&amp;amp;quot; , serif;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;I&amp;amp;amp;O leaders who are optimizing operations and need to show the value of their automation spend should:&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;&amp;lt;ul&amp;gt;&amp;lt;li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;times&amp;amp;quot; , &amp;amp;quot;times new roman&amp;amp;quot; , serif;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;Justify I&amp;amp;amp;O automation initiatives by focusing first on efficiency improvements in labor usage and on effectiveness gains in quality, consistency, agility and risk reduction.&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/ul&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/blockquote&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://shirazerosagon.blogspot.com/2018/01/build-case-for-io-automation-initiative.html#more&amp;quot;&amp;gt;Read more »&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&lt;/content&gt;&lt;link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='https://shirazerosagon.blogspot.com/feeds/2904208342083423653/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/&gt;&lt;link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='https://shirazerosagon.blogspot.com/2018/01/build-case-for-io-automation-initiative.html#comment-form' title='1 Comments'/&gt;&lt;link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='https://www.blogger.com/feeds/7374203414060321045/posts/default/2904208342083423653'/&gt;&lt;link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='https://www.blogger.com/feeds/7374203414060321045/posts/default/2904208342083423653'/&gt;&lt;link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='https://shirazerosagon.blogspot.com/2018/01/build-case-for-io-automation-initiative.html' title='Build a Case for Infrastructure &amp;amp; Operation Automation Initiative'/&gt;&lt;author&gt;&lt;name&gt;Shiraz Erosagon&lt;/name&gt;&lt;uri&gt;http://www.blogger.com/profile/15746064654668743879&lt;/uri&gt;&lt;email&gt;<span class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="7816170a1d081401381a14171f1f1d0a561b1715">[email&#160;protected]</span>&lt;/email&gt;&lt;gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='32' height='32' src='//1.bp.blogspot.com/-TpTvn5RzA8g/WQ5-8-utM7I/AAAAAAAAZrU/Y3-sPBBWGXgQwPagL4d0yXnqb4bRjpJIgCK4B/s113/Lesmana_Eros_Square.jpg'/&gt;&lt;/author&gt;&lt;media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-G6xQyaC85XY/WmmSRoSRwxI/AAAAAAAAgrk/4dihaTvrk5Uf7IhaKqCqcMPLSGjq9_VQgCLcBGAs/s72-c/Screen%2BShot%2B2018-01-25%2Bat%2B14.29.38.png" height="72" width="72"/&gt;&lt;thr:total&gt;1&lt;/thr:total&gt;&lt;/entry&gt;&lt;entry&gt;&lt;id&gt;tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-7374203414060321045.post-5325988746774888191&lt;/id&gt;&lt;published&gt;2017-12-29T19:23:00.000+07:00&lt;/published&gt;&lt;updated&gt;2018-01-26T08:07:37.724+07:00&lt;/updated&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="Vmware"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="vRA"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="vRealize Automation"/&gt;&lt;title type='text'&gt;Improve IT Service Delivery Quality with Automation&lt;/title&gt;&lt;content type='html'&gt;This post is part of blog post series focusing on how a company might kickstart their automation or cloud journey.&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;Part 1: Improve IT Service Delivery Quality with Automation (this post)&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;Part 2: &amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://shirazerosagon.blogspot.com/2018/01/build-case-for-io-automation-initiative.html&amp;quot; target=&amp;quot;_blank&amp;quot;&amp;gt;Build a Case for Infrastructure &amp;amp;amp; Operation Automation Initiative&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;I delivered a session during VMware vForum 2017 Indonesia back in November 2017 about how a company can kick start their automation journey and get the value from it. Automation itself is a very extensive topic and one should choose what to automate carefully. IMO, it should start with repetitive tasks which will bring value to business if automated. Begin with something that is easy to automate, and along the journey, adds more tasks to further complete what requires to deliver a service. Quick wins built confidence. Do not try to automate everything in one go, as it will be complex, costly, and give you headache in supporting it. This post is a rewrite what delivered during my vForum 2017 Indonesia session, which would like to give ideas on where to start and what challenges it will solve by doing it.&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;There are 4 use cases that I presented:&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;&amp;lt;ul&amp;gt;&amp;lt;li&amp;gt;Accelerate delivery and improve consistency of application environments&amp;lt;/li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;li&amp;gt;Manage VM sprawl by automated lifecycle enforcement&amp;lt;/li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;li&amp;gt;Providing secure access to 3rd party vendor&amp;lt;/li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;li&amp;gt;Continuous Delivery for apps and SDDC&amp;lt;/li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/ul&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;Below I try to explain on challenges that each use cases try to solve, and how VMware can solve that challenges. The solution mainly powered by VMware vRealize Automation.&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;&amp;lt;h4&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/h4&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://shirazerosagon.blogspot.com/2017/12/improve-it-service-delivery-quality.html#more&amp;quot;&amp;gt;Read more »&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&lt;/content&gt;&lt;link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='https://shirazerosagon.blogspot.com/feeds/5325988746774888191/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/&gt;&lt;link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='https://shirazerosagon.blogspot.com/2017/12/improve-it-service-delivery-quality.html#comment-form' title='0 Comments'/&gt;&lt;link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='https://www.blogger.com/feeds/7374203414060321045/posts/default/5325988746774888191'/&gt;&lt;link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='https://www.blogger.com/feeds/7374203414060321045/posts/default/5325988746774888191'/&gt;&lt;link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='https://shirazerosagon.blogspot.com/2017/12/improve-it-service-delivery-quality.html' title='Improve IT Service Delivery Quality with Automation'/&gt;&lt;author&gt;&lt;name&gt;Shiraz Erosagon&lt;/name&gt;&lt;uri&gt;http://www.blogger.com/profile/15746064654668743879&lt;/uri&gt;&lt;email&gt;<span class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="721c1d0017021e0b32101e1d151517005c111d1f">[email&#160;protected]</span>&lt;/email&gt;&lt;gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='32' height='32' src='//1.bp.blogspot.com/-TpTvn5RzA8g/WQ5-8-utM7I/AAAAAAAAZrU/Y3-sPBBWGXgQwPagL4d0yXnqb4bRjpJIgCK4B/s113/Lesmana_Eros_Square.jpg'/&gt;&lt;/author&gt;&lt;thr:total&gt;0&lt;/thr:total&gt;&lt;/entry&gt;&lt;entry&gt;&lt;id&gt;tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-7374203414060321045.post-7669085534808297448&lt;/id&gt;&lt;published&gt;2017-12-26T20:04:00.000+07:00&lt;/published&gt;&lt;updated&gt;2017-12-26T20:06:42.579+07:00&lt;/updated&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="#NSXUenak"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="NSX"/&gt;&lt;title type='text'&gt;#NSXUenak: A Testimony from An NSX User&lt;/title&gt;&lt;content type='html'&gt;One of my customer spoke in a customer testimony session during VMware vForum 2017 held at Jakarta, Indonesia back in November 2017. One word he kept using to describe his satisfaction in using NSX is &amp;lt;i&amp;gt;UENAK&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;. &amp;lt;i&amp;gt;Uenak&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;, is some kind of an accentuate expression derived from the word &amp;lt;i&amp;gt;enak&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;, which is &amp;lt;i&amp;gt;Bahasa Indonesia&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt; for good, comfortable, or pleasant. During his more or less 10 minutes session, he mentioned &amp;lt;i&amp;gt;uenak&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt; for at least 5 times to express his feeling after using NSX. This post is a rewrite of what he mentioned during the session.&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;NSX uenak&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt; because it helps on the &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;scalability&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;. Distributed router and distributed firewall move east-west traffic from what it used to be centralized in physical device (core switch or firewall) to be processed in the transport layer (eg. the ESXi hosts). It is important to them as the nature of their business requires flexible scalability. With NSX (and vSphere), every time they add new hosts, they not only add compute (CPU and RAM) capacity, but also network capacity (in term of bandwidth and additional power to process traffic routing and segmentation/isolation.&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://shirazerosagon.blogspot.com/2017/12/nsxuenak-testimony-from-an-nsx-user.html#more&amp;quot;&amp;gt;Read more »&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&lt;/content&gt;&lt;link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='https://shirazerosagon.blogspot.com/feeds/7669085534808297448/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/&gt;&lt;link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='https://shirazerosagon.blogspot.com/2017/12/nsxuenak-testimony-from-an-nsx-user.html#comment-form' title='0 Comments'/&gt;&lt;link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='https://www.blogger.com/feeds/7374203414060321045/posts/default/7669085534808297448'/&gt;&lt;link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='https://www.blogger.com/feeds/7374203414060321045/posts/default/7669085534808297448'/&gt;&lt;link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='https://shirazerosagon.blogspot.com/2017/12/nsxuenak-testimony-from-an-nsx-user.html' title='#NSXUenak: A Testimony from An NSX User'/&gt;&lt;author&gt;&lt;name&gt;Shiraz Erosagon&lt;/name&gt;&lt;uri&gt;http://www.blogger.com/profile/15746064654668743879&lt;/uri&gt;&lt;email&gt;<span class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="dab4b5a8bfaab6a39ab8b6b5bdbdbfa8f4b9b5b7">[email&#160;protected]</span>&lt;/email&gt;&lt;gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='32' height='32' src='//1.bp.blogspot.com/-TpTvn5RzA8g/WQ5-8-utM7I/AAAAAAAAZrU/Y3-sPBBWGXgQwPagL4d0yXnqb4bRjpJIgCK4B/s113/Lesmana_Eros_Square.jpg'/&gt;&lt;/author&gt;&lt;thr:total&gt;0&lt;/thr:total&gt;&lt;/entry&gt;&lt;entry&gt;&lt;id&gt;tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-7374203414060321045.post-4136951525849448325&lt;/id&gt;&lt;published&gt;2017-07-27T17:11:00.000+07:00&lt;/published&gt;&lt;updated&gt;2017-12-29T18:50:43.376+07:00&lt;/updated&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="API"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="Infrastructure as Code"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="Vmware"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="vRA"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="vRealize Automation"/&gt;&lt;title type='text'&gt;Infrastructure as Code&lt;/title&gt;&lt;content type='html'&gt;&amp;lt;h3&amp;gt;Consuming vRA Catalog Item using REST API&amp;lt;/h3&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;I&amp;amp;#39;m preparing a demo to show how developer can consume infrastructure layer by using API. I have the cloud management platform using VMware vRealize Automation up and working, blueprints already created, catalog set for user and ready to consume. Now the question is how to consume the Catalog Item using API. Thankfully a colleague point me to a blog from &amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;http://www.linkedin.com/pub/ryan-kelly/3/a22/88/&amp;quot; target=&amp;quot;_blank&amp;quot;&amp;gt;Ryan Kelly&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; here:&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;http://www.vmtocloud.com/how-to-script-a-vrealize-automation-7-rest-api-request/&amp;quot;&amp;gt;http://www.vmtocloud.com/how-to-script-a-vrealize-automation-7-rest-api-request/&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;.&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;The article is awesome, it shows step-by-step on how to do it so you will understand the flow, which will be useful for further exploration. And at the end of the article, it wrapped all the steps into one script that user can call to request the catalog item. After that, it only requires to run the script to do the request.&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://shirazerosagon.blogspot.com/2017/07/infrastructure-as-code.html#more&amp;quot;&amp;gt;Read more »&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&lt;/content&gt;&lt;link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='https://shirazerosagon.blogspot.com/feeds/4136951525849448325/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/&gt;&lt;link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='https://shirazerosagon.blogspot.com/2017/07/infrastructure-as-code.html#comment-form' title='0 Comments'/&gt;&lt;link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='https://www.blogger.com/feeds/7374203414060321045/posts/default/4136951525849448325'/&gt;&lt;link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='https://www.blogger.com/feeds/7374203414060321045/posts/default/4136951525849448325'/&gt;&lt;link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='https://shirazerosagon.blogspot.com/2017/07/infrastructure-as-code.html' title='Infrastructure as Code'/&gt;&lt;author&gt;&lt;name&gt;Shiraz Erosagon&lt;/name&gt;&lt;uri&gt;http://www.blogger.com/profile/15746064654668743879&lt;/uri&gt;&lt;email&gt;<span class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="1977766b7c697560597b75767e7e7c6b377a7674">[email&#160;protected]</span>&lt;/email&gt;&lt;gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='32' height='32' src='//1.bp.blogspot.com/-TpTvn5RzA8g/WQ5-8-utM7I/AAAAAAAAZrU/Y3-sPBBWGXgQwPagL4d0yXnqb4bRjpJIgCK4B/s113/Lesmana_Eros_Square.jpg'/&gt;&lt;/author&gt;&lt;media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-9xWhHcL_Wp4/WXm6cY_1JtI/AAAAAAAAc8c/Hemafw_i8uIFbzM_urSudAKGroC5PmM7wCLcBGAs/s72-c/Screen%2BShot%2B2017-07-27%2Bat%2B15.55.14.png" height="72" width="72"/&gt;&lt;thr:total&gt;0&lt;/thr:total&gt;&lt;/entry&gt;&lt;entry&gt;&lt;id&gt;tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-7374203414060321045.post-237994675773620327&lt;/id&gt;&lt;published&gt;2017-05-18T08:00:00.000+07:00&lt;/published&gt;&lt;updated&gt;2018-01-26T08:16:50.602+07:00&lt;/updated&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="Best Practices"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="P2V"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="Vmware"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="vROps"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="vSphere"/&gt;&lt;title type='text'&gt;VM Performance Issue Troubleshooting&lt;/title&gt;&lt;content type='html'&gt;&amp;lt;h3&amp;gt;Always Remove Unnecessary Hardware on a VM after Doing P2V&amp;lt;/h3&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;One day, a customer of mine called me asking for advise for an application that his team has just P2V but was having performance issue. As usual, my response was to understand the issue and the application itself, came up with some suggestions, including asked them to raise a support request (SR) to VMware Support. Couple of days passed by, but no resolution on the issue. So I decide to visit the customer to see whether I can help. This blog documents the process I took which ended on resolving the issue, and points out one important step post P2V which tends to be missed out.&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;&amp;lt;h4&amp;gt;What&amp;amp;#39;s the issue? On what ground the user said the application is slow?&amp;lt;/h4&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;This is the first thing I try to understand if facing a performance issue. Can the user really quantify the slowness? Or is it just based on feeling? For this case, the performance issue was quite clear. They showed me that running one process took about 10 seconds in P2V app, where in physical normally only 3 seconds. Ok, now I know what to expect. My goal was to get that 3 seconds back.&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;&amp;lt;h4&amp;gt;What&amp;amp;#39;s the application? How&amp;amp;#39;s the architecture? How user access it?&amp;lt;/h4&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;Next is to know what application is that. We might want to cross-check whether any documented best practice available for that application. One place to check is at &amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;http://www.vmware.com/solutions/business-critical-apps.html&amp;quot; target=&amp;quot;_blank&amp;quot;&amp;gt;Virtualizing Business Critical Applications&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; page on VMware website, or just Google with keyword &amp;amp;quot;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;application name&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt; on VMware best practices&amp;amp;quot;. If one exists, you can use it to later check whether the VM/application already configured according to the best practices.&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://shirazerosagon.blogspot.com/2017/05/vm-performance-issue-troubleshooting.html#more&amp;quot;&amp;gt;Read more »&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&lt;/content&gt;&lt;link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='https://shirazerosagon.blogspot.com/feeds/237994675773620327/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/&gt;&lt;link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='https://shirazerosagon.blogspot.com/2017/05/vm-performance-issue-troubleshooting.html#comment-form' title='0 Comments'/&gt;&lt;link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='https://www.blogger.com/feeds/7374203414060321045/posts/default/237994675773620327'/&gt;&lt;link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='https://www.blogger.com/feeds/7374203414060321045/posts/default/237994675773620327'/&gt;&lt;link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='https://shirazerosagon.blogspot.com/2017/05/vm-performance-issue-troubleshooting.html' title='VM Performance Issue Troubleshooting'/&gt;&lt;author&gt;&lt;name&gt;Shiraz Erosagon&lt;/name&gt;&lt;uri&gt;http://www.blogger.com/profile/15746064654668743879&lt;/uri&gt;&lt;email&gt;<span class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="107e7f6275607c6950727c7f777775623e737f7d">[email&#160;protected]</span>&lt;/email&gt;&lt;gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='32' height='32' src='//1.bp.blogspot.com/-TpTvn5RzA8g/WQ5-8-utM7I/AAAAAAAAZrU/Y3-sPBBWGXgQwPagL4d0yXnqb4bRjpJIgCK4B/s113/Lesmana_Eros_Square.jpg'/&gt;&lt;/author&gt;&lt;thr:total&gt;0&lt;/thr:total&gt;&lt;/entry&gt;&lt;entry&gt;&lt;id&gt;tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-7374203414060321045.post-1533043915820622375&lt;/id&gt;&lt;published&gt;2017-05-04T17:52:00.000+07:00&lt;/published&gt;&lt;updated&gt;2017-05-04T17:53:04.659+07:00&lt;/updated&gt;&lt;title type='text'&gt;My VCAP6-DCV Deployment Exam Preparation&lt;/title&gt;&lt;content type='html'&gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;p1&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: Trebuchet MS, sans-serif; font-size: small;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;Last Friday, I finally sat on my VCAP6-DCV Deployment Exam after around 6 weeks of intensive preparation. The preparation itself is really exhausting. Need a lot of determination to keep it going with my study plan, and that includes sacrificing so many precious time with my loved ones during weekends and public holidays, which somehow there&amp;amp;#39;s so many public holiday in Indonesia in the last 6 weeks, and I don&amp;amp;#39;t know how many glass of coffees to ensure my eyes and brain active to receive all the information. My study plan is simple, VCAP6-DCV Deploy Exam has 26 objectives from 8 sections. So everyday, I try to cover all skills and abilities required for one objective. Though, a lot of time I missed the time target since the objective is so extensive to cover, or I was bustled with my work. I started my study with the blueprint sections which I think I strong, which are storage, network, availability and scalability, and performance, and then continue to the rest of blueprint sections.&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;p1&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: Trebuchet MS, sans-serif; font-size: small;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;p1&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: Trebuchet MS, sans-serif; font-size: small;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;Here is some sources which help me preparing the exam:&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;ul&amp;gt;&amp;lt;li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: Trebuchet MS, sans-serif;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;Official Exam Blueprint: &amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://mylearn.vmware.com/mgrReg/plan.cfm?plan=88753&amp;amp;amp;ui=www_cert&amp;quot;&amp;gt;https://mylearn.vmware.com/mgrReg/plan.cfm?plan=88753&amp;amp;amp;ui=www_cert&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;ul&amp;gt;&amp;lt;li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: Trebuchet MS, sans-serif;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;Officially only available online, pdf (like in VCAP5 days) no longer available&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: Trebuchet MS, sans-serif;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;This blueprint will tell you all the official documents you need to be able to cover all skills and abilities required.&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;ul&amp;gt;&amp;lt;li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: Trebuchet MS, sans-serif;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;Read each skill and ability from each objective, find related basic theory on the manual, and then practice the steps required to implement that objective.&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/ul&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/ul&amp;gt;&amp;lt;li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: Trebuchet MS, sans-serif;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;VCAP6-DCV Deployment Study Group: &amp;lt;span class=&amp;quot;s2&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://plus.google.com/u/0/communities/108002000588564278612&amp;quot;&amp;gt;https://plus.google.com/u/0/communities/108002000588564278612&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;ul&amp;gt;&amp;lt;li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: Trebuchet MS, sans-serif;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;Check this Google+ group for other test takers experience on preparing the exam.&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/ul&amp;gt;&amp;lt;li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: Trebuchet MS, sans-serif;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;Notable Study Guide (For Kyle Jenner, Mordi Shushan, and Ramy Mahmoud who dedicated their time to write these great study guides, your work are awesome! Much appreciated.)&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;ul&amp;gt;&amp;lt;li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;http://www.vjenner.com/vcap6-dcv-deployment-study-guide/&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: Trebuchet MS, sans-serif;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;http://www.vjenner.com/vcap6-dcv-deployment-study-guide/&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;http://vpentathlon.com/vcap-dcv-deploy-study-guide/&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: Trebuchet MS, sans-serif;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;http://vpentathlon.com/vcap-dcv-deploy-study-guide/&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://ucconnect.wordpress.com/2016/08/21/vcap6-dcv-deployment-study-guide/&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: Trebuchet MS, sans-serif;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;https://ucconnect.wordpress.com/2016/08/21/vcap6-dcv-deployment-study-guide/&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: Trebuchet MS, sans-serif;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;These study guides summarise the basic theory and implementation steps for each objective. They are really great in helping me to speed up the study time and focus on things required for the exam, but still I suggests everyone who want to take the exam to also spend enough time to read the official documentations.&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/ul&amp;gt;&amp;lt;li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: Trebuchet MS, sans-serif;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;VMware Hands-on Lab: &amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;http://labs.hol.vmware.com/&amp;quot;&amp;gt;http://labs.hol.vmware.com&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;.&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;ul&amp;gt;&amp;lt;li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: Trebuchet MS, sans-serif;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;One of the key thing for this exam is to get your hands-on, so having access to a lab is really crucial. I have my personal lab, build a nested ESXi using VMware Fusion on two Macbook Pro, but I also leverage VMware Hands-on Lab extensively.&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;ul&amp;gt;&amp;lt;li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: Trebuchet MS, sans-serif;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;FYI my HOL account transcript records that I completed 25 labs during my exam preparation period. Some labs taken couple of times since the same lab can be used to cover some objectives.&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/ul&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/ul&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/ul&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: Trebuchet MS, sans-serif;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;p3&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: Trebuchet MS, sans-serif; font-size: small;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a src=&amp;quot;https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-Fd-1LhoLDgI/WDwJuJNgtkI/AAAAAAAAOtM/oEnrUlcdFK8w5BKvumgcKOMErQEfZ2VfwCLcB/s400/upgrade.png&amp;quot; width=&amp;quot;400&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;p1&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;p1&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;p1&amp;quot;&amp;gt;Recently, a lot of my customer are planning, doing, or have just done vSphere upgrade. Mostly due to vSphere 5.1 which already in end of general support phase per 24 August 2016. Technical guidance will still be provided for vSphere 5.1 until 24 August 2018 (For a complete important date on your product support phase, please check this VMware &amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;http://www.vmware.com/content/dam/digitalmarketing/vmware/en/pdf/support/product-lifecycle-matrix.pdf&amp;quot; target=&amp;quot;_blank&amp;quot;&amp;gt;product lifecycle matrix&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;.), but please note that no more security patches or bug fixes will be released for vSphere 5.1 in the future, unless stated otherwise. Other than that, during technical guidance phase, support request will only be given to low-severities issues on supported configuration only as stated in this VMware &amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://www.vmware.com/support/policies.html#lifecyclepolicies&amp;quot; target=&amp;quot;_blank&amp;quot;&amp;gt;lifecycle policies&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;. This is my personal notes on some information which can help in planning VMware environment upgrade.&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;p1&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://shirazerosagon.blogspot.com/2016/11/vsphere-upgrade-consideration.html#more&amp;quot;&amp;gt;Read more »&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&lt;/content&gt;&lt;link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='https://shirazerosagon.blogspot.com/feeds/8068640446847487386/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/&gt;&lt;link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='https://shirazerosagon.blogspot.com/2016/11/vsphere-upgrade-consideration.html#comment-form' title='0 Comments'/&gt;&lt;link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='https://www.blogger.com/feeds/7374203414060321045/posts/default/8068640446847487386'/&gt;&lt;link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='https://shirazerosagon.blogspot.com/2016/11/vsphere-upgrade-consideration.html' title='vSphere (and Some Other Products) Upgrade Notes '/&gt;&lt;author&gt;&lt;name&gt;Shiraz Erosagon&lt;/name&gt;&lt;uri&gt;http://www.blogger.com/profile/15746064654668743879&lt;/uri&gt;&lt;email&gt;<span class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="442a2b362134283d0426282b232321366a272b29">[email&#160;protected]</span>&lt;/email&gt;&lt;gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='32' height='32' src='//1.bp.blogspot.com/-TpTvn5RzA8g/WQ5-8-utM7I/AAAAAAAAZrU/Y3-sPBBWGXgQwPagL4d0yXnqb4bRjpJIgCK4B/s113/Lesmana_Eros_Square.jpg'/&gt;&lt;/author&gt;&lt;media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-Fd-1LhoLDgI/WDwJuJNgtkI/AAAAAAAAOtM/oEnrUlcdFK8w5BKvumgcKOMErQEfZ2VfwCLcB/s72-c/upgrade.png" height="72" width="72"/&gt;&lt;thr:total&gt;0&lt;/thr:total&gt;&lt;/entry&gt;&lt;entry&gt;&lt;id&gt;tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-7374203414060321045.post-8221201907401739324&lt;/id&gt;&lt;published&gt;2016-11-14T23:11:00.001+07:00&lt;/published&gt;&lt;updated&gt;2016-11-14T23:19:52.787+07:00&lt;/updated&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="Co Stop"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="CPU Contention"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="CPU Ready"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="CPU scheduler"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="CPU state"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="CSTP"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="HOL"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="performance"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="RDY"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="RUN"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="vCPU"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="Vmware"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="WAIT"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="World"/&gt;&lt;title type='text'&gt;Why Guest OS Task Manager is Showing Different Value Compare to vSphere Performance Monitor? &lt;/title&gt;&lt;content type='html'&gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;h3&amp;gt;Demystifying CPU States in vCPU World&amp;lt;/h3&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;Have you experienced a situation where your guest OS task manager is showing different value compare to vSphere performance monitor? Or you get a request for additional vCPU from the application team which uses your VM because they see their VM utilizing almost all vCPU they have, but when you check vCPU usage of that VM in your vSphere web client, it only shows low utilization? Is there something wrong? Before you think there&amp;amp;#39;s something wrong with vSphere performance monitor, read this article to understand what&amp;amp;#39;s causing that situation.&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;table align=&amp;quot;center&amp;quot; cellpadding=&amp;quot;0&amp;quot; cellspacing=&amp;quot;0&amp;quot; class=&amp;quot;tr-caption-container&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;tbody&amp;gt;&amp;lt;tr&amp;gt;&amp;lt;td style=&amp;quot;text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-93-nLBdhg_o/WCnLLXYVnUI/AAAAAAAAL80/_JeGMH1Dz00OYqmFLuhkTz6__pFpTdJCQCLcB/s1600/Screen%2BShot%2B2016-11-14%2Bat%2B21.20.15.png&amp;quot; imageanchor=&amp;quot;1&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;img alt=&amp;quot;&amp;quot; border=&amp;quot;0&amp;quot; height=&amp;quot;311&amp;quot; src=&amp;quot;https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-93-nLBdhg_o/WCnLLXYVnUI/AAAAAAAAL80/_JeGMH1Dz00OYqmFLuhkTz6__pFpTdJCQCLcB/s400/Screen%2BShot%2B2016-11-14%2Bat%2B21.20.15.png&amp;quot; title=&amp;quot;Windows task manager shows ~100% CPU Utilization&amp;quot; width=&amp;quot;400&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/td&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/tr&amp;gt;&amp;lt;tr&amp;gt;&amp;lt;td class=&amp;quot;tr-caption&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;Figure 1. Windows task manager shows ~100% CPU Utilization&amp;lt;/td&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/tr&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/tbody&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/table&amp;gt;Before going further, let me first describe the situation clearer. Figure 1 and 2 are coming from the same Virtual Machine, &amp;lt;i&amp;gt;perf-worker-01b&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;. The first figure shows Windows Task Manager where the CPU utilization is hitting 100% for most of the last 4 minutes. The second figure shows vSphere performance monitor which taken about the same time as Figure 1, and this figure reveals that for the last 4 minutes, VM CPU usage is only around 50%. FYI, I actually ran a CPU benchmark tool on perf-worker-01b for about 30 minutes, and for most of the time in that period, Windows task manager showed 100% CPU utilization, while vSphere performance monitor showed around 50% CPU usage. Why vSphere performance monitor only showed 50% CPU usage when Windows task manager showed ~100%?&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://shirazerosagon.blogspot.com/2016/11/understanding-vm-cpu-state.html#more&amp;quot;&amp;gt;Read more »&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&lt;/content&gt;&lt;link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='https://shirazerosagon.blogspot.com/feeds/8221201907401739324/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/&gt;&lt;link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='https://shirazerosagon.blogspot.com/2016/11/understanding-vm-cpu-state.html#comment-form' title='0 Comments'/&gt;&lt;link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='https://www.blogger.com/feeds/7374203414060321045/posts/default/8221201907401739324'/&gt;&lt;link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='https://www.blogger.com/feeds/7374203414060321045/posts/default/8221201907401739324'/&gt;&lt;link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='https://shirazerosagon.blogspot.com/2016/11/understanding-vm-cpu-state.html' title='Why Guest OS Task Manager is Showing Different Value Compare to vSphere Performance Monitor? '/&gt;&lt;author&gt;&lt;name&gt;Shiraz Erosagon&lt;/name&gt;&lt;uri&gt;http://www.blogger.com/profile/15746064654668743879&lt;/uri&gt;&lt;email&gt;<span class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="1e70716c7b6e72675e7c727179797b6c307d7173">[email&#160;protected]</span>&lt;/email&gt;&lt;gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='32' height='32' src='//1.bp.blogspot.com/-TpTvn5RzA8g/WQ5-8-utM7I/AAAAAAAAZrU/Y3-sPBBWGXgQwPagL4d0yXnqb4bRjpJIgCK4B/s113/Lesmana_Eros_Square.jpg'/&gt;&lt;/author&gt;&lt;media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-93-nLBdhg_o/WCnLLXYVnUI/AAAAAAAAL80/_JeGMH1Dz00OYqmFLuhkTz6__pFpTdJCQCLcB/s72-c/Screen%2BShot%2B2016-11-14%2Bat%2B21.20.15.png" height="72" width="72"/&gt;&lt;thr:total&gt;0&lt;/thr:total&gt;&lt;/entry&gt;&lt;entry&gt;&lt;id&gt;tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-7374203414060321045.post-2441776268853695241&lt;/id&gt;&lt;published&gt;2016-11-07T20:00:00.000+07:00&lt;/published&gt;&lt;updated&gt;2016-11-07T20:00:22.780+07:00&lt;/updated&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="How to"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="Vmware"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="vRealize Operations Manager"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="vROps"/&gt;&lt;title type='text'&gt;Quickly Identify Whether My Virtual Machines Get All CPU Resources They Need &lt;/title&gt;&lt;content type='html'&gt;&amp;lt;h4&amp;gt;Background&amp;lt;/h4&amp;gt;One of the capability brings by virtualization is the ability to run several virtual machines in one physical machine. This ability may lead to something called over provisioned, where we provisioned resources to VMs more than what we have in the physical layer. For instance, we can create 20 VMs, where each has 4 vCPUs - in total of 80 vCPUs provisioned, while the server we used only has 20 CPU cores. Wait.. wait.... If we only has 20, how can we give 80? How can we give more than what we actually had? Actually the answers is one of the reason why virtualization rose in the first place: most of our server has - in average - low CPU utilization and each server has different time in experiencing peak and low utilization. VMware vSphere manages how VMs get their turn utilizing physical CPU resources in efficient and fair manner by a component called CPU Scheduler. In simple word, CPU Scheduler is like traffic light. It rules who may go, or in this case who may use the physical CPU resources, and who need to stop and wait. More about CPU Scheduler can be found on this &amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;http://www.vmware.com/techpapers/2013/the-cpu-scheduler-in-vmware-vsphere-51-10345.html&amp;quot; target=&amp;quot;_blank&amp;quot;&amp;gt;CPU Scheduler Technical Whitepaper&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;.&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;Using the analogy of traffic light, we know that at one time, the number of cars can go will be defined by numbers of lanes available. If the road has 4 lanes, then only maximum of 4 cars can pass at the same time, other cars will queue behind the first row. This is also true in virtualization, even though we can do over provisioning, what CPU scheduler can schedule at a time will be limited to how many  logical CPUs available on the physical server. Means, if at any one time there are several VMs, with total vCPUs more than available logical CPUs, asking for their share to use logical CPUs, then some of those VMs will need to queue. By having to queue, it will takes longer for a VM to finish its job. Now the challenge is how to identify this queue, and furthermore how to manage that queue into an acceptable timeframe. This article will try to answer the first part, while for the latter will be discussed in the future article.&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;&amp;lt;h4&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/h4&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://shirazerosagon.blogspot.com/2016/11/quickly-identify-cpu-contention-with-vrops.html#more&amp;quot;&amp;gt;Read more »&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&lt;/content&gt;&lt;link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='https://shirazerosagon.blogspot.com/feeds/2441776268853695241/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/&gt;&lt;link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='https://shirazerosagon.blogspot.com/2016/11/quickly-identify-cpu-contention-with-vrops.html#comment-form' title='3 Comments'/&gt;&lt;link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='https://www.blogger.com/feeds/7374203414060321045/posts/default/2441776268853695241'/&gt;&lt;link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='https://www.blogger.com/feeds/7374203414060321045/posts/default/2441776268853695241'/&gt;&lt;link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='https://shirazerosagon.blogspot.com/2016/11/quickly-identify-cpu-contention-with-vrops.html' title='Quickly Identify Whether My Virtual Machines Get All CPU Resources They Need '/&gt;&lt;author&gt;&lt;name&gt;Shiraz Erosagon&lt;/name&gt;&lt;uri&gt;http://www.blogger.com/profile/15746064654668743879&lt;/uri&gt;&lt;email&gt;<span class="__cf_email__" width="72"/&gt;&lt;thr:total&gt;3&lt;/thr:total&gt;&lt;/entry&gt;&lt;entry&gt;&lt;id&gt;tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-7374203414060321045.post-7503366847772766357&lt;/id&gt;&lt;published&gt;2016-10-24T20:00:00.000+07:00&lt;/published&gt;&lt;updated&gt;2016-10-24T20:10:20.004+07:00&lt;/updated&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="opinion"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="security"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="VM encryption"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="Vmware"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="vSphere 6.5"/&gt;&lt;title type='text'&gt;VMware Virtual Machine Virtual Disk Security&lt;/title&gt;&lt;content type='html'&gt;&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;p1&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span class=&amp;quot;s1&amp;quot;&amp;gt;Last week, during VMworld 2016 Europe, VMware announces the latest release of vSphere 6.5. You can check this, amongst other things being announced, on this &amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;http://www.vmware.com/company/news/releases/vmw-newsfeed.VMware-Advances-Cross-Cloud-Architecture-with-New-Releases-of-vSphere,-Virtual-SAN-and-vRealize-Solutions-to-Drive-IT-and-Developer-Productivity.2104600.html&amp;quot; target=&amp;quot;_blank&amp;quot;&amp;gt;press release&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;. One area of improvement for vSphere 6.5 is in virtual infrastructure security which you can read &amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;http://blogs.vmware.com/vsphere/2016/10/whats-new-in-vsphere-6-5-security.html&amp;quot; target=&amp;quot;_blank&amp;quot;&amp;gt;here&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;. What interests me related to the new security features is &amp;lt;i&amp;gt;VM encryption&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;, as some customers which I met asked about this capability. So I dug out an old post which originally &amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;was a personal notes I wrote back in 2014 about some points of discussion regarding virtual disk security, and modify it to be relevant with the recent announcement. &amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;p2&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span class=&amp;quot;s1&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;p1&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span class=&amp;quot;s1&amp;quot;&amp;gt;OK, let&amp;amp;#39;s understand the problem first. &amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;Remember one of the characteristic of virtualisation? Encapsulation. In other word, VM basically is only a set of files. If those files happened to be walked out the door, then people can mount it up, extract the files/information, or even have the VM up and running. Check this &amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;http://searchvmware.techtarget.com/news/1378347/How-to-steal-a-virtual-machine-and-its-data-in-3-easy-steps&amp;quot; target=&amp;quot;_blank&amp;quot;&amp;gt;article&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; if you want to get the idea on how that could be done.&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;You might say that if that situation happened, that means that company not applying a good security policy, and if that is the case, anything can happened, even in non virtualise world. Well you got that right, but let&amp;amp;#39;s see what we can do to prevent that situation, how VMware able to cater this situation, how VMware can make sure that if virtual disk leakage happened, the person who have it could not take advantage from it.&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://shirazerosagon.blogspot.com/2016/10/vsphere65-vm-encryption.html#more&amp;quot;&amp;gt;Read more »&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&lt;/content&gt;&lt;link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='https://shirazerosagon.blogspot.com/feeds/7503366847772766357/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/&gt;&lt;link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='https://shirazerosagon.blogspot.com/2016/10/vsphere65-vm-encryption.html#comment-form' title='0 Comments'/&gt;&lt;link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='https://shirazerosagon.blogspot.com/2016/10/vsphere65-vm-encryption.html' title='VMware Virtual Machine Virtual Disk Security'/&gt;&lt;author&gt;&lt;name&gt;Shiraz Erosagon&lt;/name&gt;&lt;uri&gt;http://www.blogger.com/profile/15746064654668743879&lt;/uri&gt;&lt;email&gt;<span class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="5c32332e392c30251c3e30333b3b392e723f3331">[email&#160;protected]</span>&lt;/email&gt;&lt;gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='32' height='32' src='//1.bp.blogspot.com/-TpTvn5RzA8g/WQ5-8-utM7I/AAAAAAAAZrU/Y3-sPBBWGXgQwPagL4d0yXnqb4bRjpJIgCK4B/s113/Lesmana_Eros_Square.jpg'/&gt;&lt;/author&gt;&lt;media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-m3lGJqMDNpA/WA3xB2BAE9I/AAAAAAAAL5s/Z9zmF7NEojw82gq6-rwOFW2JIinsjCfowCLcB/s72-c/Screen%2BShot%2B2016-10-24%2Bat%2B18.27.56.png" height="72" width="72"/&gt;&lt;thr:total&gt;0&lt;/thr:total&gt;&lt;/entry&gt;&lt;entry&gt;&lt;id&gt;tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-7374203414060321045.post-2984965327007024533&lt;/id&gt;&lt;published&gt;2016-10-17T20:14:00.002+07:00&lt;/published&gt;&lt;updated&gt;2016-10-17T20:14:53.443+07:00&lt;/updated&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="Fusion"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="lab"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="lunar.lab"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="ospf"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="router"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="routing"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="Vmware"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="vyatta"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="vyos"/&gt;&lt;title type='text'&gt;[lunar.lab] Build My Lab Network Using VyOS&lt;/title&gt;&lt;content type='html'&gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: Helvetica Neue, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;Am trying to build my own lab. The idea is to have three &amp;amp;quot;virtual datacenter&amp;amp;quot; as described in the following figure. Datacenter A and datacenter B would be two independent datacenter, where later I can simulate DR failover, workload mobility, stretch network, etc across those two datacenter.  Each datacenter will have their own ESXi hosts and vCenter. Datacenter C is where I keep shared services which are required by either datacenter A or B, but not relevant to the test that I want to perform. Other than that, datacenter C will hosts some workload which mimic as user accessing workload on datacenter A or B. Each datacenter will have their own router, and dynamic routing should be configured between those 3 datacenter as later I want to explore NSX multi site capabilities. You can see the network and address that I plan to use on the following figure.&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-a3rV73zKmF0/WAS5ytF-LwI/AAAAAAAAL1c/2yJShxOzRuM3GNrM8C4Nz1nF8P-aq6UdgCLcB/s1600/lab.png&amp;quot; imageanchor=&amp;quot;1&amp;quot; updated content please visit &amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://shirazerosagon.blogspot.co.id/p/free-technical-resources.html&amp;quot;&amp;gt;this page&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;.&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;Is there any free resources to learn about VMware technologies? I have seen many people asking this question again and again. Actually there are a lot, and here I try to list down all the free technical VMware resources available on the Internet that I aware of. If you know any other resources, feel free to drop a note on the comment and I will try to consolidate it.&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="blade"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="Dell"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="Dell Management Plug-in for VMware vCenter"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="DMP"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="server"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="server management"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="vCenter"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="vCenter Plug-in"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="Vmware"/&gt;&lt;title type='text'&gt;Integrating VMware vSphere with Dell Blade Server Solutions&lt;/title&gt;&lt;content type='html'&gt;&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;Di sekitar akhir Agustus 2012 kemarin, saya mengisi sesi demo dalam event yang diadakan kantor dengan tema virtualisasi (baca VMware) dengan sponsor Dell. Untuk itu, Dell menyediakan 3 unit blade server, lengkap dengan enclosure dan modul interconnectnya, dan iSCSI storage Equallogic. Karena sponsornya Dell, tentunya saya harus bisa menunjukkan value dari penggunaan hardware Dell pada solusi virtualisasi dengan VMware. Jadi setelah berdiskusi dengan tim Dell, dan banyak googling, akhirnya saya putuskan untuk mengangkat soal integrasi VMware vSphere dan hardware Dell dengan tiga topik bahasan: server management menggunakan Dell Management Plug-in (DMP) for VMware vCenter, fitur &nbsp;VAAI (vStorage APIs for Array Integration) yang dimiliki Equallogic, dan Equallogic management menggunakan Host Integration Tool – VMware Edition (HIT-VE). Artikel ini akan membahas mengenai DMP yang berguna untuk melakukan management Dell server langsung pada VMware vCenter.&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://shirazerosagon.blogspot.com/2012/09/dell-management-plug-in-for-vmware-vcenter.html#more&amp;quot;&amp;gt;Read more »&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&lt;/content&gt;&lt;link rel='replies' width="72"/&gt;&lt;thr:total&gt;0&lt;/thr:total&gt;&lt;/entry&gt;&lt;entry&gt;&lt;id&gt;tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-7374203414060321045.post-7369091456938641288&lt;/id&gt;&lt;published&gt;2012-09-18T21:05:00.002+07:00&lt;/published&gt;&lt;updated&gt;2012-09-18T21:05:34.969+07:00&lt;/updated&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="cb2000"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="hitachi compute blade 2000"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="hitachi data systems"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="SMP"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="symmetrical multi processing"/&gt;&lt;title type='text'&gt;Configuring two-blade SMP on Hitachi Compute Blade 2000&lt;/title&gt;&lt;content type='html'&gt;Masih ingat &amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;http://shirazerosagon.blogspot.com/2012/08/hcb2000-unique-features.html&amp;quot;&amp;gt;artikel&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; saya mengenai fitur-fitur unik yang dimiliki oleh sistem blade Hitachi Compute Blade 2000? Salah satu fitur unik dari HCB2000 adalah multi-blade SMP (Symmetrical Multi Processing), dimana beberapa individual server dapat digabungkan menjadi satu sehingga diperoleh tambahan kemampuan, di antaranya penambahan jumlah socket processor, jumlah slot DIMM, dan jumlah I/O slot. Video berikut memperlihatkan cara konfigurasi 2-blade SMP untuk menyatukan dua high-performance blade server, dilengkapi dengan performance test, baik sebelum maupun sesudah proses penyatuan.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;iframe scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="cb2000"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="cpu shares"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="hitachi"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="hitachi compute blade 2000"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="hitachi virtualization manager"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="hvm"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="logical partitioning"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="lpar"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="resource pool"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="service ratio"/&gt;&lt;title type='text'&gt;CPU Management pada fitur LPAR di HCB2000&lt;/title&gt;&lt;content type='html'&gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: Trebuchet MS, sans-serif;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;Di&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;http://shirazerosagon.blogspot.com/2012/08/hcb2000-unique-features.html&amp;quot;&amp;gt; artikel&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; sebelumnya, telah saya ulas mengenai beberapa fitur yang menjadi pembeda bagi sistem Hitachi Compute Blade 2000 (HCB2000), dimana salah satunya adalah fitur &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;Logical Partitioning&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt; &amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;(LPAR) atau &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;Hitachi Virtualization Manager&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt; (HVM). Pada artikel ini, mari kita coba kenali lebih jauh mengenai LPAR/HVM, khususnya mengenai resource (CPU) management yang mencakup CPU allocation, &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;logical processor Group&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;, dan &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;logical processor Share Ratio&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;. Untuk melengkapi artikel ini, berikut adalah video demo mengenai topik yang akan kita bahas.&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: Trebuchet MS, sans-serif;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;iframe allowfullscreen=&amp;#39;allowfullscreen&amp;#39; webkitallowfullscreen=&amp;#39;webkitallowfullscreen&amp;#39; mozallowfullscreen=&amp;#39;mozallowfullscreen&amp;#39; width=&amp;#39;320&amp;#39; height=&amp;#39;266&amp;#39; src=&amp;#39;https://www.youtube.com/embed/4ScIbn2Jfww?feature=player_embedded&amp;#39; frameborder=&amp;#39;0&amp;#39; /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: Trebuchet MS, sans-serif;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: Trebuchet MS, sans-serif;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://shirazerosagon.blogspot.com/2012/08/hcb2000-lpar-cpumanagement.html#more&amp;quot;&amp;gt;Read more »&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&lt;/content&gt;&lt;link rel='replies' href='https://shirazerosagon.blogspot.com/2012/08/hcb2000-lpar-cpumanagement.html' title='CPU Management pada fitur LPAR di HCB2000'/&gt;&lt;author&gt;&lt;name&gt;Shiraz Erosagon&lt;/name&gt;&lt;uri&gt;http://www.blogger.com/profile/15746064654668743879&lt;/uri&gt;&lt;email&gt;<span class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="3e50514c5b4e52477e5c525159595b4c105d5153">[email&#160;protected]</span>&lt;/email&gt;&lt;gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='32' height='32' src='//1.bp.blogspot.com/-TpTvn5RzA8g/WQ5-8-utM7I/AAAAAAAAZrU/Y3-sPBBWGXgQwPagL4d0yXnqb4bRjpJIgCK4B/s113/Lesmana_Eros_Square.jpg'/&gt;&lt;/author&gt;&lt;thr:total&gt;1&lt;/thr:total&gt;&lt;/entry&gt;&lt;entry&gt;&lt;id&gt;tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-7374203414060321045.post-1442014716667116142&lt;/id&gt;&lt;published&gt;2012-08-18T09:44:00.000+07:00&lt;/published&gt;&lt;updated&gt;2012-08-24T20:01:32.188+07:00&lt;/updated&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="cb2000"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="CDCS"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="hitachi"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="hitachi compute blade 2000"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="hitachi virtualization manager"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="hvm"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="hybrid io"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="logical partitioning"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="lpar"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="multi-blade SMP"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="SMP"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="symmetrical multi processing"/&gt;&lt;title type='text'&gt;Hitachi Compute Blade 2000: Bukan Sekedar Sistem Blade Biasa&lt;/title&gt;&lt;content type='html'&gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;#39;Trebuchet MS&amp;amp;#39;, sans-serif;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;Ketika mendengar HDS (Hitachi Data Systems) meluncurkan server dalam bentuk sistem blade, yang terlintas dalam benak saya akankah HDS mampu bersaing dengan pemain-pemain lain yang sudah lebih dahulu berkibar di dunia server dan sistem blade. Apakah sistem ini hanya merupakan pelengkap &nbsp;bagi sistem storage HDS untuk memenuhi portfolio dari Converged Data Center Solutions (CDCS) yang sedang dikembangkan berbagai principal IT saat ini. Fitur apa yang ditawarkan oleh sistem blade Hitachi, hal unik yang mampu menjadi pembeda dan bermanfaat bagi penggunanya, yang akan membuat sistem blade Hitachi meraih tempat di pasar sistem blade. Artikel ini mencoba menggambarkan beberapa fitur tersebut dengan berdasarkan pengalaman penulis dalam mengeksplorasi Hitachi Compute Blade 2000.&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://shirazerosagon.blogspot.com/2012/08/hcb2000-unique-features.html#more&amp;quot;&amp;gt;Read more »&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&lt;/content&gt;&lt;link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='https://shirazerosagon.blogspot.com/feeds/1442014716667116142/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/&gt;&lt;link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='https://shirazerosagon.blogspot.com/2012/08/hcb2000-unique-features.html#comment-form' title='0 Comments'/&gt;&lt;link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='https://www.blogger.com/feeds/7374203414060321045/posts/default/1442014716667116142'/&gt;&lt;link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='https://www.blogger.com/feeds/7374203414060321045/posts/default/1442014716667116142'/&gt;&lt;link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='https://shirazerosagon.blogspot.com/2012/08/hcb2000-unique-features.html' title='Hitachi Compute Blade 2000: Bukan Sekedar Sistem Blade Biasa'/&gt;&lt;author&gt;&lt;name&gt;Shiraz Erosagon&lt;/name&gt;&lt;uri&gt;http://www.blogger.com/profile/15746064654668743879&lt;/uri&gt;&lt;email&gt;<span class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="0b6564796e7b67724b6967646c6c6e7925686466">[email&#160;protected]</span>&lt;/email&gt;&lt;gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='32' height='32' src='//1.bp.blogspot.com/-TpTvn5RzA8g/WQ5-8-utM7I/AAAAAAAAZrU/Y3-sPBBWGXgQwPagL4d0yXnqb4bRjpJIgCK4B/s113/Lesmana_Eros_Square.jpg'/&gt;&lt;/author&gt;&lt;media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-NX_-ekCo6Jo/UC7uHyxeqHI/AAAAAAAAADI/aeqst0nxC3E/s72-c/hcb2000.jpg" height="72" width="72"/&gt;&lt;thr:total&gt;0&lt;/thr:total&gt;&lt;/entry&gt;&lt;/feed&gt;</code></a></li>

term="storage"/&gt;&lt;category term="study"/&gt;&lt;category term="testing"/&gt;&lt;category term="virtualization"/&gt;&lt;category term="worth-reading"/&gt;&lt;category term="ASIC"/&gt;&lt;category term="Alpine"/&gt;&lt;category term="ELAM"/&gt;&lt;category term="NSX"/&gt;&lt;category term="Northstar"/&gt;&lt;category term="RnS"/&gt;&lt;category term="VSM"/&gt;&lt;category
