Aires, CABA, Argentina&lt;/georss:featurename&gt;&lt;georss:point&gt;-34.6036844 -58.381559100000004&lt;/georss:point&gt;&lt;georss:box&gt;-34.8127694 -58.704282600000006 -34.3945994 -58.0588356&lt;/georss:box&gt;&lt;/entry&gt;&lt;entry&gt;&lt;id&gt;tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-8042221378852147813.post-8380009317013088515&lt;/id&gt;&lt;published&gt;2017-01-10T14:44:00.001-03:00&lt;/published&gt;&lt;updated&gt;2017-01-10T14:44:25.442-03:00&lt;/updated&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="ACI"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="CCIE"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="CCIE LAB"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="DC"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="DCv2"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="UCS"/&gt;&lt;title type='text'&gt;CCIE DCv2: Lab experience &amp;amp; general recommendations&lt;/title&gt;&lt;content type='html'&gt;Well, I think that if you are in an IE track you probably read a lot about this day and prep prior to it. I will not bore you with all the same stuff and I will only summarize few steps that I took.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;ul&amp;gt;&amp;lt;li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;Lab Day&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/ul&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;All that you have read still applies, be familiar with lab location, have a good meal and arrive early, I will add also &amp;quot;be confident&amp;quot; probably you where working on this track for a the past months so this day you will transfer all that knowledge that you gather into the lab&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;ul&amp;gt;&amp;lt;li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;Lab Experience&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/ul&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;For v2 there are some changes, first of all is the introduction of a DIAG section. DIAG is composed of a series of scenarios in which you got some input from client and need to diagnose the issue. It&amp;#39;s really no complex at all, if you have some prior experience in show commands you should not face any issue. Also is good to know that *&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;based on all the output provided&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;* only &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;u&amp;gt;one&amp;lt;/u&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt; question is correct. You&amp;#39;re granted of one hour to end DIAG, notice that if you end early you will not have access to the lab, after one hour the lab would be started for you and you will get access to devices and questions.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;In lab there&amp;#39;s not much to say, use your own strategy, read carefully (I really encourage you to read all the questions first, at least once) and do only what is asked. Lab is hard, I will not lie to you, but if you train well and have practice you will find it possible :), remember be confident, avoid getting stuck with a question if you feel that something is taking you so much time just make a note and go ahead. Other really useful recommendation, and related to ACI, is to take snapshots, I found it very useful when I was making changes in ACI to have some snaps to quickly come back after modifying stuff that hurt my tenants :)&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;After the exam, relax, watch Vikings and release anger/stress/anxiety or whatever you feel, news will come (in my case it took up like almost 48hs....)&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-XKHmjSUVQ1M/WHIjK4KIapI/AAAAAAAADGg/FzZrePJ01JQ61GGJd4h0HS0kj_Gm2EWiwCPcB/s1600/ccielogo.png&amp;quot; imageanchor=&amp;quot;1&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;img border=&amp;quot;0&amp;quot; src=&amp;quot;https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-XKHmjSUVQ1M/WHIjK4KIapI/AAAAAAAADGg/FzZrePJ01JQ61GGJd4h0HS0kj_Gm2EWiwCPcB/s1600/ccielogo.png&amp;quot; /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&lt;/content&gt;&lt;link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='https://underlays.blogspot.com/feeds/8380009317013088515/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/&gt;&lt;link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='https://underlays.blogspot.com/2017/01/ccie-dcv2-lab-experience-general.html#comment-form' title='0 Comments'/&gt;&lt;link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='https://www.blogger.com/feeds/8042221378852147813/posts/default/8380009317013088515'/&gt;&lt;link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='https://www.blogger.com/feeds/8042221378852147813/posts/default/8380009317013088515'/&gt;&lt;link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='https://underlays.blogspot.com/2017/01/ccie-dcv2-lab-experience-general.html' title='CCIE DCv2: Lab experience &amp;amp; general recommendations'/&gt;&lt;author&gt;&lt;name&gt;Ariel Liguori&lt;/name&gt;&lt;uri&gt;http://www.blogger.com/profile/11059180104069090363&lt;/uri&gt;&lt;email&gt;<span class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="82ecedf0e7f2eefbc2e0eeede5e5e7f0ace1edef">[email&#160;protected]</span>&lt;/email&gt;&lt;gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='32' height='32' src='//4.bp.blogspot.com/-6FrHoMlmQZA/XU1v0z7Jc3I/AAAAAAAAE3A/aF_iJtf1iXIn-z6MWJKMrs-nZ9Jilk-IACK4BGAYYCw/s113/IMG_1606.JPG'/&gt;&lt;/author&gt;&lt;media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-XKHmjSUVQ1M/WHIjK4KIapI/AAAAAAAADGg/FzZrePJ01JQ61GGJd4h0HS0kj_Gm2EWiwCPcB/s72-c/ccielogo.png" height="72" width="72"/&gt;&lt;thr:total&gt;0&lt;/thr:total&gt;&lt;georss:featurename&gt;Buenos Aires, CABA, Argentina&lt;/georss:featurename&gt;&lt;georss:point&gt;-34.6036844 -58.381559100000004&lt;/georss:point&gt;&lt;georss:box&gt;-34.8127694 -58.704282600000006 -34.3945994 -58.0588356&lt;/georss:box&gt;&lt;/entry&gt;&lt;entry&gt;&lt;id&gt;tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-8042221378852147813.post-1563619499846525073&lt;/id&gt;&lt;published&gt;2017-01-09T17:46:00.002-03:00&lt;/published&gt;&lt;updated&gt;2017-01-09T17:48:23.345-03:00&lt;/updated&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="ACI"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="CCIE"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="CCIE LAB"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="Cobra"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="DC"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="DCv2"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="EVPN"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="NEXUS"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="UCS"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="UCSC"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="UCSD"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="VXLAN"/&gt;&lt;title type='text'&gt;CCIE DCv2: Part I - Preparation&lt;/title&gt;&lt;content type='html'&gt;Well I think that here things get more exciting, lets talk about preparation that I face for CCIE DC, v1 and also v2.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;As you may notice I&amp;#39;ve failed v1, it was in April of this year, and fail by so little (literally, doing maths it was about 2 points..,), for that (v1) my prep was based on:&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;ul&amp;gt;&amp;lt;li&amp;gt;INE CCIE v1 bootcamp (Nexus Switching)&amp;lt;/li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;li&amp;gt;Lot of knowledge of Nexus / UCS&amp;lt;/li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;li&amp;gt;Minimal rack lab practice...&amp;lt;/li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/ul&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;As you may notice, being confident could be one of your biggest enemy, so instead of thinking that you may know something is better if you can practice (a lot) to get faster and confident for real lab.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;So lets forget v1 and start talking of v2, lot of new stuff: UCS Central, UCS Director, VXLAN, Cisco AVS and, as you may know, ACI.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;Lets summarize:&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;ul&amp;gt;&amp;lt;li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;UCS Central / UCS Director&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/ul&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;For this Cisco community and particularly DevNet workflows was the best, also I practice a lot basic tasks like creating pools, tshooting pool asignments (from UCS C) and from Director side I created basic workflows like configure vlans, service profiles and some ACI workflows.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;ul&amp;gt;&amp;lt;li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;VXLAN&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/ul&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;This is the real hard topic to cover, not in theory or technology but really in config section. For this I really tried to use Cisco Documentation but wasn&amp;#39;t enough, so further reading follow me to this GREAT presentation:&amp;amp;nbsp;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://www.ciscolive.com/online/connect/sessionDetail.ww?SESSION_ID=81202&amp;quot;&amp;gt;BRKDCT-2404 VXLAN Deployment Models - A Practical Perspective&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;Also to tackle VXLAN I followed this:&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;- Understand control plane options: Flood and Learn &amp;amp;amp; BGP EVPN&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;- Understand how to configure in the different nexus families: Nexus 5K &amp;amp;amp; Nexus 7K, Cisco documentation is good for N5K but not so good for 7K, let say that scenarios presented are not complete at all and are so different from a real case, I made a review of those documents but didn&amp;#39;t get a reply from cisco yet. A workaround that I&amp;#39;ve found for such poor doc at 7K was using 9K documentation in NX-OS mode, configuration is pretty much the same :)&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;Those are the docs I&amp;#39;ve used:&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;VXLAN&amp;amp;nbsp;@7K:&amp;amp;nbsp;http://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/datacenter/sw/nx-os/vxlan/configuration/guide/b_NX-OS_VXLAN_Configuration_Guide/overview.html&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;VXLAN&amp;amp;nbsp;@5K:&amp;amp;nbsp;http://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/datacenter/nexus5600/sw/layer2/7x/b_5600_Layer2_Config_7x/b_5600_Layer2_Config_7x_chapter_010010.html&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;VXLAN&amp;amp;nbsp;@9K:&amp;amp;nbsp;http://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/switches/nexus-9000-series-switches/118978-config-vxlan-00.html&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;ul&amp;gt;&amp;lt;li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;Programmability&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/ul&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;One of the interesting topics was about programmability in ACI, I really love Python and this point wasn&amp;#39;t a headache to me, &amp;amp;nbsp;if it is to you you will be able to find great tutorials on the web (I will also write down some in a few days), if you have some knowledge and you are familiar with data model of ACI and terminology you can go directly to Cisco Developers page, amazing doc there:&amp;amp;nbsp;https://developer.cisco.com/media/apicDcPythonAPI_v0.1/install.html&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;ul&amp;gt;&amp;lt;li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;ACI&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/ul&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;Last but definitely not least is ACI, as you can imagine (I figured it out at least), Cisco will push you to use this new tech that they acquire a few years ago. Actually there is no good content related ACI from any partner or learning vendor, I took a quick look at Jason Lunde and other videos, but they where so so introductory that you really need further info. In my case I achieve that by setting up a POD several times and facing all kind of errors, I focused on what I though that it was the key objectives of having ACI deployed, and for me that was:&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;- Setting up VMM integration&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;- Deploying Contracts between EPG and Tenants&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;- Customizing several Fabric configurations (It&amp;#39;s well known that in a CCIE Exam they can ask you to change whenever option is available at the interface, so be prepared)&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;- Deploy a L2 Out connection&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;- Deploy an L3 Out connection&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;- Share L3/L2 between tenants&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;For all this I really recommend to use and see Cisco Community, that was really helpful, Tomas De Leon (a TAC guy who wrote there) uploads very useful documents about how to configure APIC. And again, get a lot of hands on experience in this topic, ACI have a lot of errors and you have to get familiar with them, if you have no previous experience start with a video series to get familiar with concepts and after that book your labs, get an image or us dCloud but be sure to get hands on :)&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;In all of this process I&amp;#39;ve spend like three months, practicing every day with CCIE HOME guys and mock lab scenarios, I can tell for sure that I&amp;#39;ve tested much more that what I&amp;#39;ve found on real lab so when I saw real scenario I didn&amp;#39;t feel scared (well just a little). In next posts I will write down about overall lab experience and recommendations, hope this would be helpful for all aspirants for this AMAZING TRACK.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&lt;/content&gt;&lt;link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="CCIE"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="DC"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="DCv2"/&gt;&lt;title type='text'&gt;CCIE DC v2: Posts &amp;amp; Thanks&lt;/title&gt;&lt;content type='html'&gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: inherit;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;As i mentioned before I will start a series of post regarding my prep to achieve CCIE DCv2, but before that I want to leave some things clears:&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: inherit;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;ul&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: inherit;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;I will not post any info regarding lab that violates NDA, so please don&amp;#39;t insist&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/ul&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;ul&amp;gt;&amp;lt;li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;georgia&amp;amp;quot; , &amp;amp;quot;times new roman&amp;amp;quot; , serif;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;My wife, for supporting me at every moment&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/ul&amp;gt;&amp;lt;ul&amp;gt;&amp;lt;li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span <li><a name="l88" id="l88"><code class="a">&lt;p&gt;I have only recently learned of this second option. Unlike the first option, the certificate error is not ignored globally, but only for the individual page. Once you have loaded the desired page and the error appears, just type &amp;#8222;&lt;em&gt;thisisunsafe&lt;/em&gt;&amp;#8220; (without quotes). This will whitelist the page, reload and ignore the certificate error (Source: &lt;a href="https://podtech.com/os/mac-osx/chrome-catalina-certificate-issue/"&gt;https://podtech.com/os/mac-osx/chrome-catalina-certificate-issue/&lt;/a&gt;).&lt;/p&gt;</code></a></li>

<li><a name="l1" id="l1"><code class="b">&lt;rss version="2.0" xmlns:content="http://purl.org/rss/1.0/modules/content/" xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"&gt;&lt;channel&gt;&lt;title&gt;virtualramp&lt;/title&gt;&lt;description&gt;virtualramp&lt;/description&gt;&lt;link&gt;https://www.virtualramp.net/home&lt;/link&gt;&lt;item&gt;&lt;title&gt;Understanding VMware HCX deployment for VMware cloud on AWS Part -3 (Site Pair and Service mesh)&lt;/title&gt;&lt;description&gt;&lt;![CDATA[In Part 2 we discussed about the onprem HCX manager deployment and configuration, in this post we will take few steps further and will setup the connectivity between the 2 environments (Onprem and Cloud side). We will start with the site pairing.HCX Site pairing is done between two HCX Manager deployments in our case its onprem and VMware cloud on AWS side of HCX manager. You can also have one to many relationship in which we can connect multiple Onprem HCX Managers (for example you have 2&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_dd47a13ab538484693ecaffda5288be7%7Emv2.png/v1/fill/w_754%2Ch_254/165892_dd47a13ab538484693ecaffda5288be7%7Emv2.png"/&gt;]]&gt;&lt;/description&gt;&lt;dc:creator&gt;Atul Srivastava&lt;/dc:creator&gt;&lt;link&gt;https://www.virtualramp.net/single-post/2019/11/12/Understanding-VMware-HCX-deployment-for-VMware-cloud-on-AWS-Part--3-Site-Pair-and-Service-mesh&lt;/link&gt;&lt;guid&gt;https://www.virtualramp.net/single-post/2019/11/12/Understanding-VMware-HCX-deployment-for-VMware-cloud-on-AWS-Part--3-Site-Pair-and-Service-mesh&lt;/guid&gt;&lt;pubDate&gt;Mon, 11 Nov 2019 21:04:15 +0000&lt;/pubDate&gt;&lt;content:encoded&gt;&lt;![CDATA[&lt;div&gt;&lt;div&gt;In Part 2 we discussed about the onprem HCX manager deployment and configuration, in this post we will take few steps further and will setup the connectivity between the 2 environments (Onprem and Cloud side). We will start with the site pairing.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;HCX Site pairing is done between two HCX Manager deployments in our case its onprem and VMware cloud on AWS side of HCX manager. You can also have one to many relationship in which we can connect multiple Onprem HCX Managers (for example you have 2 datacenters and you want to connect both of them to cloud) to one VMware cloud on AWS HCX Manager. &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Site pairing requires a connectivity between the onprem HCX Manager and Cloud HCX Manager on port 443. and as discussed in part 2 we can reach the cloud side HCX manager in 2 ways, either on public IP or if there is a direct connect in picture then using the private IP. &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Note: To get the hcx cloud url click on open hcx in SDDC's add on section and copy the url . By default the cloud side hcx manager fqdn will resolve to public IP, however if we want it to go via private IP we will have to either create a DNS entry or we will have to edit the host file on the hcx manager appliance by doing an ssh to it.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;For establishing a site pair go to the onprem vCenter html client and open hcx plug in. on the dashboard select New site pair. and cloudadmin user name and password and click register. &lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_dd47a13ab538484693ecaffda5288be7~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;Once registered click cancel (Do not proceed with any component installation), you are now back on the dashboard, refresh the page and now you will be able to see the site pairing as up.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Note: We can also do the site pair from the site pair tab of the Interconnect &amp;gt; Multi-site Service Mesh&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Tips: If site pairing is not up please check the connectivity on port 443&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_80eec6c242814a22b9bda19342afdc9c~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;Now its time to understand and deploy the Service mesh.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;The Multi-Site Service mesh is used to create a secure optimized transport fabric between any two sites managed by HCX. Also when HCX Migration, Disaster recovery, Network Extension, WAN Optimization services are enabled, HCX deploys Virtual Appliances in the source site and corresponding &amp;quot;peer&amp;quot; virtual appliances on the destination site. The Multi-Site Service Mesh enables the configuration, deployment, and serviceability of these Interconnect virtual appliance pairs with ease.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Before we deploy the service mesh and setup the hcx tunnels we first need to understand and create few profiles &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;1) Compute Profile : This profile will be used by service mesh to deploy the HCX appliances, we will supply details &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; like cluster, resources pool, Datastore in compute profile so that service mesh can use it for the &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; deployment of HCX appliances.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;2) Networking Profile : In Network profile we are going to supply networking related information like port group, &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; vxlan IP-Address pool for appliances deployed with service mesh. &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;**We can create multiple compute and networking profile, a good used case would be if we want to keep vMotion, Management and uplink on different networks.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Before deploying the Compute profile we will have to create network profiles (because we are going to use these network profiles in compute profile)&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;To create a Network Profile we need to go to the HCX plugin in vCenter or open HCX manager page with fqdn and login to it with vCenter admin credentials.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Click on the interconnect option at the left and select Network profile under Multi-site service Mesh &lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_d3e9ba286a964ef8877bbecc06f49f71~mv2.jpg"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;On the create network profile page select the appropriate network and create an IP - pool for that network (Usually we need Management, vMotion and uplink profile, We can also use one profile for all these) &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Management - will be used to communicate with management components (Esxi, vCenter etc)&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;vMotion - Make sure this network and ip pool is in the same range as your Esxi vMotion network&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;vSphere Replication - This profile will be used for replication purpose with Bulk Migration, RAV or HCX site recovery. &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Uplink - &nbsp;This profile will be used for establishing the HCX tunnel (Over internet or Direct connect) between on-prem and SDDC.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_ebe97df3248e4929a6dba08e923d0c37~mv2.jpg"/&gt;&lt;div&gt; After filling all the details click create. &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;In my lab I am using 1 network for everything however if you have different networks for Management, vMotion and uplink please create three network profiles.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Alright so lets start with the creation of Compute profile&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;On the same page where we created the network profile click compute profile and then select Create compute profile&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;1) Type a name for compute profile and click continue&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;2) Select the HCX services you want to use &lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_86b02b0fd025431b91abef918e52a37c~mv2.jpg"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;3) Click continue and on the next page select the resource (Datacenter or specific cluster) where you want service mesh to deploy the appliance VMs.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_3783b40d25a74abc9f081f4e85ad78dd~mv2.jpg"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;4) Clicking continue will enable another option of selecting the data-store where we should deploy the HCX appliances.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_756816667de843cebc427b1d96362cbf~mv2.jpg"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;5) Now We get an option to select a network profile for Management Network which will be used by the appliances to communicate with &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; management components like Esxi or vCenter.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_c17697add04442699bdb127e6c8a3832~mv2.jpg"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;Once you select the network you will see another option getting activated i.e. &amp;quot;Advanced Configurations&amp;quot; we will use this option if in case we want to define certain static routs for the appliances (This is optional).&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_aaed16ef2d674aa190b17d2392d4fc3d~mv2.jpg"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;6) After Management Network once you click on continue you will be presented with an option to select uplink profile which will be used for the &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; communication to the cloud side components in my lab I am using management for everything.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_7bf50ecbfd284d559658d27be8815abb~mv2.jpg"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;7) clicking continue will present you with vMotion network profile . with this network the HCX appliance is going to communicate with Esxi hosts over vMotion network. this network will only be used in case you are performing vMotion not Bulk Migration.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_007b2a0a149c4793a5fee86bfb83497e~mv2.jpg"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;8) Finally we will select the Replication Network profile which will be used for Replication purpose.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_849d79a7a22642ec93a24d091ec91f81~mv2.jpg"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;10) after clicking continue it will ask us to select the network switch for network extensions which we will use in-case we want to extend any on &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; prem network to VMC cloud (L2 Extensions).&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_822953575050452db1c93be0c808afa5~mv2.jpg"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;Clicking Continue will generate the a connection rules (LAN and WAN) which will help us to identify what Firewall rules need to be open, We can give this list to the networking team to review and open the required ports.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;(The best part of this entire setup is that we have a pictorial representation of the connectivity and we can verify and correct if we see any issues in that representation. )&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Finally we click on finish to complete the compute profile. On the finish page we can review entire connectivity in the diagram.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_a897abac717b40258e5760216a6bc55e~mv2.jpg"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;Alright so We have Network Profile and compute profile created, we have already reviewed the connectivity and we also have the list of subnets and required ports.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_e3bd997506cc4304b8b6ae23b083c769~mv2.jpg"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;Finally we will create the service mesh &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Checklist before creating Service mesh : &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;1) Compute Profile is created.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;2) Firewall rules are opened. &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;3) We have sufficient resources available in vSphere.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;4) Site Pairing is up and running.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Lets Start with service Mesh deployment now &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Click on Service Mesh and select Create Service Mesh, Lets begin with the Wizard&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;1) Select the correct source and destination site pairing (You can do multiple site pairing and thats what it is important to &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; select the correct ones here based on this selection appliances are going to be deployed at onprem and cloud side to &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; create an IPsec tunnel).&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_52736b69e7874f3082f86dd217489a24~mv2.jpg"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;2) Click continue and now select the compute profile we created earlier , and default compute profile at cloud side.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_a7f33a7bf7b847ff91466d4f42232413~mv2.jpg"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;3) Next screen will give you option to deselect services which you defined in compute profile if in &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; case you do not want to use any service or you want to create different service mesh for different &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; services.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_6d257139b288441aa63d776a690e2282~mv2.jpg"/&gt;&lt;div&gt; 4) Next screen will give you an option to select uplink profiles for setting up the tunnel, the tunnel can be established using either Direct connect &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; connection or Internet connection based on your connection preference you can use the network profile onprem and cloud side. Make sure the profile you are selecting has available Free IPs if not we can &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; always add IPs to network profiles. &lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_49a7d403518d4099a03d68fff3b15fe3~mv2.jpg"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;5) Clicking continue will present you with the option to network extension appliance setup, on this page you can select the number of Network &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; extension appliance (one appliance can extend upto 7 on prem networks to cloud), by default it will deploy one appliance however to increase the &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; number of appliances click CONFIGURE THE NETWORK EXTENSION APPLIANCE SCALE&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_041a125d5d7849b4b66e8361b1540197~mv2.jpg"/&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_19191cbac5b04f4b833e27259249d662~mv2.jpg"/&gt;&lt;div&gt; 6) Further pages are bandwidth limit for uplink (Configure the maximum aggregate uplink bandwidth that will be consumed for migrations across all the uplinks), followed by topology review and final page will give you option for giving a name to your service Mesh.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_1905da5c3db5480b9023a478637a8bec~mv2.jpg"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;Enter a name for your service mesh and click Finish. You can monitor the service Mesh deployment in Tasks tab. You can also monitor vCenter Tasks and events (Onprem and cloud side) which will show you multiple OVF deployments and VM re-configs. &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Once service Mesh is deployed and if all the config is correct in 2-5 Minutes you should see Tunnel status as Up in the appliance section of the Service Mesh.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_f9aac65fc61b413db40e7c02a1171f05~mv2.jpg"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;And now we are ready to Migrate VMs using IX and extend Network using NE..&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Go back to &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.virtualramp.net/single-post/2019/05/17/Understanding-VMware-HCX-deployment-for-VMware-cloud-on-AWS-Part--1"&gt;Part-1&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.virtualramp.net/single-post/2019/11/12/Understanding-VMware-HCX-deployment-for-VMware-cloud-on-AWS-Part--2-HCX-Manager"&gt;Part-2&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;]]&gt;&lt;/content:encoded&gt;&lt;/item&gt;&lt;item&gt;&lt;title&gt;Understanding VMware HCX deployment for VMware cloud on AWS Part -2 (HCX Manager)&lt;/title&gt;&lt;description&gt;&lt;![CDATA[In part one of this blog series we learned about HCX basics and the cloud side deployment, in this blog we will talk in depth about onprem deployment and will explore each and every components in detail. Alright ! so before starting with the deployment of on prem HCX manager lets get the list of ports which will be required by HCX manager and other HCX components to communicate with other resources and internet. Lets review the following port diagram. As we can see, on-prem HCX Manager requires&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_8d8c65f05ad2475da5bd351b41de70f3%7Emv2.png"/&gt;]]&gt;&lt;/description&gt;&lt;dc:creator&gt;Atul Srivastava&lt;/dc:creator&gt;&lt;link&gt;https://www.virtualramp.net/single-post/2019/11/12/Understanding-VMware-HCX-deployment-for-VMware-cloud-on-AWS-Part--2-HCX-Manager&lt;/link&gt;&lt;guid&gt;https://www.virtualramp.net/single-post/2019/11/12/Understanding-VMware-HCX-deployment-for-VMware-cloud-on-AWS-Part--2-HCX-Manager&lt;/guid&gt;&lt;pubDate&gt;Mon, 11 Nov 2019 21:04:03 +0000&lt;/pubDate&gt;&lt;content:encoded&gt;&lt;![CDATA[&lt;div&gt;&lt;div&gt;In part one of this blog series we learned about HCX basics and the cloud side deployment, in this blog we will talk in depth about onprem deployment and will explore each and every components in detail. Alright ! so before starting with the deployment of on prem HCX manager lets get the list of ports which will be required by HCX manager and other HCX components to communicate with other resources and internet. Lets review the following port diagram.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_8d8c65f05ad2475da5bd351b41de70f3~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt; As we can see, on-prem HCX Manager requires connectivity to : &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;1) Onprem vSphere infra like vCenter ( TCP Port 443), PSC ( TCP Port 7444), ESXi (TCP Port 902).&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;2) Onprem Infrastructure services DNS (TCP/UDP port 53) and optionally to NTP , Syslog and SNMP.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;3) Access to internet for activation URL &amp;quot;connect.hcx.vmware.com&amp;quot; and for getting updates URL &amp;quot;hybridity-depot.vmware.com&amp;quot; &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; both on TCP port 443.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;4) Other onprem HCX components like Interconnect appliance (TCP port 8123, 22, 443, 9443) &amp;amp; Network extension appliance (TCP port 9443)&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;5) Lets talk about the final and important point which is connectivity to VMware Cloud on AWS SDDC. &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Onprem HCX Manager can connect to the VMware Cloud on AWS SDDC in two ways&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;- Via Internet (An internet connectivity between the appliances) - with this method the Site Pairing, IX IPsec tunnel and L2C IPSEC tunnel all get &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; established VIA Internet, we will require the onprem components to have internet connectivity and on the cloud side HCX Manager, IX Appliance &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; and L2C appliance will use public IP addresses. &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;div&gt;- ViaDirect connect connection (Private VIF)&lt;/div&gt;: &nbsp;If you have an AWS direct connect connectivity from your onprem to VMware cloud on AWS &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; SDDC, the onprem routes and the SDDC routes will be exchanged between on prem router and AWS router over BGP, this will allow us a seamless &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; &amp;amp; fast connectivity between the two environments, with direct connect we can establish site paring (Port 443), IX IPsec tunnel (UDP 500 and &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; 4500) and an L2C IPsec tunnel (UDP 500 and 4500) over private IPs, no public IP is required.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;After taking care of the ports and deciding on the kind of connectivity we want between the 2 environments, Let's proceed with the HCX Manager on-prem Deployment. &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;I have already described in part 1, how to download the ovf for onprem HCX manager, after the download the deployment is very straight forward, during the deployment in the network section we just need to make sure we are selecting a network which has connectivity as per the first network port diagram we discussed (To all the onprem components as well as to https://connect.hcx.vmware.com for Activation, access to the cloud hcx manager public IP FQDN or If DX is used access to DX network). &lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_bf485cc6788941e9a7a793f891cab849~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;After the deployment its time for the activation and registration process, we can open the HCX manager page by providing its FQDN or IP on port 9443, using admin as user and the password we supplied during the OVA deployment. which will directly give us the page for the registration where we will find the url mentioned for activation as &amp;quot;https://connect.hcx.vmware.com&amp;quot; and its asking for the activation key, paste the activation key (get the Activation key from cloud side Add on &amp;gt; open HCX page. &lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_89b3420b44324257ab3ff05c4ac157f3~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;click on Activate.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Next we will be prompted to select the city and location of the on-prem HCX manager. select and click yes and continue and the activation will get completed.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;And you are given an option to configure the appliance right now or later. lets click Continue.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_765c19e201584527ba61f6c6c7da168b~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;Next screen is the registration with on-prem vCenter (vCenter fqdn, admin username and password, port 443)) &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; Note: if NSX registration is required (For extending the vxlan network details ) select connect your nsx and enter the username and password for &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; nsx manager &lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_aca58305340f47efb8720824abf6363d~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;click continue.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; Enter the SSO username and password and Click Continue (Port 7444 to the PSC) &lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_d607a2c7666f479f9111cd6a95d11ccb~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt; To get everything correct and in working condition click on Restart HCX service (it takes 5 minutes to reinitialize the hcx)&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_376f1098a2b44bc4866dfc3443fd793a~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;We may have to keep refreshing the page and once everything is up and running, we will see the dashboard with all the updated information.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_eadc804a16f14ebaa991c42af895ac28~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;Once everything is up and running like in the above screen shot, we can start adding some users to manage the HCX components, we can do this by clicking on configuration and selecting &amp;quot;vSphere Role Mapping&amp;quot; option. through the configuration page, we can verify and change other registrations like vCenter or NSX as well.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_de6e3a1965244e299bbbf036b818e78c~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;Next we can verify the HCX plugin and its functionality by logging in to the on-prem vSphere web Client. if you are already logged in log off and log back in. it may take some time to install the plugin (There are almost 9 Plugins ). you might get a notification at the top about which plugin got installed and we should refresh the page.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_f9d6a90ba059449ba4ecf47f9d7a679c~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;And after final refresh we will be able to see the HCX Plugin. &lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_90f19fa48ea549a1a5299dd62d10b053~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;The HCX Manager onprem Deployment is now completed, We will now start working on getting the 2 sites connected in the next post.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.virtualramp.net/single-post/2019/11/12/Understanding-VMware-HCX-deployment-for-VMware-cloud-on-AWS-Part--3-Site-Pair-and-Service-mesh"&gt;Understanding-VMware-HCX-deployment-for-VMware-cloud-on-AWS-Part--3-Site-Pair-and-Service-mesh&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;]]&gt;&lt;/content:encoded&gt;&lt;/item&gt;&lt;item&gt;&lt;title&gt;Understanding VMware HCX deployment for VMware cloud on AWS Part -1&lt;/title&gt;&lt;description&gt;&lt;![CDATA[Hello Everyone, in my previous posts I have already written about HCX and how do we configure it specially with VMware Cloud on AWS . Here are the links for those 2 blog posts.HCX Part -1 HCX Part - 2In this blog series we will understand the the deployment in details and will go through the newly introduced Service Mesh option. VMware has recently released an update to HCX and that has introduced a very interesting option and interface for users which is called Service Mesh. in this blog we are&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_49c5afa7869a4c17b0287bbe9fe6b4a2%7Emv2.png/v1/fill/w_961%2Ch_423/165892_49c5afa7869a4c17b0287bbe9fe6b4a2%7Emv2.png"/&gt;]]&gt;&lt;/description&gt;&lt;dc:creator&gt;Atul Srivastava&lt;/dc:creator&gt;&lt;link&gt;https://www.virtualramp.net/single-post/2019/05/17/Understanding-VMware-HCX-deployment-for-VMware-cloud-on-AWS-Part--1&lt;/link&gt;&lt;guid&gt;https://www.virtualramp.net/single-post/2019/05/17/Understanding-VMware-HCX-deployment-for-VMware-cloud-on-AWS-Part--1&lt;/guid&gt;&lt;pubDate&gt;Mon, 11 Nov 2019 21:03:21 +0000&lt;/pubDate&gt;&lt;content:encoded&gt;&lt;![CDATA[&lt;div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Hello Everyone, in my previous posts I have already written about HCX and how do we configure it specially with VMware Cloud on AWS . Here are the links for those 2 blog posts.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.virtualramp.net/single-post/2018/09/04/Deploy-and-configure-HCX-for-VMware-Cloud-on-AWS-Part--1"&gt;HCX Part -1&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.virtualramp.net/single-post/2018/09/04/Deploy-and-configure-HCX-for-VMware-Cloud-on-AWS-Part--2"&gt;HCX Part - 2&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;In this blog series we will understand the the deployment in details and will go through the newly introduced Service Mesh option. VMware has recently released an update to HCX and that has introduced a very interesting option and interface for users which is called Service Mesh. in this blog we are going to talk about what is service mesh, how to deploy and configure it and what advantages are there of service mesh. and as you all know like all my blogs this blog will also be based on VMware Cloud on AWS, so let's get started :) ...&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;HCX has already become a popular tool for cloud migrations and the beauty of this product is that it's a Multi Cloud App Mobility And Infrastructure Hybridity Across Any vSphere. it delivers secure and seamless app mobility and infrastructure hybridity across vSphere 5.0+ versions, on-premises and in the cloud. &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Some of the key capabilities are :&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;# You can transform your data center with secure, seamless app mobility between vSphere 5.0+ on-premises and the cloud without &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; upgrading your vSphere version. Enable zero-downtime &amp;quot;live&amp;quot; migrations and scheduled low-downtime, large-scale migrations. &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; Multiple VM migration models (including vMotion, live, warm, cold) make it easy.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;# VMware HCX enables seamless and secure cloud on-boarding. Thanks to features such as secure proxy for vMotion; secure network &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; extension; and high-throughput, WAN-optimized, load-balanced multisite by directional interconnects.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;# In the event of a disaster, VMware HCX recovers the networking layer. Traffic routes are maintained as before the disaster, resulting &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; in high-speed disaster recovery with low downtime. HCX can also be used for avoiding Disasters. VMs can be migrated out of SDDC &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; of disaster zone to a safe location when disaster warning is received.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Here is an overview of HCX and how it connects the on prem and VMware cloud on AWS SDDC Environments.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_49c5afa7869a4c17b0287bbe9fe6b4a2~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;div&gt;We have already discussed about these components in my previous blog &lt;a href="https://www.virtualramp.net/single-post/2018/09/04/Deploy-and-configure-HCX-for-VMware-Cloud-on-AWS-Part--1"&gt;HCX Part -1 ,&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.virtualramp.net/single-post/2018/09/04/Deploy-and-configure-HCX-for-VMware-Cloud-on-AWS-Part--1"&gt;Lets do a recap here as well.&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;1- HCX Manager (or HCX Enterprize Manager) : HCX Manager is the central command center appliance through which we begin our &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;HCX deployment Journey, this is available as an OVA and gets registered with our vCenter and installs a plugin for performing installation of HCX components and other VM migration tasks.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;div&gt;2- HCX Interconnect service :&lt;/div&gt; HCX Interconnect service provides resilient access over the Internet and private lines to the target site while providing strong encryption, traffic engineering and extending the data-center. This services simplifies secure pairing of sites and management of HCX components.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;div&gt;3- WAN Optimization Service (Optional) :&lt;/div&gt; Improves performance characteristics of the private lines or Internet paths by leveraging WAN Optimization techniques like data de-duplication and line conditioning. This makes performance closer to a LAN environment.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;div&gt;4- Network Extension Service:&lt;/div&gt; High throughput Network Extension service with integrated Proximity Routing which unlocks seamless mobility and simple disaster recovery plans across sites. L2 Extension. &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;As we discussed above the first point to start with HCX is by deploying the HCX manager, but why ? Lets understand.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;1) HCX Manager will register itself with vCenter and then we will get the HCX plugin listed for further operations.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;2) HCX Manager will be used for activating HCX using activation key.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;3) HCX Manager will establish the site pairing. hence after deploying the HCX manager and registering it to the vCenter we should use the hcx plugin for site &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; pairing. &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;4) HCX Manager has the Bit to deploy Interconnect appliance, Wan opt and L2C Appliance, hence after deploying the HCX manager and registering it to the &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; vCenter we should use the add on for the deployment of these. &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Lets Begin with the HCX add-on deployment on VMware cloud on AWS side.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Login to the SDDC &amp;gt; open SDDC &amp;gt; Click on Add ons &amp;gt; click open HCX and finally click on Deploy hcx on the sddc, this will initiate the flow of deploying HCX manager on cloud side &lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_9f878ead8bfe4e048f53653813508fa7~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;This will Deploy HCX Manager on the cloud SDDC . (&amp;quot;Deploy HCX &amp;quot; will only deploy the HCX Manager component at cloud side) once this is deployed you will be able to see HCX Manager VM on the cloud side vCenter.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_a894e1b7a9b549eb95bd63799c3fad88~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;HCX manager has picked up an IP from the management ip range for communicating with the management components. and also a DNS Name (This DNS Name will be used while doing the site pair at onprem side we can keep a note of this). &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;and if we try to ping this DNS name we could see it is getting resolved to a public IP .. Yes ! a public IP is assigned to HCX manager however it will be VIA NAT to the private IP of HCX Manager.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_e0eb1eaa37cf43b1ba3e8bc7592ddc65~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;Now the question is from where this public IP coming from in SDDC ? so while deploying HCX on cloud side the workflow also requests for 3 new public IPs in the SDDC console and one of these public IPs are being used for HCX manager (other two IPs will be used if we will deploy IX appliance and L2C appliance and want to connect them VIA internet not direct connect).&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;To check these public IPs go to the SDDC and click on networking and security tab and select public IP section you will see 3 IPs with Notes as HCX, HCX-Fleet-1, HCX-Fleet-2. You can verify in the below screenshot that the cloud side HCX Manager of my environment has taken the IP which says HCX in Notes.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_108ad28fbf1d4665aea6ecddcdd4ad19~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;Alright so now we have the insight of how and what was configured on cloud side when we do HCX Deployment. Let's deploy the Onprem side HCX Manager.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;To get the HCX Manager OVA we will have to click on &amp;quot;Open HCX&amp;quot; option on add-on section, which will open the cloud side HCX manager page (the fqdn of this page is same as the dns name of the cloud side hcx appliance) &lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_a91f448357854a689ceaec09a3fd828c~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;It will prompt for the Username and password, we can use the same credentials which we use for login to the VMC vCenter &amp;quot;<span class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="1e7d72716b7a7f7a7377705e68737d3072717d7f72">[email&#160;protected]</span>&amp;quot;.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_fa04205a4f3a4e96bc81fd68a426e4ae~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;We will now see a nice dashboard of HCX Cloud with overview and other badges, We will see a section in dashboard which says Hybrid Connectivity and there we will find the link for Downloading the HCX Enterprise Client.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_344b695d201444c49c79d6b9315828a5~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;By Clicking on this link it will take us to the administration page and we will find a Request download link option there, once we click on that it will display the download link or copy link option for downloading on-prem HCX.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_49ecb442507f42a090245a654abd0057~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;Once the OVA is downloaded, next we will deploy this OVA. Let's continue the on-prem side deployment in next blog &amp;quot;&lt;a href="https://www.virtualramp.net/single-post/2019/11/12/Understanding-VMware-HCX-deployment-for-VMware-cloud-on-AWS-Part--2-HCX-Manager"&gt;Understanding VMware HCX deployment for VMware cloud on AWS Part -2&amp;quot;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;]]&gt;&lt;/content:encoded&gt;&lt;/item&gt;&lt;item&gt;&lt;title&gt;VMware Cloud on AWS DRaaS (SRM) Deployment&lt;/title&gt;&lt;description&gt;&lt;![CDATA[One of the Best use cases for Hybrid cloud is when we want to protect our on-prem workloads on cloud, so during any disaster situations we can easily recover them and reduce the total downtime of a service. We have DRaaS introduced with VMware Cloud on AWS as SRM solution and it works seamlessly between On-prem and Cloud Data-centers.In this Blog I want to demonstrate a step by step deployment of DRaaS on VMware Cloud on AWS and Onprem vSphere , lets get started with the requirements, and first&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_0a93bd59bddf4777abbef7de7bb1ea33%7Emv2.png/v1/fill/w_961%2Ch_541/165892_0a93bd59bddf4777abbef7de7bb1ea33%7Emv2.png"/&gt;]]&gt;&lt;/description&gt;&lt;dc:creator&gt;Atul Srivastava&lt;/dc:creator&gt;&lt;link&gt;https://www.virtualramp.net/single-post/2019/03/14/VMware-Cloud-on-AWS-DRaaS-SRM-Deployment&lt;/link&gt;&lt;guid&gt;https://www.virtualramp.net/single-post/2019/03/14/VMware-Cloud-on-AWS-DRaaS-SRM-Deployment&lt;/guid&gt;&lt;pubDate&gt;Wed, 13 Mar 2019 21:11:37 +0000&lt;/pubDate&gt;&lt;content:encoded&gt;&lt;![CDATA[&lt;div&gt;&lt;div&gt;One of the Best use cases for Hybrid cloud is when we want to protect our on-prem workloads on cloud, so during any disaster situations we can easily recover them and reduce the total downtime of a service. We have DRaaS introduced with VMware Cloud on AWS as SRM solution and it works seamlessly between On-prem and Cloud Data-centers.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;In this Blog I want to demonstrate a step by step deployment of DRaaS on VMware Cloud on AWS and Onprem vSphere , lets get started with the requirements, and first lets talk about the required ports so that we can avoid any hiccups during our deployment.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Requirements :&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;# IPSEC VPN / Direct Connect between Onprem and VMC &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;# Your SDDC should be updated with onprem DNS&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;# Following Ports should be Opened at on prem side and SDDC Side&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_0a93bd59bddf4777abbef7de7bb1ea33~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;Now lets get started with the deployment and the connectivity steps.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;We will first activate site recovery on the VMware Cloud on AWS Side and to do that :&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;1) Login to vmc.vmware.com portal and go to VMware cloud on AWS.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;2) Select your desired SDDC.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;3) Click on Add Ons.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;4) Click on activate button in Site recovery section.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_f0dd21da304045388ca7548d2e99b630~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;After clicking Activate a new Window will pop up which gives you the option to set an extension key , Extension Key could be useful in case you want to connect your second site to this SDDC. For each protected site, you must install one instance of Site Recovery Manager Server at the protected site and one instance of Site Recovery Manager Server at the recovery site. You can only pair Site Recovery Manager Server instances that have the same Site Recovery Manager extension ID. Each protected site must include its own vCenter Server instance.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_7bdd8c7304f4412a97dcc81333e75b03~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;**Make sure whatever Extension ID you are providing here you should use same at the onprem side while installing SRM otherwise you might end up having issues in Site paring where the SRM for remote site will not be visible.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; Now once you click activate the cloud side SRM will start deploying &lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_2ab1bb5adaf840bba43af4f007eb590b~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;Create following Firewall rules at SDDC Side (192.168.10.0/24 is the sub-net for my onprem components, please check the first port diagram if you want to do it for each component)&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_167ee6ddcdd4456faea868a1a46e29ae~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;Now lets Jump Back to the On-prem side and install the 2 required components there (Use this Doc &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;1) SRM server : Install this service on a Windows Server 2012 and Register it with onprem vCenter&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_c4decd5c7c8c4e6f91142bc11f2f54d5~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;and now you will be able to see the Site Recovery add on in vCenter HTML Client (You might have to log off and log back in)&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_c8c09340c97d4fc9a088434188bdaa2c~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;2) VR appliance : Deploy the VR as Appliance &lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_0448174d20b7448da1276cae2eb13ca5~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;And Configure and register VR appliance with vCenter &lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_590a959c287b437da365686f6043a0a3~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt; After VR Appliance configuration we are done on the installation part and now lets do the site pairing &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Before we jump on to the site pairing part lets make sure that we are good at DNS part &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;1) It is recommended to make the DNS entry of all the Onprem SRM components.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;2) For cloud Side components Either your Onprem DNS should be able to forward the requests to Internet DNS. or you will have to create an &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; entry for SRM and VR Manually by adding a Zone for your SDDC.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Lets do the Site pairing now.. &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;- Go to Site recovery Plugin and open site recovery and then click new site pair &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;- Select the Local vCenter in first site box (if you are initiating site pairing from on-prem side)&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;- In the second site section paste the VMware cloud side vCenter URL, Username and password &lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_7254207a20df4d29a5c50f1478879eca~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;Click Next and You will see Cloud side Components (SRM and VR listed in vCenter Server and Services Window &lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_4a73eddf98b04e56bbd8230a8b17cef5~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;Select Both the service components and click Next after a review Window Click Finish &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;And we are done with the site pairing now &lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_614bea2221af4e2d989448e965765013~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;And in the Summary page You should now see all the information&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_cbdc816799684f359ba71532d3564a50~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;And now we can do normal site recovery operations by creating protection group, recovery plan and protect our Onprem VMs to Cloud on VMware Cloud on AWS SDDC.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;]]&gt;&lt;/content:encoded&gt;&lt;/item&gt;&lt;item&gt;&lt;title&gt;Deploy and configure HCX for VMware Cloud on AWS Part -1&lt;/title&gt;&lt;description&gt;&lt;![CDATA[Hybrid Cloud extension has already become a popular solution for Cloud migrations, this great tool is available as an add on with VMware cloud on AWS for on-prem to cloud migration or vice-versa. The beauty of the tool is, it makes migration a very seamless experience. As of today HCX is a free option available with VMware cloud on AWS subscription.In this blog post I want to specifically talk about how to configure HCX for VMware Cloud on AWS, however before starting with the implementation,&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_30bf5095d16a4363825082fc0b2c64d2%7Emv2.png/v1/fill/w_961%2Ch_563/165892_30bf5095d16a4363825082fc0b2c64d2%7Emv2.png"/&gt;]]&gt;&lt;/description&gt;&lt;dc:creator&gt;Atul Srivastava&lt;/dc:creator&gt;&lt;link&gt;https://www.virtualramp.net/single-post/2018/09/04/Deploy-and-configure-HCX-for-VMware-Cloud-on-AWS-Part--1&lt;/link&gt;&lt;guid&gt;https://www.virtualramp.net/single-post/2018/09/04/Deploy-and-configure-HCX-for-VMware-Cloud-on-AWS-Part--1&lt;/guid&gt;&lt;pubDate&gt;Tue, 04 Sep 2018 13:05:04 +0000&lt;/pubDate&gt;&lt;content:encoded&gt;&lt;![CDATA[&lt;div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Hybrid Cloud extension has already become a popular solution for Cloud migrations, this great tool is available as an add on with VMware cloud on AWS for on-prem to cloud migration or vice-versa. The beauty of the tool is, it makes migration a very seamless experience. As of today HCX is a free option available with VMware cloud on AWS subscription.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;In this blog post I want to specifically talk about how to configure HCX for VMware Cloud on AWS, however before starting with the implementation, let's Plan our HCX deployment and understand the components and prerequisites.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;1-HCX Manager (or HCX Enterprize Manager) : HCX Manager is the central command center appliance through which we begin our HCX deployment Journey, this is available as an OVA and gets registered with our vCenter and installs a plugin for performing installation of HCX components and other VM migration tasks.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;2- HCX Interconnect service : HCX Interconnect service provides resilient access over the Internet and private lines to the target site while providing strong encryption, traffic engineering and extending the datacenter. This services simplifies secure pairing of sites and management of HCX components.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;3- WAN Optimization Service (Optional) : Improves performance characteristics of the private lines or Internet paths by leveraging WAN Optimization techniques like data de-duplication and line conditioning. This makes performance closer to a LAN environment.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;4- Network Extension Service: High throughput Network Extension service with integrated Proximity Routing which unlocks seamless mobility and simple disaster recovery plans across sites.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;There are a number of ports required to be opened for HCX on-prem deployment, if we talk about the deployment at VMware on AWS side it is just a matter of a click. &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;as a prerequisite lets first open all these ports for different on-prem side components so that they can talk to each other.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_30bf5095d16a4363825082fc0b2c64d2~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;Above picture is Taken from : &lt;a href="https://hcx.design/2018/06/22/vmware-hcx-network-ports/"&gt;https://hcx.design/2018/06/22/vmware-hcx-network-ports/&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Once we are done with all these ports which is mentioned in origin site we are good to start with the deployment.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Let's Begin with the Cloud Side deployment&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;1) Login to vmc.vmware.com and open the SDDC we want to connect to onprem HCX.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;2) Click on add-on tab &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;3) click on &amp;quot;Open Hybrid Cloud extension&amp;quot;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_73b8a5a265a54406ae77022edc3f977b~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt; 4) This will open a New HCX Page, Click on SDDCs and Click on &amp;quot;DEPLOY HCX&amp;quot; link on the desired SDDC Badge&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_9f878ead8bfe4e048f53653813508fa7~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt; 5) This will take 15-20 Minutes and we are done with the cloud part of the HCX Deployment :-) &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;On-prem HCX Deployment :&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;6) After the cloud side deployment gets finished we start our on-prem HCX deployment Journey from the same page &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; where we clicked &amp;quot;Deploy HCX&amp;quot; in the last step. We will see that &amp;quot;Deploy HCX&amp;quot; link is not there and we have got 2 &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; New options after deployment, &amp;quot;Open HCX&amp;quot; and &amp;quot;Undeploy HCX&amp;quot;. (On the same page we will see an option called as &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; &amp;quot;Activation Keys&amp;quot; click on that and create a new activation key for HCX Enterprise and make a note of it we will use it later during on-&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; prem activation)&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_a91f448357854a689ceaec09a3fd828c~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;7) For getting the HCX Manager OVA we will have to click on &amp;quot;Open HCX&amp;quot;, which will open the HCX manager page &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; for the cloud side of HCX and will prompt for the Username and password, we can use the same credentials which &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; we use for login to the VMC vCenter &amp;quot;<span class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="096a65667c6d686d646067497f646a2765666a6865">[email&#160;protected]</span>&amp;quot;.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_fa04205a4f3a4e96bc81fd68a426e4ae~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;8) We will now see a nice dashboard of HCX Cloud with overview and other badges, We will see a section in &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; dashboard which says Hybrid Connectivity and there we will find the link for Downloading the HCX Enterprise &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; Client.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_344b695d201444c49c79d6b9315828a5~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;9) By Clicking on this link it will take us to the administration page and we will find a Request download link option &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; there, once we click on that it will display the download link or copy link option for downloading on-prem HCX &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; Manager OVA.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_49ecb442507f42a090245a654abd0057~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;10) Once the OVA is downloaded, next we will have to deploy this OVA, which is very straight forward ova &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; deployment in the network section we just need to make sure we are selecting a network which has connectivity as &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; per the first network port diagram we discussed (in most cases a management network with all the required ports &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; opened.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;11) After the deployment its time for the activation and registration process, we can open the HCX manager page by &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; providing its FQDN or IP on port 9443, using admin as user and the password we supplied during the OVA &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; deployment. which will directly give us the page for the registration where we will find the url mentioned for &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; activation as &amp;quot;https://connect.hcx.vmware.com&amp;quot; and its asking for the activation key, paste the activation key and &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; click on Continue.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_89b3420b44324257ab3ff05c4ac157f3~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;12) Next we will be prompted to select the city and location of the on-prem HCX manager. select and click yes and &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; continue and the activation will get completed&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;13) Next screen is the registration with on-prem vCenter (vCenter fqdn, admin username and password)&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;14) if NSX registration is required (For extending the vxlan networks) select connect our nsx and enter the username &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; and password for nsx manager click continue.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;15) Enter the SSO username and password and Click Continue.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;16) To get everything correct and in working condition click on Restart HCX service (it takes 5 minutes to reinitialize &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; the hcx)&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;17) We may have to keep refreshing the page and once everything is up and running, we will see the dashboard with all &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; the updated information.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_608fe8b22b8b4f8791b0c319ab61a6b7~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;Once everything is up and running like in the above screen shot immidiately we can add some users to manage the HCX components by clicking on configuration and selecting &amp;quot;vSphere Role Mapping&amp;quot; option. through the configuration page we can verify and change other registrations like vCenter or NSX as well.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_bd0ed00b59f64589948131c00b6ac16c~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;Next we can verify the HCX plugin and its functionality by logging in to the on-prem vSphere web Client.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_93130f75a8024a07be6b968a05378cf2~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;On the Right hand side Click on new Site Pairing and You will be asked to provide Site URL, which is the URL of your HCX Manager Cloud Instance (e.g. https://[HCX-Manager-Cloud-Instance-IP]) and the <span class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="187b74776d7c797c757176586e757b3674777b7974">[email&#160;protected]</span> username and credential. Click Register.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_7f1102fcedc34113b401bd85abf50bae~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;Great ! so we have successfully installed and configured the HCX on the on-prem side and connected it successfully to the cloud (VMware Cloud on AWS), in the next blog we will try to understand the Interconnect service, Service Components and different type of migrations. &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Next - &lt;a href="https://www.virtualramp.net/single-post/2018/09/04/Deploy-and-configure-HCX-for-VMware-Cloud-on-AWS-Part--2"&gt;Deploy and configure HCX for VMware Cloud on AWS Part -2&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;]]&gt;&lt;/content:encoded&gt;&lt;/item&gt;&lt;item&gt;&lt;title&gt;Deploy and configure HCX for VMware Cloud on AWS Part -2&lt;/title&gt;&lt;description&gt;&lt;![CDATA[In part-1 we have deployed HCX in the cloud as well as in on prem and connected these 2 as well. In Part-2 we will deploy and configure the interconnect components, I have already given an introduction to this components in Part-1 however lets do a recap here as well..1- HCX Interconnect service : HCX Interconnect service provides resilient access over the Internet and private lines to the target site while providing strong encryption, traffic engineering and extending the datacenter. This&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_614b7e57a2264d90a46304bc0d48f2ab%7Emv2.png/v1/fill/w_961%2Ch_361/165892_614b7e57a2264d90a46304bc0d48f2ab%7Emv2.png"/&gt;]]&gt;&lt;/description&gt;&lt;dc:creator&gt;Atul Srivastava&lt;/dc:creator&gt;&lt;link&gt;https://www.virtualramp.net/single-post/2018/09/04/Deploy-and-configure-HCX-for-VMware-Cloud-on-AWS-Part--2&lt;/link&gt;&lt;guid&gt;https://www.virtualramp.net/single-post/2018/09/04/Deploy-and-configure-HCX-for-VMware-Cloud-on-AWS-Part--2&lt;/guid&gt;&lt;pubDate&gt;Tue, 04 Sep 2018 13:04:28 +0000&lt;/pubDate&gt;&lt;content:encoded&gt;&lt;![CDATA[&lt;div&gt;&lt;div&gt;In &lt;a href="https://www.virtualramp.net/single-post/2018/09/04/Deploy-and-configure-HCX-for-VMware-Cloud-on-AWS-Part--1"&gt;part-1&lt;/a&gt; we have deployed HCX in the cloud as well as in on prem and connected these 2 as well. In Part-2 we will deploy and configure the interconnect components, I have already given an introduction to this components in Part-1 however lets do a recap here as well..&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;1- HCX Interconnect service : HCX Interconnect service provides resilient access over the Internet and private lines to the target site while providing strong encryption, traffic engineering and extending the datacenter. This services simplifies secure pairing of sites and management of HCX components.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;3- WAN Optimization Service (Optional) : Improves performance characteristics of the private lines or Internet paths by leveraging WAN Optimization techniques like data de-duplication and line conditioning. This makes performance closer to a LAN environment.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;4- Network Extension Service: High throughput Network Extension service with integrated Proximity Routing which unlocks seamless mobility and simple disaster recovery plans across sites.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Further to this we will also get some more understanding of these components once we will deploy them so let's do it :&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;1) To deploy these services we will login to the onprem vSphere-Web-Client and open the HCX Plugin and go to the Interconnect option and select HCX Components. &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;2) Click on Install HCX Components&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;3) Select the Components to be installed&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_614b7e57a2264d90a46304bc0d48f2ab~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;HCX Interconnect Service will be required for Bulk Migration (replication based Migration) as well as vMotion (Live Migration)&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;WAN optimization will deploy an extra appliance that will will enable the compression and de-duplication capabilities. &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Network Extension service will be used for Following requests&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Use Extension with Migration to keep Virtual Machine IP and MAC addresses during migration.Extend VLANS from VMware’s vSphere Distributed Switch.Extend VXLANs (Requires NSX integration in the HCX Appliance Management interface).Extend Cisco’s Nexus 1000v networks.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Let's Click on Next which gives us a form to be filled for IX (Interconnect)&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_c77722e1178844bfb4b02b0841fe41fa~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Network : Select a distributed port group. The interface connected to the selected network is used for management of the appliance, for HCX internal communications, and for the migration protocols. Selecting the ESX Management network is preferred.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Cluster/Host: To deploy the service, select a resource VM. Ensure that the appliance is not resource constrained for maximum migration performance.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Datastore : Use the flash/high performance tier datastore for maximum migration performance. HCX Interconnect disks are 1.5 GB.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;IP Address/Prefix Length : Provide an available IP address and prefix length for the network selected .&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Default Gateway : The network gateway IP address for the specified network.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;DNS : Provide the local DNS server IP address.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;vMotion Network : Select the vMotion distributed port group. If the management network defined in step 1 is also used for vMotion, leave this left blank.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;vMotion IP Address/PL : Provide an available IP address and prefix length in the same range as the vMotion network for the network selected. Skip if 7 was left blank&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Click Next&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Configure this setting only if there is a need to restrict the bandwidth available for HCX.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Click Next &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Deploying the Network Extension Service appliance allows networks to be extended in the vSphere Web Client. The Remote HCX-NET-EXT appliance is created automatically whenever a local appliance is deployed. The HCX-NET-EXT service appliance is always deployed as a pair.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Compute : To deploy the service VM, select a resource; Consider the Deployment Options implications when selecting the resource. See the preceding Deployment Options section for details.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Datastore : Select a datastore for deploying the Extension appliance. Network Extension appliance disks are about 1.5 GB total.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Network : Select a distributed port group. The interface connected to the selected network is used for management of the appliance and HCX internal communications with the HCX Manager&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;VM Hostname : Specify a friendly name for the HCX Network Extension VM.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;IP Address/Prefix Length : Provide an available IP address and prefix length (e.g 255.255.255.128 = PL 25) for the selected network.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Default Gateway : The network gateway IP address for the specified network.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Passwords : Set the admin and root passwords. Click Next and configure the other selected services, or to the Ready to Configure screen.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_dd08cb87b315410485046c68073d2315~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;Click on Finish and we can monitor the tasks at cloud side as well as at On-prem side. you will notice few peer appliances will get deployed at both the sides. &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;This will take some time for these components to show up in the HCX component section of the interconnect tab.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Once everything is up and running we will get tunnel status as up for Migration service and network extension service individually.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_081fa05ef1e841d6b97b9e625f9f12f5~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;Cool Now let us try some migrations :)&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Let's click on the Migration tab and select the option Migrate Virtual Machine.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;This will open the Migrate virtual Machine to remote Site Window (By default this is onprem to cloud migration), if we want to perform cloud to onprem Migration we can select the first check box which says &amp;quot;Reverse Migration&amp;quot;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;We can select default option to default the settings of the destination location for all the VMs or we can select it on an individual VM basis as well.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_8efecc55b4b847be83d889707a714796~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;Usually on the cloud side we don't have much access to the resources so we will Select the Folder as &amp;quot;Workloads&amp;quot; Resource pool as &amp;quot;Compute-Resource-pool&amp;quot; and Data-store as &amp;quot;WorkloadDatastore&amp;quot; .&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Remember to choose &amp;quot;Select Migration Type&amp;quot; as vMotion or Bulk Migration. vMotion will be a cold or hot Migration of the VM however Bulk Migration&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;- Will Create a copy of the VM at destination&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;- Run the replication for source and destination side VM&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;- Powers off the source VM&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;- Rename the Source VM&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;- Power On the Destination VM.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Once all the options are good, click next for the validation and then finish to start the migration.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;In My lab I did a vMotion of a VM from on-prem to Cloud and then Bulk Migrated in back to the On-Prem. &lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_25e701c2b8a34cd6bece58441a821ac8~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;vMotion Completed and Bulk Migration replication in progress &lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_14cbcb113be84b619448bf0259d7c2cb~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt; Bulk Migration and vMotion both completed Successfully&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_5211426cca8a4cd48f78916e97ff9b70~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt; Highlighted is the renamed and powered off VM at source side after bulk migration&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;**whatever we have discussed is only for the first time deployment of HCX however if there is a need to connect second data-center to the VMware cloud on AWS, we will have to perform some extra steps, where in the Network section of the SDDC scroll down till &amp;quot;Public IPs&amp;quot; we will have to request some additional Public IPs and once those IPs are available will have to get in touch with VMware on AWS support for getting these IPs updated at the backend to the fleet pool . and then proceed with the deployment from step-1.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.virtualramp.net/single-post/2018/09/04/Deploy-and-configure-HCX-for-VMware-Cloud-on-AWS-Part--1"&gt;Deploy-and-configure-HCX-for-VMware-Cloud-on-AWS-Part--1&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;This is amazing that how simple it is to migrate VMs from onprem to VMware cloud on AWS and vice-versa. So in this 2 part blog post we have successfully deployed and tested the HCX Migration and I hope it will help others in setting up and understanding the product..&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;]]&gt;&lt;/content:encoded&gt;&lt;/item&gt;&lt;item&gt;&lt;title&gt;Secure your VMware Cloud on AWS Deployment (Auto-scaler &amp;amp; Stretched Cluster)&lt;/title&gt;&lt;description&gt;&lt;![CDATA["VMware cloud on aws" is moving towards maturity very fast, New features are coming on the road maps and existing features are getting robust.
