When we design a data-center, the thumb rule of a good design is that components (Physical or virtual) should be well protected. When we talk about the protection, to protect our vSphere based data-centers (physical or SDDC) we have been using vSpere HA for years now and it has its own proven capability in-case of host failure in a cluster, HA works&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_156c2d6b72804e00b185b8ff5105368d%7Emv2.jpg/v1/fill/w_841%2Ch_349/165892_156c2d6b72804e00b185b8ff5105368d%7Emv2.jpg"/&gt;]]&gt;&lt;/description&gt;&lt;dc:creator&gt;Atul Srivastava&lt;/dc:creator&gt;&lt;link&gt;https://www.virtualramp.net/single-post/2018/08/06/Secure-your-VMware-Cloud-on-AWS-Deployment-Auto-scaler-Stretched-Cluster&lt;/link&gt;&lt;guid&gt;https://www.virtualramp.net/single-post/2018/08/06/Secure-your-VMware-Cloud-on-AWS-Deployment-Auto-scaler-Stretched-Cluster&lt;/guid&gt;&lt;pubDate&gt;Mon, 06 Aug 2018 18:57:44 +0000&lt;/pubDate&gt;&lt;content:encoded&gt;&lt;![CDATA[&lt;div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&amp;quot;VMware cloud on aws&amp;quot; is moving towards maturity very fast, New features are coming on the road maps and existing features are getting robust. When we design a data-center, the thumb rule of a good design is that components (Physical or virtual) should be well protected. When we talk about the protection, to protect our vSphere based data-centers (physical or SDDC) we have been using vSpere HA for years now and it has its own proven capability in-case of host failure in a cluster, HA works really well in VMware Cloud on AWS SDDC and to double the security there is an auto-scaler mechanism also in-place. if a host fails, HA restarts all the VMs hosted on the failed host on another host and Auto-scaler tries to restart the failed host. if even after restarting the failed host it does not come up, auto-scaler starts adding a new host to the cluster automatically and replaces the failed host, This automation is awesome and gives a fastest recovery of a failed infrastructure deployed in the same AWS availability zone. &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Now what about protection at Availability zone level ? Yes VMware cloud on AWS has answer for this now as well &amp;quot;A Stretched Cluster&amp;quot; , Though we know that it is likely to happen may be once in years but as we discussed earlier single point of failure is not acceptable at any level .&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;What is a Stretched Cluster in Vmware Cloud on AWS :&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;The Stretched Cluster (aka Multi AZ deployment) deploys a Single SDDC across two Availability Zones. for example if you have deployed 6 Servers in an SDDC (6 is the minimum requirement for Stretched Cluster), 3 of them will be deployed in one Availability Zone and other 3 will be deployed in the Second availability zone. Thus it will use 2 Subnets ( one per availability zone) to identify the ESXi with Subnets. Stretched Cluster is using vSan Stretched cluster feature to spin-up vSan in 2 different AZs. &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;So how does the Failures been communicated ..? Yes your are right there is a Witness Node who takes care of the failure scenarios. This witness node resides outside of the cluster and in a third availability zone. &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Not only vSAN this deployment also extends network between 2 availability zones using NSX. This will leverage seamless migration and communication of the workload VMs distributed in 2 AZs.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Here is the list of What a stretched cluster is offering as of today&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;- Zero RPO high availability for enterprise applications virtualized on vSphere across AWS Availability Zones (AZ), leveraging multi-AZ stretched clustering. Stretched clusters enable developers to focus on core application requirements and capabilities, instead of infrastructure availability. &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;- Significantly improve your application's availability without needing to architect it into your application - the VMware Cloud on AWS infrastructure delivers protection against failures of AWS AZs at an infrastructure level. &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;- Stretching an SDDC cluster across two AWS AZs within a region means if an AZ goes down, it is simply treated as a vSphere HA event and the virtual machine is restarted in the other AZ. &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;The Deployment :&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Key point to remember is that a Stretched Cluster option is only available when first time deploying the SDDC. we will not be able to enable this after the deployment is completed or on an existing SDDC.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;The process of deployment is same as normal SDDC deployment however you need to select deployment type as Multi Host &amp;amp; Stretched cluster, the moment we select Stretched cluster checkbox number of host will change to minimum 6. &lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_156c2d6b72804e00b185b8ff5105368d~mv2.jpg"/&gt;&lt;div&gt; After SDDC properties you select rest of the options as usual and the only change after this you will notice is in the VPC and Subnet Section where you will be able to select the VPC and 2 Subnets from the subnet drop - down (both should be from different AZs)&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_46971dbd87da4edb96686e2928fe5048~mv2.jpg"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;Once the deployment is complete you will see 2 AZs listed in the summary page of the SDDC, Also if you login to the vCenter you will find a separate ESXi host like entry in the inventory which is out side of the Cluster that is the witness node (towards the bottom of the following pic)&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_5a12591b1d194ea1abbbf4aaa4896a08~mv2.jpg"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;And this is all about the Protection of SDDC. for live demo and understanding use this &lt;a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zea-hNiPois&amp;amp;feature=youtu.be"&gt;you tube link&lt;/a&gt; :)&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;]]&gt;&lt;/content:encoded&gt;&lt;/item&gt;&lt;item&gt;&lt;title&gt;Introduction to Firewall Rule Accelerator and Troubleshooting tab&lt;/title&gt;&lt;description&gt;&lt;![CDATA[Setting up Hybrid linked mode was a multi-step process as I explained in my previous Blog post Hybrid linked mode . VMware has integrated some new features and tools with VMware Cloud on AWS to eliminate few steps and customers can perform majority of the pre-checks before they implement Hybrid Linked mode. Let's Check these cool features1) Firewall Rule Accelerator : Correctly setting up a firewall rule is a Crucial step for network communications to happen correctly, When we start with HLM&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_3da173690e16462cad7d076f74288cae%7Emv2.jpg/v1/fill/w_961%2Ch_459/165892_3da173690e16462cad7d076f74288cae%7Emv2.jpg"/&gt;]]&gt;&lt;/description&gt;&lt;dc:creator&gt;Atul Srivastava&lt;/dc:creator&gt;&lt;link&gt;https://www.virtualramp.net/single-post/2018/07/17/New-Enhancement-To-make-HLM-setup-easy&lt;/link&gt;&lt;guid&gt;https://www.virtualramp.net/single-post/2018/07/17/New-Enhancement-To-make-HLM-setup-easy&lt;/guid&gt;&lt;pubDate&gt;Fri, 29 Jun 2018 11:17:00 +0000&lt;/pubDate&gt;&lt;content:encoded&gt;&lt;![CDATA[&lt;div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Setting up Hybrid linked mode was a multi-step process as I explained in my previous Blog post &lt;a href="https://www.virtualramp.net/single-post/2018/05/30/Hybrid-Linked-Mode"&gt;Hybrid linked mode&lt;/a&gt; . VMware has integrated some new features and tools with VMware Cloud on AWS to eliminate few steps and customers can perform majority of the pre-checks before they implement Hybrid Linked mode. &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Let's Check these cool features&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;div&gt;1) Firewall Rule Accelerator :Correctly setting up a firewall rule is a Crucial step for network communications to &lt;/div&gt;happen correctly, When we start with HLM setup between onprem and VMware Cloud on AWS vCenter there are few firewall ports which we need to open as mentioned in my &lt;div&gt;previous post &lt;a href="https://www.virtualramp.net/single-post/2018/05/30/Hybrid-Linked-Mode"&gt;Hybrid linked mode&lt;/a&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.virtualramp.net/single-post/2018/05/30/Hybrid-Linked-Mode"&gt;. VMware has introduced Firewall rule accelerator f&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.virtualramp.net/single-post/2018/05/30/Hybrid-Linked-Mode"&gt;eature on the Networking page of the SDDC. This feature will eliminate the process of&lt;/a&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.virtualramp.net/single-post/2018/05/30/Hybrid-Linked-Mode"&gt;remembering and creating the correct firewall rules for the features like HLM, vMotion&lt;/a&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.virtualramp.net/single-post/2018/05/30/Hybrid-Linked-Mode"&gt;and SRM at VMware Cloud on AWS side.&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.virtualramp.net/single-post/2018/05/30/Hybrid-Linked-Mode"&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Procedure&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Log in to the VMC Console at https://vmc.vmware.com.Navigate to the Network tab of your SDDC.Under Management Gateway, click IPsec VPNs.Click Firewall Rule Accelerator.The Firewall Rules Accelerator opens.From the VPN (Remote Network) drop-down menu, select the remote (on-premises) network that you want to create firewall rules for.The Firewall Rules Accelerator displays the rules that will be created.Click Create Firewall Rules to create these rules.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;How will you identify what all rule FRA (Firewall Rule Accelerator) has created ? The answer is simple whatever IPSEC VPN you have selected in above steps all the firewall rules created by the accelerator will start with that name.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;div&gt;2) Troubleshooting Tab : A new troubleshooting tab is introduced in the SDDC Page with this tab we can run a Pre-check for &lt;/div&gt;the HLM setup, where we can check the connectivity from Cloud vCenter to Onprem components (DNS, onprem vCenter, AD server, PSC and ESXI) This test will involve ping, port and name resolution for different components, which are important for HLM setup.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_3da173690e16462cad7d076f74288cae~mv2.jpg"/&gt;&lt;div&gt; You just need to enter the on-prem details of different components and Click on Run all Tests.. It will Show the Results and we can straight forward work on the resolution to fix the issues before implementation. &lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;]]&gt;&lt;/content:encoded&gt;&lt;/item&gt;&lt;item&gt;&lt;title&gt;Configure an Extended Network and Layer 2 VPN&lt;/title&gt;&lt;description&gt;&lt;![CDATA[Extended network with L2 VPN can be useful when we want to extend our onprem network to VMware Cloud on AWS environment. This configuration can help when we want to move our on-prem VMs to the cloud and do not want to loose network settings or want to keep same IP address in cloud as well. Apart from this we may want to spin-up new VMs and want them to be in the same network as our onprem VMs are. Stretching of L2 VPN requires a supported device at onprem side For Example Stand alone nsx edge,&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_3686f41b28804a86b8a6d76d3ca46dba%7Emv2.jpg"/&gt;]]&gt;&lt;/description&gt;&lt;dc:creator&gt;Atul Srivastava&lt;/dc:creator&gt;&lt;link&gt;https://www.virtualramp.net/single-post/2018/06/25/Configure-an-Extended-Network-and-Layer-2-VPN&lt;/link&gt;&lt;guid&gt;https://www.virtualramp.net/single-post/2018/06/25/Configure-an-Extended-Network-and-Layer-2-VPN&lt;/guid&gt;&lt;pubDate&gt;Mon, 25 Jun 2018 13:12:24 +0000&lt;/pubDate&gt;&lt;content:encoded&gt;&lt;![CDATA[&lt;div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Extended network with L2 VPN can be useful when we want to extend our onprem network to VMware Cloud on AWS environment. This configuration can help when we want to move our on-prem VMs to the cloud and do not want to loose network settings or want to keep same IP address in cloud as well. Apart from this we may want to spin-up new VMs and want them to be in the same network as our onprem VMs are. Stretching of L2 VPN requires a supported device at onprem side &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;For Example Stand alone nsx edge, NSX Edge or any supported gateway device for L2 stretch. in all the configurations VMC side will act as a server side of L2 VPN and the on prem device will join this server as client.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;For the purpose of demonstration in this blog I am using a full edge deployment.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Before I forget let's have a look at the prerequisites &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;The on-premises data center must be running vSphere 5.0 or later. vSphere 5.1 or later is recommendedThe source NSX Edge providing L2VPN client services must be NSX 6.1.1 or later. NSX 6.4.0 is recommendedYou can stretch a vLAN or vxLAN, (This demo is for vxLAN)An uplink IP address is required for the NSX Edge instance that serves as the L2 VPN client. This address must be the Compute Gateway public IP. Create a firewall rule to allow HTTPS traffic from this IP address to the cloud SDDC.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;So let's Start with this setup&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;1) Configuration at VMware Cloud on AWS side : there are 2 simple configuration needed at VMware Cloud on AWS side - &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;a) Created an extended network &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;To create an extended network open the cloud vCenter and click on Menu, Select option Global inventory list&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_b1758570f3e24a2085cc31ad5874a21c~mv2.jpg"/&gt;&lt;div&gt; In the Global inventory list select Logical Networks option and Click on ADD&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_2f8f413b95f54cb08e90b49e171faa02~mv2.jpg"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;In the New Logical Network window change the Network from Routed Network to Extended Network, Also fill in a network name and Tunnel ID (You can put in any random number between 0 to 4093 and note down this number because this will be used while configuring on-prem side)&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_8c82acf1470741dba9aafe181c683387~mv2.jpg"/&gt;&lt;div&gt; That's ! it part a of Cloud side is done now let's move to part b&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;b) In Part b we will prepare the L2 VPN Server in our SDDC, for doing this, we have to open the desired SDDC by logging into https://vmc.vmware.com, once you are in your SDDC &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;- Click on network tab &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;- Scroll Down till Compute Gateway &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;- Expand L2 VPN. &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;- Click Add VPN&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;- In the Add VPN Section fill out the Details&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;VPN Name - Give a name of your choice&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Status and Server IP will auto populate (Note Down the Server IP to supply it during Client Creation)&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Encryption - Currently supported only AES128 we can select either on or off for encryption&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Username - Any username of your choice (keep a note for client side config)&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Password - Any password of your choice (keep a note for client side config)&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_3686f41b28804a86b8a6d76d3ca46dba~mv2.jpg"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;Click Save and the VMware cloud on AWS part is done, Now comes the on-prem part&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;2) Configuration at Onprem Side (we will stretch a Logical network over L2 VPN) :&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;In the following picture we are using Test L2 logical switch for my VMs on onprem and we would like to stretch this over L2 VPN.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_346abeeab34e4d8ca7137be068b61136~mv2.jpg"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;2. a) Once done we can start our task by creating a trunk port on the distributed switch (We can create this trunk port on standard switch as well) This port &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; will later be used while creating trunk port on NSX edge.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; 2 things to remember while creating trunk port are VLAN type as VLAN trunking &amp;amp; setting forged transmits to Accept&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_e44ed7d07cfb4f4f8bd9d447ce680405~mv2.jpg"/&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_11e7a2bac13f4e1897247a2391b48c5c~mv2.jpg"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;2.b) Lets do the NSX side configuration now&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;We need to go to Network and security in vSphere client and highlight NSX edges and double click the Edge device (This Edge should either have a public IP as up-link or connectivity to the internet)&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;In the Edge Select Manage &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;In the Manage &amp;gt; Settings tab for an NSX Edge, click Interfaces.Select an interface and click the Edit () icon.In the Edit Edge Interface dialog box, type a name for the interface.In Type, select TrunkSelect the standard portgroup or distributed portgroup to which we created as trunk in step 2.a &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Click Change next to the Connected To field.Depending on what you want to connect to the interface, click the Standard Portgroup or Distributed Portgroup tab.Select the appropriate portgroup and click OK. &lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_68adbb943c4a481f81cbc77f21d0c616~mv2.jpg"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;In Sub Interfaces, click the Add icon.Click Enable Sub interface and type a name for the sub interface.In Tunnel Id, type a number between 1 and 4094 (here enter the same tunnel ID which we entered while creating the extended network at VMC side in part 1)In Backing Type, we are selecting Network because we will extend the VXLAN network.Click Select and select the distributed portgroup or logical switch. (The network we identified in the beginning of part 2 To add subnets to the sub interface, click the Add icon in the Configure Subnets area.In Add Subnets, click the Add icon to add an IP address. Type the IP address and click OK. (VMS connected to this network will be using this IP as their gateway IPEdit the default MTU value for the sub interface if required.Select Enable Send Redirect to convey routing information to hosts.Enable or Disable Reverse Path Filter.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Reverse Path Filter verifies the readability of the source address in packets being forwarded. In enabled mode, the packet must be received on the interface that the router would use to forward the return packet. In loose mode, the source address must appear in the routing table&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_dc680af6b9ad4aa1ad6298bfd58bc421~mv2.jpg"/&gt;&lt;div&gt; Click on OK &lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_f1016839b3d84536b4517e3da5068307~mv2.jpg"/&gt;&lt;div&gt; Click on OK to close the NSX Edge Interface Window.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Now Let's click on the Manage &amp;gt; VPN in the NSX Edge Screen and select L2 VPN, After this we will have to select L2 VPN Mode as Client (the VMware cloud on aws side will act as L2 VPN server) and click on the change Button.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_b3201f70054441ea8f992c85f155af07~mv2.jpg"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;Now we are in Client Details window, Let's fill out the details&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Server Addreess : Fill in the Public IP address of L2 VPN server which we recorded in part 1.b.Encryption Algorithm : It should be same as what we have supplied in part 1.b. (As of now only AES 128 bit is supported )Stretched Interface : click on select sub Interface and choose the interface which we have created in previous step.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;We will Leave rest of the fields as blank and We will come down to User ID and password Section where we will fill in the Same User ID and password which we have supplied at VMware cloud on AWS end and recorded in section 1.b.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_804bd6285f9e4923aaa35df91241fb0d~mv2.jpg"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;Click on OK Now we are back on the VPN screenLets Click on the Start Button on L2 VPN Service Status.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;If Everything is configured correctly we should see The VPN tunnel as UP in the Tunnel Status Section&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_566e91c56fba4cbb9f5d76988377e2da~mv2.jpg"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;Now Let's try to test the connectivity.. For this I have Migrated a VM from my on-prem to VMware Cloud on AWS and trying to ping Its gateway &lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_d1ca12eb44ed4df4b98b445ee84920a8~mv2.jpg"/&gt;&lt;div&gt; So this was a long process of extending The L2 Network from the On-Prem to VMware cloud on AWS environment. if you do not have NSX implemented you can use standalone-edge. or any supported physical device.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;For extending An on prem network as an L2 extension and also to bulk migrate Vms from Onprem to VMware cloud on AWS VMware has already introduced a new add-on Called HCX (Hybrid Cloud Extension) Which is a very exciting tool to use and Migrate the workload. the Best part of this add-on is it is Free of cost with VMware cloud on AWS solution. We will talk about it in detail in my upcoming blogs.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;]]&gt;&lt;/content:encoded&gt;&lt;/item&gt;&lt;item&gt;&lt;title&gt;Hybrid Linked Mode&lt;/title&gt;&lt;description&gt;&lt;![CDATA[Hybrid linked mode is one of the coolest features of VMware cloud on AWS . using this we can manage our on-prem vCenter and VMC vCenter from one single console (Like enhanced linked mode). To achieve this we will have to establish a trust between onprem sso and VMC sso domain also we will add our on-prem Active directory server or LDAP server as an identity source to our VMC vCenter, by doing this you are opening a path for your active directory users to login to VMC vCenter URL. This will&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_81a96059209042ee8931c12453c9841b%7Emv2.jpg"/&gt;]]&gt;&lt;/description&gt;&lt;dc:creator&gt;Atul Srivastava&lt;/dc:creator&gt;&lt;link&gt;https://www.virtualramp.net/single-post/2018/05/30/Hybrid-Linked-Mode&lt;/link&gt;&lt;guid&gt;https://www.virtualramp.net/single-post/2018/05/30/Hybrid-Linked-Mode&lt;/guid&gt;&lt;pubDate&gt;Fri, 11 May 2018 08:31:00 +0000&lt;/pubDate&gt;&lt;content:encoded&gt;&lt;![CDATA[&lt;div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Hybrid linked mode is one of the coolest features of VMware cloud on AWS . using this we can manage our on-prem vCenter and VMC vCenter from one single console (Like enhanced linked mode). To achieve this we will have to establish a trust between onprem sso and VMC sso domain also we will add our on-prem Active directory server or LDAP server as an identity source to our VMC vCenter, by doing this you are opening a path for your active directory users to login to VMC vCenter URL. This will prevent us from sharing the <span class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="83e0efecf6e7e2e7eeeaedc3f5eee0adefece0e2ef">[email&#160;protected]</span> credentials with other admins and non-admin users. &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Also getting both the vCenters in one single window enables you to vMotion your VM (cold and hot) from your onprem Environment to VMware cloud on aws and vice versa (for hot migration there are additional recommendations like Direct-x).&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;let's start with the prerequisites for HLM : &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Prerequisites at Onprem side:&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;1) vSphere 6.5.0d or later.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;2) You can link only one on-premises SSO domain&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;3) Configure a management gateway IPsec VPN connection between your on-premises data center and cloud SDDC. ( &lt;a href="https://www.virtualramp.net/single-post/2018/04/23/Connect-the-Onprem-to-VMC-IPsec-VPN-Part-2"&gt;Click here&lt;/a&gt;to know how)&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;4) Ensure that you have network connectivity between your VMware Cloud on AWS management gateway and your on-premises ID source and &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; SSO domain.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;5) Ensure that the onprem firewall allows access to necessary ports from the VMC SDDC&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;On-premises vCenter Server Ports 443On-premises Platform Services Controller Ports 389, 636On-premises Active Directory server Ports 389, 636, 3268, 3269On-premises DNS Port 53&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;6) Create an AD group on your onprem side to allow access on VMC&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;7) Ensure you have login credentials for your onprem SSO domain.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Prerequisites at VMC side:&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;1) Accessibility to onprem vCenter, DNS and AD server&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;2) Create firewall rule in management gateway (Update : We can now use firewall rule accelerator check this &lt;a href="https://www.virtualramp.net/single-post/2018/07/17/New-Enhancement-To-make-HLM-setup-easy"&gt;blog post&lt;/a&gt;)&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;SDDC vCenter access - HTTPSvCenter SSO access - TCP 7444&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Update : We can now use some cool new features of Running pre-checks and creating firewall rules with firewall rule accelerator check out this &lt;a href="https://www.virtualramp.net/single-post/2018/07/17/New-Enhancement-To-make-HLM-setup-easy"&gt;blog post&lt;/a&gt; )&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;See below Example : &lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_1a40bc2499e443ffaf82ad6dd18cce96~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;3) Enter the onprem DNS server address in vmc management gateway to resolve the on-prem identity source and PSC. &lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_48154a6acd4144ebb39684e7de700155~mv2.jpg"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;4) Also make an entry for VMC vCenter private IP in your onprem DNS. we can find the private IP in support tab of the SDDC.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_aa0d2e4b1d6547688516e3fb1c8b8add~mv2.jpg"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;Let's start the HLM configuration &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;1) Login to the VMC vCenter by using the URL provided in support tab, and by supplying the credentials for <span class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="2447484b51404540494d4a645249470a484b474548">[email&#160;protected]</span> &lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_4222b811f4e84cec842cce1f7f7095e8~mv2.jpg"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;2) Click on menu and select administration.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_d5d8ab2d1610424397e020003298bde7~mv2.jpg"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;3) At the Left side pane click on Linked Domains&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_20ae3ebb94a34fd6a5b35c12548de153~mv2.jpg"/&gt;&lt;div&gt; 4) We get a form to fill-up with some onprem details Like on prem PSC Information, add the on-prem active directory or LDAP as identity &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; source and add the AD group which we want to allow access here.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;a) First we filled up the information about onprem SSO and then we clicked on the drop-down of select identity source and selected Add Identity Source.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_9f71928ee05d452389676c8184c9de9c~mv2.jpg"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;b) After Clicking on Add Identity Source it opens a new form for us and we fill in all the details here&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_7abf03480493453e99ccab10a2c50f79~mv2.jpg"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;Identity Source Type : select either Active Directory over LADAP or open LDAP&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Identity Source Name : Give any name of your Choice&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Base distinguished name for users &amp;amp; Base Base distinguished name for groups :&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;** we can get this info from Active directory users and computers By selecting the attribute editor option in the properties of the folder or OU (refer the image below)&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_d5e20f9014e34e9491d5cec5b9821a4e~mv2.jpg"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;Domain Name : Domain name of your onprem domain&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;username : domain admin username&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;password : domain admin password&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Connect to : specify specific DC name or select first option&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Rest all options are optional&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;5 - Click Add&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;6- Once this is added the onprem identity source will start reflecting in identity source section and once we start typing the Group names from&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; AD it will give you the results to add the groups in allowed list of VMC vCenter login. (in this example I have created VMCADMINS group in &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; the AD).&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_ffa81bbffc5e42c6afdb41982f008e39~mv2.jpg"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;7- Once the groups are added we can click on link button at the bottom (We may get a certificate warning click on continue)&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;8- And finally it says Domain has been linked :) &lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_81a96059209042ee8931c12453c9841b~mv2.jpg"/&gt;&lt;div&gt; 9- Clicking OK will log us out from <span class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="4a2926253f2e2b2e2723240a3c2729642625292b26">[email&#160;protected]</span> account&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;10- You can now login with an onprem ad user which is a part of allowed domain and has permission to access the onprem vCenter.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_2da1e5ecd21a41a183b88e79b3f93684~mv2.jpg"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;This is It ! we have successfully setup the Hybrid Linked mode and able to manage both the vCenters from one console. &lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;]]&gt;&lt;/content:encoded&gt;&lt;/item&gt;&lt;item&gt;&lt;title&gt;Securing your Active Directory environment with VMware cloud on AWS&lt;/title&gt;&lt;description&gt;&lt;![CDATA[History:Securing an active directory environment is a very crucial consideration while designing a datacenter in a traditional datacenter environment to secure an AD environment we keep a primary domain controller at the primary site and secondary domain controller in some other site, so that in any unwanted situation we make sure our directory services are available and users/resources are getting authenticated with the available domain controller.Introducing VMware Cloud to the Scenario:With&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_73d4ae2a28e0439b939b30dd343e38e7%7Emv2.png/v1/fill/w_961%2Ch_184/165892_73d4ae2a28e0439b939b30dd343e38e7%7Emv2.png"/&gt;]]&gt;&lt;/description&gt;&lt;link&gt;https://www.virtualramp.net/single-post/2018/04/28/Securing-your-Active-Directory-environment-with-VMware-cloud-on-AWS&lt;/link&gt;&lt;guid&gt;https://www.virtualramp.net/single-post/2018/04/28/Securing-your-Active-Directory-environment-with-VMware-cloud-on-AWS&lt;/guid&gt;&lt;pubDate&gt;Sat, 28 Apr 2018 08:43:00 +0000&lt;/pubDate&gt;&lt;content:encoded&gt;&lt;![CDATA[&lt;div&gt;&lt;div&gt;History:&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Securing an active directory environment is a very crucial consideration while designing a datacenter in a traditional datacenter environment to secure an AD environment we keep a primary domain controller at the primary site and secondary domain controller in some other site, so that in any unwanted situation we make sure our directory services are available and users/resources are getting authenticated with the available domain controller.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Introducing VMware Cloud to the Scenario:&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;With the increased usage of VMware cloud on AWS, customers are liking the idea of using VMware cloud as a DR site for their on-prem environment. Adding to the same idea we will demonstrate how can we secure the on-prem Active directory environment by deploying a secondary domain controller in VMware cloud on aws , and if needed how can we promote it as a primary domain controller (DR or on-prem datacenter’s Maintenance/Upgradation) .&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;General Info for this demonstration:&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;There could be multiple active directory scenarios however for the purpose of this demonstration we are using following configuration.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;# 1 Primary domain controller named ad-dns.homelab.lab (preconfigured)&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;# 1 on-prem DNS server (Preconfigured)&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;# An Active and preconfigured CGW ipsec VPN (check my old post on how to configure VPN and firewall &lt;a href="https://www.virtualramp.net/single-post/2018/04/23/Connect-the-Onprem-to-VMC-IPsec-VPN-Part-2"&gt;click here&lt;/a&gt;) &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;# Onprem Domain Name homelab.lab&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;# VMC DC Name : VMC-AD-DNS&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Good to know information before we begin:&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;In an active directory environment, you typically have 1 Primary domain controller and some Secondary/Backup/additional domain controllers. Secondary domain controllers are used for load balancing and as a backup for primary DC in case of any failure.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Also, if there is a condition where we want to promote Secondary DC to primary we can do it by transferring/Seizing 5 FSMO roles to it.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Procedure:&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;To better understand the scenario Lets start with having a look at the current configuration.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;In my on-prem DC we ran “nltest /dclist:homelab.lab” command and found that currently we have only 1 DC i.e. ad-dns.homelab.lab.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_73d4ae2a28e0439b939b30dd343e38e7~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;Now we need to deploy a secondary DC (Server 2012 R2 for this demonstraion) in VMC environment and before that Some firewall configuration is needed and other settings need to be verified.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Opening Firewall rules on your onprem and CGW of VMC&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;TCP and UDP Port 88 – Kerberos authenticationTCP and UDP Port 135 – domain controllers-to-domain controller and client to domain controller operations.TCP Port 139 and UDP 138 – File Replication Service between domain controllers.UDP Port 389 – LDAP to handle normal queries from client computers to the domain controllers.TCP and UDP Port 445 – File Replication ServiceTCP and UDP Port 464 – Kerberos Password ChangeTCP Port 3268 and 3269 – Global Catalog from client to domain controller.TCP and UDP Port 53 – DNS from client to domain controller and domain controller to domain controller.TCP Port 5722 – DFSR/RPC – Sysvol Replication between Domain Controllers.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Other Consideration for the ports could be:&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;TCP Port Range 1025-5000 – If your network has any Server 2003 R2 or older domain controllers. This is the default dynamic range for RPC connections.TCP Port Range 49152-65535 – If your network has any Server 2008 or newer domain controllers. This is the new dynamic port range for RPC connections&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; 2. Connectivity between the new VM in VMC to DC and DNS server (verify it with ping)&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; 3. Change the DNS on VMC server to your on-prem DNS (If you are planning to install a secondary dns in VMC you can do that too)&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Install and Prepare the environment :&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;After all these checks we will install active directory role on the VMC server, The installation is simple, from server manager you click on add roles and features and select the box Active directory domain services and follow the wizard.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_80d8f9c9ca5b418b8adbb6f618891b7c~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;Once installed we need to configure it and the only difference in the configuration of Secondary Domain controller is, you select option as add a domain controller to an existing domain and supply the domain name and domain admin username and password.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_2cba20b7c68e4cfb8c6753429a983e55~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;Follow the wizard for rest of the configuration. If all the config is correct AD will be installed and during the installation it-self, you will be able to contact and list out the other DC.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_033a7e250d114f359fe41fff43d9ce5b~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;Once the wizard completes the secondary DC will reboot and That’s It! you are ready with your secondary Functional DC.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Now we will talk about the second scenario where we need to transfer the roles from primary to secondary DC.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Let’s verify which Domain controller is holding the FSMO roles right now.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;On any of the DC you run command “netdom /query fsmo” to check which DC holds what role&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_45b03da7384246baac2007e78c4e4ee4~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;As we can see above right now the onprem DC contains all the 5 FSMO roles.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;(For ow to transfer roles refer official Microsoft KB)&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;It was easy and quick I first transferred the domain wide role you can see the before and after transfer status of the Domain wide role transfer.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_e6dba319a1004799a0318a86cbb722e3~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;Once that was done we can transfer the forest wide roles as well, so all the 5 roles were now present on the DC hosted in VMware cloud.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_7d0a26b75e224a37aabd45c692cefa3e~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;Optionally you can perform a cleanup task to clear out the original DC entry (only if you don’t want to bring it back in the environment) demonstrated here.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_f4bd9314054c455daf584ad028982211~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt; And your new Primary DC in VMC cloud is ready for use 😊&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;]]&gt;&lt;/content:encoded&gt;&lt;/item&gt;&lt;item&gt;&lt;title&gt;Connect Onprem Datacenter to VMware Cloud on AWS (via IPsec VPN ) Part-2&lt;/title&gt;&lt;description&gt;&lt;![CDATA[By default all incoming communications are blocked by the SDDC firewall and to access the vCenter you should at least open port 443 towards vCenter.in order to open a firewall rule :1) Login to vmc.vmware.com2) select the sddc 3) go to network tab 4) In the management Gateway section expand firewall rule and select add ruleFill in the details as below in source section you can type the subnet of your onprem management machines, or type "Any" to access the vCenter from anywhere.Similar way you&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_56b5b990c23742ebbd18ee0dc54ae050%7Emv2.jpg/v1/fill/w_546%2Ch_48/165892_56b5b990c23742ebbd18ee0dc54ae050%7Emv2.jpg"/&gt;]]&gt;&lt;/description&gt;&lt;dc:creator&gt;Atul Srivastava&lt;/dc:creator&gt;&lt;link&gt;https://www.virtualramp.net/single-post/2018/04/23/Connect-the-Onprem-to-VMC-IPsec-VPN-Part-2&lt;/link&gt;&lt;guid&gt;https://www.virtualramp.net/single-post/2018/04/23/Connect-the-Onprem-to-VMC-IPsec-VPN-Part-2&lt;/guid&gt;&lt;pubDate&gt;Mon, 23 Apr 2018 08:53:30 +0000&lt;/pubDate&gt;&lt;content:encoded&gt;&lt;![CDATA[&lt;div&gt;&lt;div&gt;By default all incoming communications are blocked by the SDDC firewall and to access the vCenter you should at least open port 443 towards vCenter.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;in order to open a firewall rule :&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;1) Login to vmc.vmware.com&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;2) select the sddc &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;3) go to network tab &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;4) In the management Gateway section expand firewall rule and select add rule&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Fill in the details as below &lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_56b5b990c23742ebbd18ee0dc54ae050~mv2.jpg"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;in source section you can type the subnet of your onprem management machines, or type &amp;quot;Any&amp;quot; to access the vCenter from anywhere.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Similar way you can open an ICMP traffic for vCenter as well.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;now we will start with the actual IPsec configuration and as I mentioned earlier in Part-1 that I am using a pfsense router, I will configure my ipsec on that however you can use any other vendor/hardware router which can support IPSEC VPN or NSX to configure this .&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;The configuration is very simple and VMware has provided a specific list of Phase-1 and Phase-2 supported settings for onprem ipsec vpn to avoid any kind of error.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_2aebbe889bbe4da893d1a17fde7afe12~mv2.jpg"/&gt;&lt;div&gt; Lets configure it on the pfsense first &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;open the management page of the pfsense appliance (default username : admin, default password : pfsense) and selected IPSEC from VPN menu at the top.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;in the Tunnels tab clicked on &amp;quot;+ Add P1&amp;quot; button at the bottom.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_0c7833af59a842979bbc158fc7e42a56~mv2.jpg"/&gt;&lt;div&gt; Only fill the details which are highlighted here. Remote gateway is the public IP of the vmc management gateway, you can get that from the network diagram of network tab in vmc.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_4cf74bd84774475f9bc024d76ef838db~mv2.jpg"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;you should type in a pre-shared key in Pre-shared key section and make a note of it. rest everything you can keep as default.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;once you click on Save it will give you an option to edit phase 2 settings.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;In Phase 2 edit the following parameters&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Remote Network - which is the VMC management network in my case it is 10.0.0.0/16 (Default)Local Network - it is your onprem Management network in my case 192.168.10.0/24 (refer my network diagram in Part-1)&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Encryption Algorithm - AES and 256 bits (configurable, but make sure to match it on the VMC side)Has Algorithm - SHA1PFS key group - 2 (configurable, but make sure to match it on the VMC side)Lifetime - 3600 (default)&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_78dec26b11654d07899243e6cbef5d61~mv2.jpg"/&gt;&lt;div&gt; Click Save and you are done with the onprem side configuration.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Let's switch to the vmc side &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;and open desired sddc and select network tab, in the vpn section of management gateway, click create vpn.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Fill in the details to match with the onprem settings.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Remote Gateway Public IP - This is the public IP Address of on-prem Gateway.Remote gateway private IP - This is the public IP of your pfsense (this is not required if the router on which you have configured ipsec at your onprem is public facing, since in my case I have set it up behind an ISP router I am using this option)Remote Networks - This is your on-prem private network that you want to be allowed over the VPN.Diffie Hellman - Default is 2 on pfSense, so you will need to adjust this on VMC (configurable, but make sure to match it with the on-prem side)Pre-shared key - This is the shared key that you had created in Step 2 and made a note.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_6022e7707d5f48a98e30b16b37217087~mv2.jpg"/&gt;&lt;div&gt; And if everything goes well , the ipsec vpn will show as connected and will indicate it with a green dot.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Note : if the vpn connection is not getting connected automatically go to the pfsense page on your onprem side and click status at the top, select ipsec and click connect, it should change in to established state, once vpn is established refresh the ipsec vpn at VMC end by clicking the refresh button next to the name of ipsec vpn.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;once everything is done, to open the vmc vCenter page from your on-prem machine using ip-sec tunnel there are 2 ways.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;1) Using Private IP&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Get the private IP of your vmc vCenter : you can do it by logging in to vmc.vmware.com select the sddc click on support tab and at the bottom you can find the private IP, you can use this ip to open vCenter page from your onprem machine.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;2) Using FQDN (There are two steps involved in this)&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; a) update the onprem DNS with the private IP of vmc&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; vCenter.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; b) Update the DNS ip in the vmc sddc page to your &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; onprem dns. you can do it by logging in to &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; vmc.vmware.com select the sddc, click on network &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; tab and expand DNS section in Management&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; Gateway ,click on Edit and type in your on-prem&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; DNS address in DNS 1.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Okay so we are all set now and you can start using your vmc vCenter from any of your onprem machine whose subnet is allowed in the remote network list of VPN.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;]]&gt;&lt;/content:encoded&gt;&lt;/item&gt;&lt;item&gt;&lt;title&gt;Connect Onprem Datacenter to VMware Cloud on AWS(IPsec VPN ) &nbsp;Part-1&lt;/title&gt;&lt;description&gt;&lt;![CDATA[Today we will talk about how you can connect your on-prem management components to VMC Management components .. the use cases are setting up HLM or accessing your vmc vCenter from private network (more security) instead of resolving the url on public IP. To accomplish the above we can setup an ipsec VPN tunnel between your on-prem ipsec router with the vmc gateway.every data-center is a different environment with different components and connections 13 Apr 2018 08:24:00 +0000&lt;/pubDate&gt;&lt;content:encoded&gt;&lt;![CDATA[&lt;div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Today we will talk about how you can connect your on-prem management components to VMC Management components .. the use cases are setting up HLM or accessing your vmc vCenter from private network (more security) instead of resolving the url on public IP. &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;To accomplish the above we can setup an ipsec VPN tunnel between your on-prem ipsec router with the vmc gateway.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;every data-center is a different environment with different components and connections however the basics always remains the same, to demonstrate IPsec vpn connectivity I am using my home-lab as onprem data-center, and before proceeding further let's understand how my setup looks like.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;I have a T7600 workstation server where I have installed windows 7 and on top of that VMware workstation 14 is running. all my management components like my Esxi, vCenter VCSA, openfiler are installed in VMware workstation, along with these I have installed a community edition of pfsense virtual router appliance. and I have connected the pfsense to my ISP router directly with bridging network card option of VMware workstation. hence pfsense virtual applinace is getting IP directly from my ISP router.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Moreover you can also use nsx as well for ipsec vpn and connect the nsx edge directly to you ISP router.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Here is a representation of my setup :&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_d82d38a97b73483c9d656c99142100ca~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;On-prem Firewall – If the on-premises gateway is behind another firewall or if the device itself is performing a firewall function, then allow the following traffic types from VMware Cloud on AWS gateways to pass through the firewall:&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Open UDP port 500 to allow ISAKMP trafficSet IP protocol ID 50 to allow IPsec ESP trafficOpen UDP port 4500 if using NAT-T&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;These are the prerequisites, Lets continue the actual configuration in &lt;a href="http://www.virtualramp.net/single-post/2018/04/23/Connect-the-Onprem-to-VMC-IPsec-VPN-Part-2"&gt;part-2&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;]]&gt;&lt;/content:encoded&gt;&lt;/item&gt;&lt;item&gt;&lt;title&gt;VMware 10 Mar 2018 04:13:00 +0000&lt;/pubDate&gt;&lt;content:encoded&gt;&lt;![CDATA[&lt;div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Once the SDDC is deployed you will find the SDDC details in your org page under SDDCs section. you with (In the picture above it shows 1 host .. Yes ! it's now possible to deploy your SDDC with 1 Node. but obviously it is only for testing not production), Its AWS region and Availability zone.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;we will discuss about the other tabs in future blogs one by one, now lets see how can we open the vCenter.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;you can do it in two ways &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;1) From the org page click open vCenter on any of the SDDC.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;2) You can get vCenter url for accessing it from public (internet) in connections tab of specific sddc. (Remember that we can make the resolution of this url to private as well so if you don't want your vCenter to be available in public).&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;The username for logging in to the vcenter is <span class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="63000f0c160702070e0a0d23150e004d0f0c00020f">[email&#160;protected]</span> and there is a password which is hidden by default.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;you get that on connections info tab or when you click on open vCenter link&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_bf84adf1ac3b47e396768c4d8dd96690~mv2.jpg"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;And finally here is the vCenter and you are ready to start spinning up your vms in vmware cloud on aws.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_7cbb3f52e9b9494ab4663f9e546cf9ad~mv2.jpg"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;About the environment:&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;# You will find 1 cluster and 2 resource pool by default&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;# The Management-resource pool is, where all the management components reside (vcsa, nsx etc.)&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;# You are not allowed to do anything in management-resource pool (it is maintained and managed by vmware).&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;# You can create vms in compute-resource pool.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;# By default there are 2 datastores which gets created &lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_92c003b3707548f3a8d5a020f5b90a63~mv2.jpg"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;The vsanDatastore is again for management components. &amp;amp; the workloadDatastore is for storing your workload vms.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;# These datastore is fully backed-up by vmware vSAN.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;# If we talk about network, only Management network is created along with 1 default Logical network for compute, you can further create logical networks as per your usage and requirements, by clicking Menu &amp;gt; Global inventory list &amp;gt; Logical networks and add.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;That's all for vCenter rest everyting is similar to your traditional vCenter.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;And yes do not forget to check the esxi version in your vmc html client :) .&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_c465428f1ae944259c1ffc955e81fbbb~mv2.jpg"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;All these Esxis are hosted on physical box in Amazon datacenter, also if at any point of time one of the esxi becomes unresponsive or crashes, a new esxi will automatically gets added to your cluster.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Let's continue to explore some more exciting stuffs in VMC on AWS in future blogs.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;]]&gt;&lt;/content:encoded&gt;&lt;/item&gt;&lt;item&gt;&lt;title&gt;Day-4 Deploy SDDC&lt;/title&gt;&lt;description&gt;&lt;![CDATA[And today we are going to deploy our first SDDC :)For seamless deployment of the SDDC its important that we should do some homework firstPrerequisites :# Ensure you have an AWS account before you create an SDDC# You will have to create subnets with atleast 64 Ips (/26)# The subnet should be in the same AWS Region where you are planning to deploy the SDDC# Its important that you create Subnets in each availability zone in your VPC# As mentioned earlier 192.168.1.0/24 should not be overlapped by&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_bcf8c3418a0145309c89e0038424d54a%7Emv2.png/v1/fill/w_546%2Ch_45/165892_bcf8c3418a0145309c89e0038424d54a%7Emv2.png"/&gt;]]&gt;&lt;/description&gt;&lt;link&gt;https://www.virtualramp.net/single-post/2018/03/04/Day-4-Creating-SDDC&lt;/link&gt;&lt;guid&gt;https://www.virtualramp.net/single-post/2018/03/04/Day-4-Creating-SDDC&lt;/guid&gt;&lt;pubDate&gt;Sun, 04 Mar 2018 06:03:00 +0000&lt;/pubDate&gt;&lt;content:encoded&gt;&lt;![CDATA[&lt;div&gt;&lt;div&gt;And today we are going to deploy our first SDDC :)&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;For seamless deployment of the SDDC its important that we should do some homework first&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Prerequisites :&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;# Ensure you have an AWS account before you create an SDDC&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;# You will have to create subnets with atleast 64 Ips (/26)&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;# The subnet should be in the same AWS Region where you are planning to deploy the SDDC&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;# Its important that you create Subnets in each availability zone in your VPC&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;# As mentioned earlier 192.168.1.0/24 should not be overlapped by the IP range of these subnets.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;# 192.168.1.0 is reserved for Default Compute gateway logical network&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; Log in to the VMC Console at https://vmc.vmware.com. Click Create SDDC.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_bcf8c3418a0145309c89e0038424d54a~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;3. From Connect to an AWS account Dropdown either select an existing account (This should not be already in use by any other SDDC .. SDDCs have one to one mapping with AWS account and vpc.)&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;If the account is not mentioned in the list you can choose connect to a new AWS account.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_331ed2ebbc1240d190a786da8a8969c7~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;VMware has defined a CloudFormation template to connect an AWS account. This template creates the IAM roles necessary to allow communication between your SDDC and your AWS account.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Once the connection is successfully established you get :&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_39077abc6b2445258dd767b53840d320~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;4. Configure SDDC properties.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Enter a name for your SDDC.Select the number of hosts in the SDDC.Select the AWS region in which to deploy the SDDC (Same region where you created your subnets)&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_7d8b64c25a1c4daaa060c4509c817449~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;5 Select a VPC and a subnet in your AWS account to connect to.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_afd98bf5bf4f4ff99948bc41bb0ffc32~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;Click Next&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;6. Enter an IP address range for the management network as a CIDR block or leave the text box blank&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;to use the default, which is 10.0.0.0/16.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;You can't change the values specified for the management network after the SDDC has been created.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Consider the following when you specify this address range:&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;The IP address range 192.168.1.0/24 is reserved for the default compute gateway logical network of the SDDC you are deploying. If you specify a management network address range that overlaps with 192.168.1.0/24, no default compute gateway logical network is created during deployment and you will have to create one manually after the SDDC is deployed.Only CIDR blocks of size /16, /20, or /23 are supported.Choose a range of IP addresses that does not overlap with the AWS subnet you are connecting to. If you plan to connect your SDDC to an on-premises data center, the IP addresses you choose must be different from the ones in your on-premises data center, to avoid IP address conflicts.The maximum number of hosts your SDDC can contain depends on the size of the CIDR block you specify. If the CIDR block is in the form XXX.XXX.XXX.XXX/YY, then the maximum number of hosts the SDDC can contain is (2 ^(27 - YY)) - 3. The table shows the number of hosts based on the value of YY.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Click on Create SDDC, This will initiate the SDDC creation and will configure all the Management components for you. this process may take 2-6 Hours to complete.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;and once this is completed you will see a new sddc in your vmc org page.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_47c1d38d85a348d9afbe05f1bf4757cb~mv2.jpg"/&gt;&lt;/div&gt;]]&gt;&lt;/content:encoded&gt;&lt;/item&gt;&lt;item&gt;&lt;title&gt;Day-3 VMware cloud on AWS &nbsp;SDDC (Software-Defined Data center) an Overview&lt;/title&gt;&lt;description&gt;&lt;![CDATA[The first and very basic step for start using VMC on AWS is to create an SDDC. Once that is done you will be able to do multiple tasks with your SDDC and start using your VMC cloud vCenter (this is just the first step).When you deploy an SDDC on VMware Cloud on AWS, it is created within an AWS account and VPC dedicated to your organization and managed by VMware. You must also connect the SDDC to an AWS account belonging to you, referred to as the customer AWS account. This connection allows your&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_04148e5405a14f3292db20e8111e7efc%7Emv2.png/v1/fill/w_546%2Ch_242/165892_04148e5405a14f3292db20e8111e7efc%7Emv2.png"/&gt;]]&gt;&lt;/description&gt;&lt;link&gt;https://www.virtualramp.net/single-post/2018/03/04/Day-3-VMC-SDDC-Software-Defined-Data-center-an-Overview&lt;/link&gt;&lt;guid&gt;https://www.virtualramp.net/single-post/2018/03/04/Day-3-VMC-SDDC-Software-Defined-Data-center-an-Overview&lt;/guid&gt;&lt;pubDate&gt;Sun, 04 Mar 2018 04:51:00 +0000&lt;/pubDate&gt;&lt;content:encoded&gt;&lt;![CDATA[&lt;div&gt;&lt;div&gt;The first and very basic step for start using VMC on AWS is to create an SDDC. Once that is done you will be able to do multiple tasks with your SDDC and start using your VMC cloud vCenter (this is just the first step).&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;When you deploy an SDDC on VMware Cloud on AWS,&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;it is created within an AWS account and VPC dedicated to your organization and managed by VMware.You must also connect the SDDC to an AWS account belonging to you, referred to as the customer AWS account. This connection allows your SDDC to access AWS services belonging to your customer account.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Now let's understand the basic topology of VMC SDDC&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_04148e5405a14f3292db20e8111e7efc~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;Management network &amp;amp; Management resource pool : This is used for SDDC's management components Like Esxis, vCenter VM, NSX components (Customers will not have any or very limited control over these components. These are entirely managed by Vmware)&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Compute Network &amp;amp; Compute resource pool : This is will be used by compute VMs which user/customer will create by accessing VMC vCenter through HTML client(Customers will have maximum control on this).&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Gateways:&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Management Gateway (MGW): &nbsp;This is nothing but an NSX Edge Gateway instance which has a Public IP assigned (from AWS Public IP address pool) and internally connected to your Management component's network. This will provide outside world (North-south) connectivity to your management components Like vCenter and NSX Manage. You can assign a network address block for the internal communication of Management components while creating the SDDC (Remember this should be an existing network in your environment that you are planning to connect to the VMC SDDC Later.)&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Compute Gateway (CWG): This is an NSX Edge Gateway for North-south connectivity of compute resources (Virtual Machines) by default a default logical network is already there however you can create new logical networks once SDDC is deployed and you have access to vCenter. This Default logical network will use IP address of Range 192.168.1.0/24.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;]]&gt;&lt;/content:encoded&gt;&lt;/item&gt;&lt;item&gt;&lt;title&gt;Day-2 Let's work !&lt;/title&gt;&lt;description&gt;&lt;![CDATA[Once you receive the invite from vmware then you setup your org, create a myvmware account (or linked the existing one) after that you can invite other users and make them org user or org admin (The only difference is org admin can invite other users)Once this is done you create a subscription for you based on your requirement for number of host (The number of host cannot be more than the maximum allowed for your organization)Steps to create a subscription1 - Log in to the VMC Console at&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_3a0a5fb549264648a28ca20155782722%7Emv2.png/v1/fill/w_439%2Ch_45/165892_3a0a5fb549264648a28ca20155782722%7Emv2.png"/&gt;]]&gt;&lt;/description&gt;&lt;dc:creator&gt;Atul Srivastava&lt;/dc:creator&gt;&lt;link&gt;https://www.virtualramp.net/single-post/2018/03/03/Day-2-Getting-Started&lt;/link&gt;&lt;guid&gt;https://www.virtualramp.net/single-post/2018/03/03/Day-2-Getting-Started&lt;/guid&gt;&lt;pubDate&gt;Sat, 03 Mar 2018 04:43:00 +0000&lt;/pubDate&gt;&lt;content:encoded&gt;&lt;![CDATA[&lt;div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Once you receive the invite from vmware then you setup your org, create a myvmware account (or linked the existing one) after that you can invite other users and make them org user or org admin (The only difference is org admin can invite other users)&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Once this is done you create a subscription for you based on your requirement for number of host (The number of host cannot be more than the maximum allowed for your organization)&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Steps to create a subscription&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;1 - Log in to the VMC Console at https://vmc.vmware.com.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;2 - Click Subscriptions.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_3a0a5fb549264648a28ca20155782722~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;3 - Click Create Subscription.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_6c4e3dc2a66b4788b09edbd598910767~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;4 - Select the number of hosts you want as part of the subscription.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;The total number of subscribed hosts cannot be more than the maximum allowed for your organization.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;5 - Select the region for these hosts and click Next Step.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_d3a211b6e0b34e0d81d0846f7c15a451~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;6 - Select a subscription period and click Next Step.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_bab177e3c6ca4ba586a8c5afddf2d941~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;The VMC Console shows the cost to and the discount compared to on-demand pricing for each subscription period.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;7 - Review the summary and click Place Order.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_72ec9fcd686d4aba89bdd455a3e6f77e~mv2.png"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;Once this is done you will receive an e-mail notification indicating that your subscription order is received and once the order is processed the next email will come in as if the subscription is successful or failed.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;]]&gt;&lt;/content:encoded&gt;&lt;/item&gt;&lt;item&gt;&lt;title&gt;Day -1 with VMware Cloud on AWS&lt;/title&gt;&lt;description&gt;&lt;![CDATA[Alright, so now we know, what VMC on AWS has to offer us .. Let's get started with Day 1 !First of all you will contact VMware Sales team and choose the subscription from different plans available here.https://cloud.vmware.com/vmc-aws/pricingOne of the best part of this solution is that you are getting dedicated hosts &amp; each host has 2 CPUs, 36 cores, 512GB RAM, NVMe attached flash storage (3.6 TB cache plus 10.7 TB raw capacity tier). Minimum required configuration is 3 hosts per cluster (as of&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/0c18e850e6e449c5a81de48680742097.jpg"/&gt;]]&gt;&lt;/description&gt;&lt;dc:creator&gt;Atul Srivastava&lt;/dc:creator&gt;&lt;link&gt;https://www.virtualramp.net/single-post/2018/02/26/Day--1-with-VMC-on-AWS&lt;/link&gt;&lt;guid&gt;https://www.virtualramp.net/single-post/2018/02/26/Day--1-with-VMC-on-AWS&lt;/guid&gt;&lt;pubDate&gt;Sun, 04 Feb 2018 04:44:00 +0000&lt;/pubDate&gt;&lt;content:encoded&gt;&lt;![CDATA[&lt;div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/0c18e850e6e449c5a81de48680742097.jpg"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;Alright, so now we know, what VMC on AWS has to offer us .. Let's get started with Day 1 !&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;First of all you will contact VMware Sales team and choose the subscription from different plans available here.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;a href="https://cloud.vmware.com/vmc-aws/pricing"&gt;https://cloud.vmware.com/vmc-aws/pricing&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;One of the best part of this solution is that you are getting dedicated hosts &amp;amp; each host has 2 CPUs, 36 cores, 512GB RAM, NVMe attached flash storage (3.6 TB cache plus 10.7 TB raw capacity tier). Minimum required configuration is 3 hosts per cluster (as of now) VMware has plans to facilitate one node cluster in future so that testing of the solution will be easy and cost effective (there is an HOL available if you want to give it a try however it is limited to the SDDC view only, you will not be able to use the vCenter link).&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;VMware has listed a Pricing calculator as well so that it will be easy for someone who is looking for TCO based on his requirement.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;a href="https://cloud.vmware.com/vmc-aws-pricing"&gt;https://cloud.vmware.com/vmc-aws-pricing&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Ok so coming back to day 1 now, once you contact the sales they will setup the account for you and you will receive an e-mail invitation containing a link that you can use to sign up for VMware Cloud on AWS account. (This link can be used only once.)&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;When you sign up for the service, an Organization is created with an Organization ID and Organization Name. You are designated as the Organization Owner and can invite other users in your organization to use the service.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Lets understand what an organization or org is &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;VMware Cloud on AWS accounts are based on an Organization, which corresponds to a group or line of business subscribed to VMware Cloud on AWS service, you can further create your SDDCs in this organization . Remember that the VMware Cloud on AWS Organizations that you create or are a member of has no relationship to AWS Organizations.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;By default the first user is always an organization owner who has access to all the resources of the Org. this user can further invite other users and assign them roles as Org Owner or Org Users (By default only org owner can invite other users).&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;If you have a My VMware account, you can use it to create an Organization Owner account after you receive the invitation email. If you don't have a My VMware account, you are prompted to create one during account creation. (if you are using an existing account make sure you update your profile correctly missing information in profile may lead to an error.)&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;steps to invite other users &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;1- Log in to the VMC Console at https://vmc.vmware.com.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;2- Click the services icon ( ) at the top right of the window, and select Identity and Access Management. You see a list&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; of all the users currently in your organization.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;3- Click Add Users.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;4- Enter an email address for each user you want to add, separated by a comma, space, or a new line.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;5- Select the role to assign. n Organization Owner. n Organization Member.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;6- Click Add&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Once users receive the invite from org owner they can accept the invite and create their account for VMC on AWS.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;]]&gt;&lt;/content:encoded&gt;&lt;/item&gt;&lt;item&gt;&lt;title&gt;Getting started with VMware Cloud on AWS&lt;/title&gt;&lt;description&gt;&lt;![CDATA[VMware Cloud on AWS is an on-demand service that enables you to run applications across vSphere-based cloud environments with access to a broad range of AWS services. Powered by VMware Cloud Foundation, this service integrates vSphere, vSAN and NSX along with VMware vCenter management, and is optimized to run on dedicated, elastic, bare-metal AWS infrastructure (Source: Vmware official website)So what is there from VMware and what AWS is providing ?1) AWS is providing a dedicated infrastructure&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_f63e3361a7d84b9bb8a9180aa4bd49a1%7Emv2.jpg/v1/fill/w_732%2Ch_283/165892_f63e3361a7d84b9bb8a9180aa4bd49a1%7Emv2.jpg"/&gt;]]&gt;&lt;/description&gt;&lt;dc:creator&gt;Atul Srivastava&lt;/dc:creator&gt;&lt;link&gt;https://www.virtualramp.net/single-post/2018/02/03/Getting-started-with-VMware-Cloud-on-AWS&lt;/link&gt;&lt;guid&gt;https://www.virtualramp.net/single-post/2018/02/03/Getting-started-with-VMware-Cloud-on-AWS&lt;/guid&gt;&lt;pubDate&gt;Sat, 03 Feb 2018 04:14:00 +0000&lt;/pubDate&gt;&lt;content:encoded&gt;&lt;![CDATA[&lt;div&gt;&lt;div&gt;VMware Cloud on AWS is an on-demand service that enables you to run applications across vSphere-based cloud environments with access to a broad range of AWS services. Powered by VMware Cloud Foundation, this service integrates vSphere, vSAN and NSX along with VMware vCenter management, and is optimized to run on dedicated, elastic, bare-metal AWS infrastructure (Source: Vmware official website)&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://static.wixstatic.com/media/165892_f63e3361a7d84b9bb8a9180aa4bd49a1~mv2.jpg"/&gt;&lt;div&gt;So what is there from VMware and what AWS is providing ?&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;1) AWS is providing a dedicated infrastructure for this service to run all the VMware SDDC Stack (vSphere, NSX, &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; vSAN)&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;2) All the VMC management components are managed and maintained by VMware.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;3) VMware is responsible for billing of all the VMC components.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;4) Regular updates for SDDC components (NSX, vCenter etc.) is managed by VMware.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;5) VMware cloud portal is the single place to deploy or manage the services (https://vmc.vmware.com)&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Some Highlights:&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;You can use this solution as a standalone vSphere environment on AWS hardware or you can connect you on-prem vCenter and SSO to VMC vCenter with HLM (Hybrid Linked Mode).&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Also if you need to connect VMs in your SDDC with resources in an Amazon VPC that isn't connected to your account using a cross-VPC ENI, you can create a VPN connection between your compute gateway and that VPC.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Site recovery manager is now available with VMC on AWS to protect your on-prem VMs to cloud (DRaaS), which makes it easy to protect your VMs in AWS datacenter using VMC on AWS.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;This is only a beginning VMware is continuously working to add more components , features to this solution. and there is a long way to go......&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;A good place to start with VMC on AWS is the faq page &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;https://cloud.vmware.com/vmc-aws/faq&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;]]&gt;&lt;/content:encoded&gt;&lt;/item&gt;&lt;/channel&gt;&lt;/rss&gt;</code></a></li>

<li><a name="l4066" id="l4066"><code class="a"> &nbsp;&amp;lt;p&amp;gt;“&amp;lt;em&amp;gt;&amp;lt;strong&amp;gt;Object Storage&amp;lt;/strong&amp;gt; (also known as object-based storage&amp;lt;sup id=&amp;quot;cite_ref-1&amp;quot; class=&amp;quot;reference&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Object_storage#cite_note-1&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/sup&amp;gt;) is a storage architecture that manages data as objects, as opposed to other storage architectures like &amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File_systems&amp;quot; title=&amp;quot;File systems&amp;quot;&amp;gt;file systems&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; which manage data as a file hierarchy and &amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Block_storage&amp;quot; title=&amp;quot;Block storage&amp;quot;&amp;gt;block storage&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; which manages data as blocks within sectors and tracks.&amp;lt;/em&amp;gt;” &amp;lt;sub&amp;gt;&amp;lt;em&amp;gt;Source: &amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Object_storage&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;strong&amp;gt;Wikipedia-en&amp;lt;/strong&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/em&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/sub&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/p&amp;gt;</code></a></li>
