<li><a name="l1" id="l1"><code class="b">&lt;?xml version='1.0' encoding='UTF-8'?&gt;&lt;?xml-stylesheet href="http://www.blogger.com/styles/atom.css" type="text/css"?&gt;&lt;feed xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2005/Atom' xmlns:openSearch='http://a9.com/-/spec/opensearchrss/1.0/' xmlns:blogger='http://schemas.google.com/blogger/2008' xmlns:georss='http://www.georss.org/georss' xmlns:gd="http://schemas.google.com/g/2005" xmlns:thr='http://purl.org/syndication/thread/1.0'&gt;&lt;id&gt;tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-3947691530317823276&lt;/id&gt;&lt;updated&gt;2020-02-26T18:32:10.848-08:00&lt;/updated&gt;&lt;category term="NetApp"/&gt;&lt;category term="Blogtober"/&gt;&lt;category term="Blogtober2018"/&gt;&lt;category term="Kubernetes"/&gt;&lt;title type='text'&gt;A blog about virtualization, storage, networking, and more!&lt;/title&gt;&lt;subtitle type='html'&gt;&lt;/subtitle&gt;&lt;link rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#feed' type='application/atom+xml' href='https://www.langhq.com/feeds/posts/default'/&gt;&lt;link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='https://www.blogger.com/feeds/3947691530317823276/posts/default'/&gt;&lt;link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='https://www.langhq.com/'/&gt;&lt;link rel='hub' href='http://pubsubhubbub.appspot.com/'/&gt;&lt;author&gt;&lt;name&gt;Donny Lang&lt;/name&gt;&lt;uri&gt;http://www.blogger.com/profile/04332684287885880604&lt;/uri&gt;&lt;email&gt;<span class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="afc1c0ddcadfc3d6efcdc3c0c8c8cadd81ccc0c2">[email&#160;protected]</span>&lt;/email&gt;&lt;gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='32' height='32' src='//1.bp.blogspot.com/-JafglNogKoE/WsfNRWPGLRI/AAAAAAAAOwA/ct7A0f4IRrMkD4AQSqkjb4FXdWMmsSSYgCK4BGAYYCw/s49/2018-04-06%2B14_39_55-Donny%2BLang%2B%2528%2540DonnyLang1%2529%2B_%2BTwitter.png'/&gt;&lt;/author&gt;&lt;generator version='7.00' uri='http://www.blogger.com'&gt;Blogger&lt;/generator&gt;&lt;openSearch:totalResults&gt;19&lt;/openSearch:totalResults&gt;&lt;openSearch:startIndex&gt;1&lt;/openSearch:startIndex&gt;&lt;openSearch:itemsPerPage&gt;25&lt;/openSearch:itemsPerPage&gt;&lt;entry&gt;&lt;id&gt;tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-3947691530317823276.post-1865142070319190328&lt;/id&gt;&lt;published&gt;2019-06-28T05:54:00.000-07:00&lt;/published&gt;&lt;updated&gt;2019-06-28T05:54:54.188-07:00&lt;/updated&gt;&lt;title type='text'&gt;NetApp E-Series Automation with the SANtricity PowerShell Toolkit&lt;/title&gt;&lt;content type='html'&gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-t7InqMs20vw/XRVe-FUP0iI/AAAAAAAAZoI/rJuEZmqxWJgiOEWWQTILOd4HH2bpwEJlwCLcBGAs/s1600/Untitled.png&amp;quot; imageanchor=&amp;quot;1&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;img border=&amp;quot;0&amp;quot; data-original-height=&amp;quot;91&amp;quot; data-original-width=&amp;quot;343&amp;quot; height=&amp;quot;105&amp;quot; src=&amp;quot;https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-t7InqMs20vw/XRVe-FUP0iI/AAAAAAAAZoI/rJuEZmqxWJgiOEWWQTILOd4HH2bpwEJlwCLcBGAs/s400/Untitled.png&amp;quot; width=&amp;quot;400&amp;quot; /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;I have a project coming up pretty soon that will require the deployment of multiple E-Series arrays whose configurations are likely going to be very similar if not identical, and I thought &amp;quot;I&amp;#39;m lazy, I don&amp;#39;t want to do this manually, let&amp;#39;s automate it&amp;quot;! I had seen that there were SANtricity (the operating system that runs on the E-Series arrays) cmdlets, about 300 of them in total, included with the NetApp PowerShell Toolkit, so I started digging in and taking a look. During my investigation, I didn&amp;#39;t find a whole lot of end-to-end &amp;quot;how-to&amp;quot;s out there on the Internet, so I am creating my own to share with you!&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;Note: Prior to getting started, I am going to make the assumption that you have:&amp;amp;nbsp;&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;- The NetApp PowerShell Toolkit downloaded and installed (I am using version 9.6)&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;- A Windows or Linux server to install the Web Services Proxy&amp;amp;nbsp;&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;- An E-Series array. I have an E5600, which does not have the embedded Web Services Proxy like the newer arrays (E2700,E2800,EF280, etc.) do. If you have one of those new-fangled models, you can skip directly to step 3.&amp;amp;nbsp;&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;1. Start by opening up your PowerShell window and importing the SANtricity module:&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;pre class=&amp;quot;brush:powershell&amp;quot;&amp;gt;(get-help *-ne* | Where-Object &amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;{$_.ModuleName -eq &amp;quot;NetApp.SANtricity.PowerShell&amp;quot;})&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/pre&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;Side note: Get-Help is your best friend when you&amp;#39;re exploring a new PowerShell module - it&amp;#39;ll tell you everything you need to know about syntax, accepted parameters - and even give you examples!&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;2. Download and install the Web Services Proxy&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;The Web Services Proxy acts as the middle layer between your client (in this case, PowerShell) and the array by taking your PS commands and translating them to API calls, which are sent to the array by the Web Services Proxy.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;Hit the link below to download the Proxy from NetApp&amp;#39;s support site (as of this writing, 3.2 is the latest version):&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://mysupport.netapp.com/products/eseries_webservices/3.2/downloads.html&amp;quot;&amp;gt;Web Services Proxy 3.2&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;Choose the installer that fits your operating system type, accept the license agreement, and the download will start. Once finished, you can run the installer to install it on your server of choice. It&amp;#39;s a very straight-forward installation process, but there is full documentation available at&amp;amp;nbsp;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://library.netapp.com/ecm/ecm_download_file/ECMLP2846165&amp;quot;&amp;gt;https://library.netapp.com/ecm/ecm_download_file/ECMLP2846165&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; as well.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;3. Create credential object with PowerShell&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;Back in your PowerShell window, create a new credential object with the &amp;quot;New-NeCredential&amp;quot; cmdlet, using the appropriate Web Services Proxy credentials:&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;pre class=&amp;quot;brush:powershell&amp;quot;&amp;gt;$NeCredential = New-NeCredential &amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;-ProxyUrl https://&amp;amp;lt;server&amp;amp;gt;:8443/devmgr &amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;-SystemCredential (Get-Credential)&amp;lt;/pre&amp;gt;It is important to note that the default administrative user name and password for the Web Services Proxy is admin/admin, which is okay for my lab environment, but decidedly not okay for production deployments. The Web Services Proxy supports role-based access control with local authentication (stored as salted SHA256 hashes in a configuration file), HTTP Basic Auth, or LDAP. See page 8 of the &amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://library.netapp.com/ecm/ecm_download_file/ECMLP2846166&amp;quot;&amp;gt;Web Services Proxy User Guide&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; for detailed information on how to set up these various authentication methods.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;4. Add Storage System to PowerShell session&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;Once you have a proper credential object stored in the $NeCredential variable, you can create the &amp;quot;NeStorageSystem&amp;quot; object that you&amp;#39;ll be interacting with.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;pre class=&amp;quot;brush:powershell&amp;quot;&amp;gt;New-NeStorageSystem -Credential $NeCredential&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;-Id 1 -ControllerAddresses &amp;amp;lt;mgmt_interface&amp;amp;gt;&amp;lt;/pre&amp;gt;If the command completes without error, you can validate that you are connected successfully by running the &amp;quot;Get-NeStorageSystem&amp;quot; command. You&amp;#39;ll see output like this (I trimmed it a bit for length):&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;pre class=&amp;quot;brush:powershell&amp;quot;&amp;gt;Id&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;: 1&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;Name&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;: lab-e5600-01&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;Wwn&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; : 60080E500043CEC11000000057B367CE&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;PasswordStatus&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;: valid&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;PasswordSet&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; : False&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;Status&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;: optimal&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;CertificateStatus&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; : unknown&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;Ip1&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; : 192.168.1.5&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;Ip2&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; : 192.168.1.6&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;ManagementPaths&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; : {192.168.1.5, 192.168.1.6}&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;Controllers&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; : {class DiscoveredController {&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;ControllerId: 070000000000000000000001&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;IpAddresses: System.Collections.Generic.List`1[System.String]&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;CertificateStatus: unknown&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;}&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;, class DiscoveredController {&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;ControllerId: 070000000000000000000002&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;IpAddresses: System.Collections.Generic.List`1[System.String]&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;CertificateStatus: unknown&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/pre&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;If you see output like this, you are successfully running commands against your array and ready to run any of the 300 cmdlets that are in the Toolkit. For many of them, you&amp;#39;ll just need to reference the SystemId (set to &amp;quot;1&amp;quot; in this example).&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;I&amp;#39;m planning on writing another couple of short posts soon to share some Pester tests to validate E-Series health and configuration (a follow-up on my ONTAP Pester tests that I worked on last month - check that post out if you missed it) as well as a post to talk about end-to-end automated E-Series deployment with PowerShell. Thanks for reading!&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&lt;/content&gt;&lt;link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='https://www.blogger.com/feeds/3947691530317823276/posts/default/1865142070319190328'/&gt;&lt;link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='https://www.blogger.com/feeds/3947691530317823276/posts/default/1865142070319190328'/&gt;&lt;link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='https://www.langhq.com/2019/06/netapp-e-series-automation-with_28.html' title='NetApp E-Series Automation with the SANtricity PowerShell Toolkit'/&gt;&lt;author&gt;&lt;name&gt;Donny Lang&lt;/name&gt;&lt;uri&gt;http://www.blogger.com/profile/04332684287885880604&lt;/uri&gt;&lt;email&gt;<span class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="452b2a372035293c0527292a222220376b262a28">[email&#160;protected]</span>&lt;/email&gt;&lt;gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='32' height='32' src='//1.bp.blogspot.com/-JafglNogKoE/WsfNRWPGLRI/AAAAAAAAOwA/ct7A0f4IRrMkD4AQSqkjb4FXdWMmsSSYgCK4BGAYYCw/s49/2018-04-06%2B14_39_55-Donny%2BLang%2B%2528%2540DonnyLang1%2529%2B_%2BTwitter.png'/&gt;&lt;/author&gt;&lt;media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-t7InqMs20vw/XRVe-FUP0iI/AAAAAAAAZoI/rJuEZmqxWJgiOEWWQTILOd4HH2bpwEJlwCLcBGAs/s72-c/Untitled.png" height="72" width="72"/&gt;&lt;/entry&gt;&lt;entry&gt;&lt;id&gt;tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-3947691530317823276.post-5704596864395092630&lt;/id&gt;&lt;published&gt;2019-05-19T07:59:00.002-07:00&lt;/published&gt;&lt;updated&gt;2019-05-19T10:19:29.598-07:00&lt;/updated&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="NetApp"/&gt;&lt;title type='text'&gt;ONTAP Configuration Compliance Auditing with PowerShell and Pester&lt;/title&gt;&lt;content type='html'&gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-fV6u5DddcxE/XOFtRPBakTI/AAAAAAAAYdo/BraQ94Bkj-0h5-RaK0Ge1-6yACs4QDfMACLcBGAs/s1600/PowerShell_5.0_icon.png&amp;quot; imageanchor=&amp;quot;1&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;img border=&amp;quot;0&amp;quot; data-original-height=&amp;quot;229&amp;quot; data-original-width=&amp;quot;633&amp;quot; height=&amp;quot;230&amp;quot; src=&amp;quot;https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-fV6u5DddcxE/XOFtRPBakTI/AAAAAAAAYdo/BraQ94Bkj-0h5-RaK0Ge1-6yACs4QDfMACLcBGAs/s640/PowerShell_5.0_icon.png&amp;quot; width=&amp;quot;640&amp;quot; /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;I have been looking for a way to validate NetApp cluster configuration settings (once a configuration setting is set, I want to validate that it was set properly in a programmatic fashion) and prevent configuration drift (if a setting is different than its expected value, I want to know about it). I needed it to be able to scale out to dozens of clusters as well, so it needed to be something that I could run both automatically and on an ad-hoc basis if necessary.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;u&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-size: large;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;NetApp PowerShell Toolkit&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/u&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;The core of the solution is the NetApp PowerShell Toolkit, without which this would likely not be possible. It contains 2300+ cmdlets for provisioning and managing NetApp storage components. It can be downloaded from the ToolChest on the NetApp MySupport site (with a valid login). You&amp;#39;ll find exhaustive documentation there as well for each of the cmdlets along with syntax examples and sample code. It is a fantastic and easy way to automate common storage tasks - we use it in our environment for everything from creating new LIFs, volumes, and igroups to entire cluster deployments. I won&amp;#39;t cover its installation in great detail as it&amp;#39;s pretty straightforward - once installed it can be loaded into PowerShell using the &amp;quot;Import-Module DataONTAP&amp;quot; command. While the PS Toolkit is great for provisioning, my current use case was to test my cluster configuration against expected values (NetApp best practices or organization-specific configuration settings) and alert me of discrepencies. For that, we use Pester.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;u&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-size: large;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;Pester&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/u&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;Pester is a unit testing framework for PowerShell (it is even bundled with the version of PowerShell that ships with Windows 10, albeit an older version), which is designed to execute PowerShell commands and evaluate their output. Pester can execute functions, cmdlets, modules, or entire scripts and can be run ad-hoc or be integrated into a deployment/provisioning process. As with the PS Toolkit, I won&amp;#39;t cover its installation in great detail, but it can be installed from the PS Gallery or with the NuGet package manager by running &amp;quot;Get-Package pester&amp;quot; and then importing it into your PowerShell session using &amp;quot;Import-Module pester&amp;quot;. Let&amp;#39;s take a look at a simple Pester test to get some context:&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;pre class=&amp;quot;brush:powershell&amp;quot;&amp;gt;Describe -Name &amp;#39;NetApp Configuration Tests&amp;#39; {&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt; Context &amp;quot;Basic Storage Tests&amp;quot; {&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt; &nbsp;It -name &amp;quot;Check Cluster ONTAP version&amp;quot; {&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt; &nbsp; &nbsp;$version = Get-NcSystemVersion &nbsp;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt; &nbsp; &nbsp;$version | Should -Match &amp;#39;NetApp Release 9.3P8&amp;#39;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt; &nbsp;} # It&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt; } # Context&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;} # Describe&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/pre&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;Pester tests are broken up into logical groups of tests called blocks. The Describe block is typically used to group larger amounts of tests, such as all tests run against a particular type of system (ONTAP clusters, for my use case). On the next hierarchical level below Describe is a Context block, which is used to group similiar types of tests, such as a group of cluster networking or high availability tests. Below Context blocks, there are It blocks, which are designed to contain a single assertion.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;Once you have the test built and assuming that you have already connected to a NetApp controller with the Connect-NcController &amp;amp;lt;controller&amp;amp;gt; command (or validated that you have a current active connection by typing &amp;quot;$currentnccontroller&amp;quot; without the quotes), you can run a Pester test using the &amp;quot;Invoke-Pester /path/to/test&amp;quot; command.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;pre class=&amp;quot;brush:powershell&amp;quot;&amp;gt;PS C:\&amp;amp;gt; Invoke-Pester .\cluster-version.ps1&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;Executing all tests in &amp;#39;.\cluster-version.ps1&amp;#39;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;Executing script .\cluster-version.ps1&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt; &nbsp;Describing NetApp Configuration Tests&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt; &nbsp; &nbsp;Context Basic Storage Tests&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;[+] Check Cluster ONTAP version 310ms&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;Tests completed in 441ms&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;Tests Passed: 1, Failed: 0, Skipped: 0, Pending: 0, Inconclusive: 0&amp;lt;/pre&amp;gt;You can see that the test passed since the value returned by the PowerShell cmdlet stored in the variable matched the value we specified in the It block. This is probably the most basic example of a Pester test, so I am using it in my Pester tests to validate that I can run commands against a cluster and return valid results. So what does a failed test look like? If we connect to a different controller that&amp;#39;s not running our expected version of ONTAP, we can see.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;pre class=&amp;quot;brush:powershell&amp;quot;&amp;gt;PS C:\&amp;amp;gt; Invoke-Pester .\cluster-version.ps1&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;Executing all tests in &amp;#39;.\cluster-version.ps1&amp;#39;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;Executing script .\cluster-version.ps1&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt; &nbsp;Describing NetApp Configuration Tests&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt; &nbsp; &nbsp;Context Basic Storage Tests&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;[-] Check Cluster ONTAP version 1.96s&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Expected regular expression &amp;#39;NetApp Release 9.3P8&amp;#39; to match NetApp Release 9.1P12, but it did not match.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;5: &nbsp; &nbsp; $version | Should -Match &amp;#39;NetApp Release 9.3P8&amp;#39;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;at scriptblock, C:\cluster-version.ps1: line 5&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;Tests completed in 421ms&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;Tests Passed: 0, Failed: 1, Skipped: 0, Pending: 0, Inconclusive: 0&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/pre&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;As you can see, the test failed now since the value returned by the PS cmdlet returned an unexpected value. We can apply this logic to any one of the PowerShell cmdlets that are part of the PowerShell Toolkit. One of the other things that comes in handy is storing the actual configuration values in a JSON configuration file that is referenced in the script instead of the actual hard-coded values. This makes it very easy to update a configuration file when values change rather than having to update the script itself (and the configuration files themselves can exist in source control). For example, here is a slightly more advanced example of multiple It blocks grouped into a single Context and referencing a simple JSON file for configuration settings:&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;JSON configuration file (sample data):&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;{&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;quot;About&amp;quot;: {&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;quot;Product&amp;quot;: &amp;quot;NetApp Cluster Config (Basic)&amp;quot;,&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;quot;ConfigVersion&amp;quot;: &amp;quot;1.0&amp;quot;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; },&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;quot;Cluster&amp;quot;: {&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;quot;Autosupport&amp;quot;: {&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;quot;IsEnabled&amp;quot;: &amp;quot;True&amp;quot;,&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;quot;Transport&amp;quot;: &amp;quot;https&amp;quot;,&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;quot;MailHost&amp;quot;: &amp;quot;smtp.domain.com&amp;quot;,&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;quot;SupportAddress&amp;quot;: &amp;quot;<span class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="8cedf9f8e3fff9fcfce3fef8cce2e9f8edfcfca2efe3e1">[email&#160;protected]</span>&amp;quot;,&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;quot;To&amp;quot;: &amp;quot;<span class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="a5d6d1cad7c4c2c0fad1c0c4c8e5c1cac8c4cccb8bc6cac8">[email&#160;protected]</span>&amp;quot;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;},&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;}&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;amp;nbsp; }&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;pre class=&amp;quot;brush:powershell&amp;quot;&amp;gt;(Get-NcNode).ForEach{ &nbsp; &nbsp;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt; &nbsp; &nbsp;Context &amp;quot;Testing AutoSupport Settings on $($_)&amp;quot; {&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;(Get-NcAutoSupportConfig -Node $_.Node).ForEach{ &amp;lt;br /&amp;gt; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;It &amp;quot;AutoSupport is enabled&amp;quot; -test {&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;$_.IsEnabled | Should -Be $basic_config.Cluster.AutoSupport.IsEnabled&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;} # It&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;It &amp;quot;Autosupport transport method is HTTPS&amp;quot; -test { &nbsp;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;$_.Transport | Should -Be $basic_config.Cluster.AutoSupport.Transport&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;} # It&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;It &amp;quot;Mail host value is well-defined&amp;quot; -test {&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;$_.MailHosts | Should -Be $basic_config.Cluster.Autosupport.MailHost&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;} # It&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;It &amp;quot;Support address is well-defined&amp;quot; -test {&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;$_.SupportAddress | Should -Be $basic_config.Cluster.Autosupport.SupportAddress&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;} # It&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;It &amp;quot;AutoSupport notification destination email is well-defined&amp;quot; -test {&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;$_.To | Should -Be $basic_config.Cluster.Autosupport.To&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;} # It &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;} # Get-NcAutoSupportConfig&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt; &nbsp; &nbsp;} # Context &nbsp; &nbsp;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt; &nbsp; } # Get-NcNode&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/pre&amp;gt;The Pester output of this command then looks like this, assuming the cluster values match the values in your JSON file:&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;pre style=&amp;quot;background: rgb(46, 47, 48); border: 1px dashed rgb(204, 204, 204); font-size: 12px; height: auto; line-height: 20px; overflow: auto; padding: 0px; width: 646.469px;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;font-size: medium; white-space: normal;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;Times New Roman&amp;amp;quot;;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;color: lime;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;amp;nbsp;Context Testing AutoSupport Settings on lab-clst-01-n1&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;Times New Roman&amp;amp;quot;;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;color: lime;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;[+] AutoSupport is enabled 1ms&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;Times New Roman&amp;amp;quot;;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;color: lime;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;[+] Autosupport transport method is HTTPS 1ms&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;Times New Roman&amp;amp;quot;;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;color: lime;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;[+] Mail host value is well-defined 1ms&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;Times New Roman&amp;amp;quot;;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;color: lime;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;[+] Support address is well-defined 1ms&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;Times New Roman&amp;amp;quot;;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;color: lime;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;[+] AutoSupport notification destination email is well-defined 1ms&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;Times New Roman&amp;amp;quot;;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;color: lime;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;Times New Roman&amp;amp;quot;;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;color: lime;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;amp;nbsp;Context Testing AutoSupport Settings on lab-clst-01-n2&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;Times New Roman&amp;amp;quot;;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;color: lime;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;[+] AutoSupport is enabled 2ms&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;Times New Roman&amp;amp;quot;;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;color: lime;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;[+] Autosupport transport method is HTTPS 1ms&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;Times New Roman&amp;amp;quot;;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;color: lime;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;[+] Mail host value is well-defined 2ms&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;Times New Roman&amp;amp;quot;;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;color: lime;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;[+] Support address is well-defined 2ms&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;Times New Roman&amp;amp;quot;;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;color: lime;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;[+] AutoSupport notification destination email is well-defined 1ms&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;Times New Roman&amp;amp;quot;;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;color: lime;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;Times New Roman&amp;amp;quot;;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;color: lime;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;amp;nbsp;Context Testing AutoSupport Settings on lab-clst-01-n3&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;Times New Roman&amp;amp;quot;;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;color: lime;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;[+] AutoSupport is enabled 1ms&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;Times New Roman&amp;amp;quot;;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;color: lime;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;[+] Autosupport transport method is HTTPS 1ms&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;Times New Roman&amp;amp;quot;;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;color: lime;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;[+] Mail host value is well-defined 1ms&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;Times New Roman&amp;amp;quot;;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;color: lime;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;[+] Support address is well-defined 1ms&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;Times New Roman&amp;amp;quot;;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;color: lime;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;[+] AutoSupport notification destination email is well-defined 3ms&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;Times New Roman&amp;amp;quot;;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;color: lime;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;Times New Roman&amp;amp;quot;;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;color: lime;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;amp;nbsp;Context Testing AutoSupport Settings on lab-clst-01-n4&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;Times New Roman&amp;amp;quot;;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;color: lime;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;[+] AutoSupport is enabled 1ms&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;Times New Roman&amp;amp;quot;;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;color: lime;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;[+] Autosupport transport method is HTTPS 1ms&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;Times New Roman&amp;amp;quot;;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;color: lime;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;[+] Mail host value is well-defined 1ms&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;Times New Roman&amp;amp;quot;;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;color: lime;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;[+] Support address is well-defined 1ms&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;Times New Roman&amp;amp;quot;;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;color: lime;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;[+] AutoSupport notification destination email is well-defined 1ms&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/pre&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;Below is a list of ONTAP components I am testing with Pester today:&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;u&amp;gt;Basic cluster level items:&amp;lt;/u&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;AutoSupport settings&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;NTP servers&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;DNS servers&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;Auto-giveback status&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;Cluster HA health&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;u&amp;gt;Networking/SnapMirror:&amp;lt;/u&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;Cluster Peer health&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;Unhealthy SnapMirror relationships&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;Down ports&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;Interfaces not at their home ports&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;Service Processor status&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;u&amp;gt;Disk/volume:&amp;lt;/u&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;Broken disks&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;Unassigned disks&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;Offline volumes&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;Check for manually created snapshots older than 180 days&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;Check for backup storage snapshots older than 180 days&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;u&amp;gt;External engine fpolicy configuration:&amp;lt;/u&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;- event&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;- policy&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;- scope&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;- service account&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;- external engine&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;- status&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;u&amp;gt;Native fpolicy configuration:&amp;lt;/u&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;- event&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;- policy&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;- scope&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;u&amp;gt;Vscan configuration:&amp;lt;/u&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;Vscanner role&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;Vscan service account&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;Vscan scanner-pool&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;Vscan on-access policy&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;Vscan enabled&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;u&amp;gt;Future/wishlist items:&amp;lt;/u&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;Values that differ based on the cluster (DNS/NIS servers, Fpolicy collector server IPs, Vscan server IPs, etc.)&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;SAN health items (offline LUNs, number of initiators per igroup, etc.)&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;More complete JSON configuration file usage&amp;amp;nbsp;&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;Automated remediation (far future, if ever)&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;My goal is to add more tests as time goes on and use cases pop up. Also, I will eventually be running the tests in an automated fashion with some sort of reporting to be more proactive about detecting configuration drift. Hopefully this is useful for more than just me as a customer - I could see it being useful as a partner for auditing the health of customer environments without ever having to manually log into the cluster.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;If you&amp;#39;d like to get more information about Pester (and believe me, there is a LOT that I haven&amp;#39;t covered, this is barely scratching the surface) you can review the documentation at &amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://github.com/pester/Pester&amp;quot;&amp;gt;https://github.com/pester/Pester&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;I&amp;#39;ve also published my Pester code (and associated sample JSON configuration file) to GitHub at &amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://github.com/zer0trust/Pester-ONTAP&amp;quot;&amp;gt;https://github.com/zer0trust/Pester-ONTAP&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; if you&amp;#39;d like to use it in your environment or even if you just want to point and laugh at my rudimentary PowerShell abilities. I have approximately one week of experience writing Pester tests, so if you see a way that it could be improved, I&amp;#39;d love the feedback and will happily update the tests to reflect that.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;Disclaimer: These tests rely on only PS &amp;quot;Get-Function&amp;quot; commands, but I&amp;#39;m not responsible for anything wacky that happens if/when you run this against production clusters.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;Thanks for reading!&lt;/content&gt;&lt;link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='https://www.blogger.com/feeds/3947691530317823276/posts/default/5704596864395092630'/&gt;&lt;link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='https://www.blogger.com/feeds/3947691530317823276/posts/default/5704596864395092630'/&gt;&lt;link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='https://www.langhq.com/2019/05/ontap-configuration-compliance-auditing.html' title='ONTAP Configuration Compliance Auditing with PowerShell and Pester'/&gt;&lt;author&gt;&lt;name&gt;Donny Lang&lt;/name&gt;&lt;uri&gt;http://www.blogger.com/profile/04332684287885880604&lt;/uri&gt;&lt;email&gt;<span class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="157b7a677065796c5577797a727270673b767a78">[email&#160;protected]</span>&lt;/email&gt;&lt;gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='32' height='32' src='//1.bp.blogspot.com/-JafglNogKoE/WsfNRWPGLRI/AAAAAAAAOwA/ct7A0f4IRrMkD4AQSqkjb4FXdWMmsSSYgCK4BGAYYCw/s49/2018-04-06%2B14_39_55-Donny%2BLang%2B%2528%2540DonnyLang1%2529%2B_%2BTwitter.png'/&gt;&lt;/author&gt;&lt;media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-fV6u5DddcxE/XOFtRPBakTI/AAAAAAAAYdo/BraQ94Bkj-0h5-RaK0Ge1-6yACs4QDfMACLcBGAs/s72-c/PowerShell_5.0_icon.png" height="72" width="72"/&gt;&lt;/entry&gt;&lt;entry&gt;&lt;id&gt;tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-3947691530317823276.post-2286548456303428565&lt;/id&gt;&lt;published&gt;2019-04-02T17:15:00.001-07:00&lt;/published&gt;&lt;updated&gt;2019-04-02T17:15:37.653-07:00&lt;/updated&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="Kubernetes"/&gt;&lt;title type='text'&gt;Deploying Kubernetes With Rancher Kubernetes Engine (RKE)&lt;/title&gt;&lt;content type='html'&gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-1Xbp92mUA8A/W_WGfnOCRVI/AAAAAAAAUac/xojmhgk2z8wykr70u4hakr6-kLJ-zrwfgCLcBGAs/s1600/rancher_kubernetes_logos.png&amp;quot; imageanchor=&amp;quot;1&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;img border=&amp;quot;0&amp;quot; data-original-height=&amp;quot;611&amp;quot; data-original-width=&amp;quot;883&amp;quot; src=&amp;quot;https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-1Xbp92mUA8A/W_WGfnOCRVI/AAAAAAAAUac/xojmhgk2z8wykr70u4hakr6-kLJ-zrwfgCLcBGAs/s1600/rancher_kubernetes_logos.png&amp;quot; /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;What is Kubernetes?&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;Kubernetes is an open-source container orchestration/management platform for managing services within containers, usually Docker. It encompasses management of all layers of the infrastructure stack (compute, networking, storage, etc.) and is designed to provide service portability across various public and private cloud providers.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;Why do I care?&amp;amp;nbsp;&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;Personally, I&amp;#39;m an infrastructure operations guy in my day job and a lot of my current job duties include managing what can best be described as &amp;quot;traditional infrastructure&amp;quot; - on-premises compute, storage, networking, etc. So you may be saying &amp;quot;I care about storage and hypervisors, I don&amp;#39;t care about containers and applications!&amp;quot; And to a point, I agree. Infrastructure is important and will always exist in some context, for sure, but the relationship between infrastructure components and applications is symbiotic - applications need infrastructure and infrastructure is pretty usually with no workload to run. A more complete understanding of how infrastructure can help applications run more efficiently doesn&amp;#39;t sound like a bad thing.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;From an application owner&amp;#39;s perspective, (at least in my experience) they typically don&amp;#39;t care at all about any of the infrastructure, as long as they can get the features/performance they need. I don&amp;#39;t think anyone ever asks what flavor of RAID their AWS server has or what brand of servers they&amp;#39;re running, they just expect a certain level of performance. To that end, I&amp;#39;ve been endeavoring to better understand enterprise applications and services to figure out how the infrastructure that I manage can fit into the puzzle.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;So now what?&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;I run a simple Docker deployment on Ubuntu (with persistent NFS volumes via FreeNAS) in my home lab to support various mission-critical functions (read: Plex Server). But what if I want to manage multiple Docker hosts? How do I handle the networking in an easy-to-manage way? How do I handle persistent storage across multiple hosts? How would I make it easy to deploy applications in an enterprise environment? How do I recover from application failures? So many questions!&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;This is where Kubernetes comes in! But after reviewing the manual deployment process, it looked like there was a fairly steep learning curve with lots of new terms and acronyms. So, my advice would be to check out this &amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://medium.com/google-cloud/kubernetes-101-pods-nodes-containers-and-clusters-c1509e409e16&amp;quot;&amp;gt;Kubernetes 101&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; post from a Google engineer, Daniel Sanche (&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://twitter.com/DanSanche21&amp;quot;&amp;gt;@DanSanche&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; on Twitter) which I found very helpful when trying to wrap my head around the components of the Kubernetes architecture.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;amp;nbsp;Armed with a (very) basic understanding of Kubernetes and my typical &amp;quot;learn by tinkering&amp;quot; mentality, I looked for an &amp;quot;easy&amp;quot; way to deploy a on-premises Kubernetes cluster that would provide me with an environment to learn about Kubernetes. And so, I discovered Rancher Kubernetes Engine.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;RKE is, essentially, a Kubernetes installer. It is designed to make rolling out a Kubernetes cluster a simple process that is driven by a single YAML file and populated with relevant information from your environment. You can find the installer at&amp;amp;nbsp;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://github.com/rancher/rke&amp;quot;&amp;gt;https://github.com/rancher/rke&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;amp;nbsp;along with some good documentation on the requirements, installation, and upgrade procedures.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;Once you have your Kubernetes cluster up and running, you&amp;#39;re free to manage it from the command line or install something like Rancher to provide a graphical management plane.&lt;/content&gt;&lt;link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='https://www.blogger.com/feeds/3947691530317823276/posts/default/2286548456303428565'/&gt;&lt;link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='https://www.blogger.com/feeds/3947691530317823276/posts/default/2286548456303428565'/&gt;&lt;link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='https://www.langhq.com/2019/04/deploying-kubernetes-with-rancher.html' title='Deploying Kubernetes With Rancher Kubernetes Engine (RKE)'/&gt;&lt;author&gt;&lt;name&gt;Donny Lang&lt;/name&gt;&lt;uri&gt;http://www.blogger.com/profile/04332684287885880604&lt;/uri&gt;&lt;email&gt;<span class="__cf_email__"
