xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-XZ7IeV890aY/W8iWsJlLrTI/AAAAAAAATro/xqt7ShHgwewy5h4v_qi2X8KyC0Co-X82gCLcBGAs/s72-c/post-title-image.png" height="72" width="72"/&gt;&lt;/entry&gt;&lt;entry&gt;&lt;id&gt;tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-3947691530317823276.post-6235168876027043115&lt;/id&gt;&lt;published&gt;2018-10-09T10:50:00.000-07:00&lt;/published&gt;&lt;updated&gt;2018-10-09T10:50:08.319-07:00&lt;/updated&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="Blogtober"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="Blogtober2018"/&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="NetApp"/&gt;&lt;title type='text'&gt;NetApp Cloud Insights Preview, Part 2: Queries, Annotations, and Performance Policies&lt;/title&gt;&lt;content type='html'&gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-Pemr3snTIVk/W7y4WkXCDmI/AAAAAAAATi4/5JD_6IkELAIlljgG_IAx-UJNUR6_Wm2owCLcBGAs/s1600/post-title-image.png&amp;quot; imageanchor=&amp;quot;1&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;img border=&amp;quot;0&amp;quot; data-original-height=&amp;quot;208&amp;quot; data-original-width=&amp;quot;367&amp;quot; height=&amp;quot;362&amp;quot; src=&amp;quot;https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-Pemr3snTIVk/W7y4WkXCDmI/AAAAAAAATi4/5JD_6IkELAIlljgG_IAx-UJNUR6_Wm2owCLcBGAs/s640/post-title-image.png&amp;quot; width=&amp;quot;640&amp;quot; /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;If you haven&amp;#39;t read Part 1 yet, check out the first post in the series&amp;amp;nbsp;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://www.langhq.com/2018/09/netapp-cloud-insights-preview-part-1.html&amp;quot;&amp;gt;HERE&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;amp;nbsp;to find out how to get involved in the preview, install the Acquisition Unit, and get your Data Collectors up and running.&amp;amp;nbsp;&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;Now that I&amp;#39;ve gotten my locally installed Acquisition Unit up and running and my Data Collectors configured and collecting data, I&amp;#39;m going to attempt to put all of this glorious data to work and display it in a useful fashion.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;Queries&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;A query is, at its most basic level, a filter-based search of the components of your environment designed to return relevant information based on the type of component selected. (for example: volumes over 90% capacity or hypervisor hosts with high memory usage). In my example, I&amp;#39;m going to be creating a query that will display all non-DP (data protection) volumes with a capacity that exceeds 85%.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;1. Start by clicking on &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;Queries &amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;on the left-hand navigation bar and then selecting &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;+ New Query &amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;from the pop-out menu.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-bFptj3w57Ss/W7zBEqAvdII/AAAAAAAATjE/ogJNgm6JdqYIiIaL-4X4mmoHhB62MTUSgCLcBGAs/s1600/cloud-insights-1.png&amp;quot; imageanchor=&amp;quot;1&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;img border=&amp;quot;0&amp;quot; data-original-height=&amp;quot;182&amp;quot; data-original-width=&amp;quot;533&amp;quot; height=&amp;quot;217&amp;quot; src=&amp;quot;https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-bFptj3w57Ss/W7zBEqAvdII/AAAAAAAATjE/ogJNgm6JdqYIiIaL-4X4mmoHhB62MTUSgCLcBGAs/s640/cloud-insights-1.png&amp;quot; width=&amp;quot;640&amp;quot; /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;2. At the top of the screen, let&amp;#39;s give our new Query a name - &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;NetApp - Production Volumes Over 90% Capacity&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;3. Click on the &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;Search For... &amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;box and select &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;Internal Volume &amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;from the lengthy drop-down menu. If your Data Collectors have been configured properly, you should see a list of your NetApp storage volumes populate in the Query Results field below.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;4. Now comes the fun part - filters! The default filter is one that displays all volumes based on their names, but I&amp;#39;d like to only consider production volumes for this particular query. My environment follows a naming scheme where SnapMirror/SnapVault destination volumes contain the characters &amp;quot;Rep&amp;quot;. You can use the &amp;quot;NOT&amp;quot; operator and wildcards to filter out unwanted results from your query. I&amp;#39;ll use &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;NOT *REP* &amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;for mine to filter out results for non-production volumes.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;5. Click the blue + icon next to the filter we set up in Step 4 to add another filter - a drop-down menu will appear. Select &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;Capacity Ratio - Used &amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;for the second filter. There are fields for &amp;quot;From&amp;quot; and &amp;quot;To&amp;quot; values for the query - input &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;85 &amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;and &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;100&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;, respectively. The query will look like the one below when you are done.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-QJFwJ02mHUM/W7zK5N5yFAI/AAAAAAAATjQ/Y6hNUbeulr043E9Jm47xAber50K8cTwcACLcBGAs/s1600/cloud-insights-2.png&amp;quot; imageanchor=&amp;quot;1&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;img border=&amp;quot;0&amp;quot; data-original-height=&amp;quot;91&amp;quot; data-original-width=&amp;quot;530&amp;quot; height=&amp;quot;108&amp;quot; src=&amp;quot;https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-QJFwJ02mHUM/W7zK5N5yFAI/AAAAAAAATjQ/Y6hNUbeulr043E9Jm47xAber50K8cTwcACLcBGAs/s640/cloud-insights-2.png&amp;quot; width=&amp;quot;640&amp;quot; /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;Obviously, this is a very simple example, but it gives you an idea of what is possible with Queries. There are A LOT of different filter options that you can use to get really granular results that are specific to your environment.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;Annotations &amp;amp;amp; Annotation Rules&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;Cloud Insights supports a system of tagging or organizing resources called Annotations, whereby you can assign different values to components of your infrastructure based on a number of different criteria. For example, you may want to annotate components that belong together in the same physical data center or within the same VMware cluster. I&amp;#39;ll be creating a Data Center annotation for my example.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;1.&amp;amp;nbsp; Click&amp;amp;nbsp;on &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;Manage &amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;on the left-hand navigation bar and then selecting &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;Annotations &amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;from the pop-out menu. A list of existing Annotations will be displayed. We&amp;#39;ll be adding custom values to the pre-defined &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;Data Center &amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;Annotation.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;2. Click on the three dots on the far right of the &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;Data Center &amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;Annotation row and click on &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;Edit. &amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;The Edit Annotation window will be displayed.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-QIlghY3SNxc/W7zQAmxishI/AAAAAAAATjc/0GmpjVmRtgAYXXEIT9RKs0rLvfNRSkdSgCLcBGAs/s1600/cloud-insights-3.png&amp;quot; imageanchor=&amp;quot;1&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;img border=&amp;quot;0&amp;quot; data-original-height=&amp;quot;401&amp;quot; data-original-width=&amp;quot;602&amp;quot; height=&amp;quot;426&amp;quot; src=&amp;quot;https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-QIlghY3SNxc/W7zQAmxishI/AAAAAAAATjc/0GmpjVmRtgAYXXEIT9RKs0rLvfNRSkdSgCLcBGAs/s640/cloud-insights-3.png&amp;quot; width=&amp;quot;640&amp;quot; /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;3. Click on the &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;+ Value &amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;button to add values to the Annotation. We&amp;#39;ll be adding &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;DC1 &amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;and &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;DC2 &amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;as values for the purposes of the example, but you can enter anything that makes sense for your environment. You also have the opportunity to enter a description of the value as well.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;4. Once you have some values assigned for your Annotation, now you can use those values to assign Annotations to specific objects. Let&amp;#39;s assign a VMware ESXi host the &amp;quot;DC1&amp;quot; Annotation.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;5. From the summary page for a given object (in this case, an ESXi host), click on the &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;+ Annotation &amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;button. An &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;Add Annotation &amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;screen will be displayed. Select the &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;Data Center &amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;Annotation that we added values to earlier, and click on the &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;Value &amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;drop-down menu to select &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;DC1.&amp;amp;nbsp;&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;That&amp;#39;s it - you&amp;#39;re ready to start using those Annotations as the basis for Queries and Dashboards. But the way we added that Annotation was a lot of manual work, and I&amp;#39;m lazy, so how do we add Annotations to objects automatically? Enter Annotation Rules!&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;Annotation Rules are used to apply Annotations to components based on criteria defined in the rule. An Annotation Rule is associated with a Query (for example, one designed to query ESXi hosts in a specific data center based on their hostnames) and then uses the output of that query to determine which components to add Annotations to.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;Performance Policies&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt; &nbsp;Performance Policies are a monitoring component that allow you to set thresholds for various objects in your infrastructure and create alerts when those thresholds are violated. They can be used in conjunction with Annotations to support very granular alerting use cases (different SLAs for primary/DR data centers, for example). I&amp;#39;m going to be creating a Hypervisor Performance Policy for my example, where we will generate an alert when CPU or Memory utilization goes above 80% for an ESXi host.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;1. Click on &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;Manage &amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;on the left-hand navigation bar and then select &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;Performance Policies &amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;from the pop-out menu. A list of existing Performance Policies is displayed. Click on the large &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;+ Performance Policy &amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;button to create a new policy.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;2. From the &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;Edit Policy &amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;window, select a name for the policy and select &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;Hypervisor &amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;from the &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;Apply to Objects of Type &amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;drop-down menu.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;3. Select &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;CPU Utilization - Total&amp;amp;nbsp;&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;from the first threshold drop-down menu and then select the greater-than symbol and input &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;80 &amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;into the percentage field.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;4. Click on &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;+ Threshold &amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;and input the same values as step 3 for the &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;Memory Utilization - Total &amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;threshold. Your policy will look like the one below when you are finished.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-GagKCiR7PTk/W7zm2WjxreI/AAAAAAAATjo/6FgzL9JdPzIL96zYGExCuIwwnRyl6BzJwCLcBGAs/s1600/cloud-insights-4.png&amp;quot; imageanchor=&amp;quot;1&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;img border=&amp;quot;0&amp;quot; data-original-height=&amp;quot;633&amp;quot; data-original-width=&amp;quot;598&amp;quot; height=&amp;quot;640&amp;quot; src=&amp;quot;https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-GagKCiR7PTk/W7zm2WjxreI/AAAAAAAATjo/6FgzL9JdPzIL96zYGExCuIwwnRyl6BzJwCLcBGAs/s640/cloud-insights-4.png&amp;quot; width=&amp;quot;604&amp;quot; /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;Summary&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;Queries, Annotations, and Performance Policies are great ways to get insight into specific parts of your environment based on your individual needs. Keep in mind that these examples represent only the simplest use cases for the features, and there are much more powerful/useful queries and policies that can be set up.&amp;amp;nbsp;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;Also, I&amp;#39;ve been finding that a lot of the documentation available for OnCommand Insight also holds true for Cloud Insights, so if you would like a much more thorough explanation of any of these features, the &amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;http://docs.netapp.com/oci-73/index.jsp&amp;quot;&amp;gt;OCI Documentation Center&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; is a great place to start.&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;Thank you for taking the time to read this blog series, and keep an eye out for Part 3 where I will be covering Applications and Dashboards as they pertain to Cloud Insights.&lt;/content&gt;&lt;link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='https://www.blogger.com/feeds/3947691530317823276/posts/default/6235168876027043115'/&gt;&lt;link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='https://www.blogger.com/feeds/3947691530317823276/posts/default/6235168876027043115'/&gt;&lt;link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='https://www.langhq.com/2018/10/netapp-cloud-insights-preview-part-2.html' title='NetApp Cloud Insights Preview, Part 2: Queries, Annotations, and Performance Policies'/&gt;&lt;author&gt;&lt;name&gt;Donny Lang&lt;/name&gt;&lt;uri&gt;http://www.blogger.com/profile/04332684287885880604&lt;/uri&gt;&lt;email&gt;<span class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="2947465b4c594550694b45464e4e4c5b074a4644">[email&#160;protected]</span>&lt;/email&gt;&lt;gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='32' height='32' src='//1.bp.blogspot.com/-JafglNogKoE/WsfNRWPGLRI/AAAAAAAAOwA/ct7A0f4IRrMkD4AQSqkjb4FXdWMmsSSYgCK4BGAYYCw/s49/2018-04-06%2B14_39_55-Donny%2BLang%2B%2528%2540DonnyLang1%2529%2B_%2BTwitter.png'/&gt;&lt;/author&gt;&lt;media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-Pemr3snTIVk/W7y4WkXCDmI/AAAAAAAATi4/5JD_6IkELAIlljgG_IAx-UJNUR6_Wm2owCLcBGAs/s72-c/post-title-image.png" height="72" width="72"/&gt;&lt;/entry&gt;&lt;entry&gt;&lt;id&gt;tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-3947691530317823276.post-7257505572097371429&lt;/id&gt;&lt;published&gt;2018-09-11T13:09:00.000-07:00&lt;/published&gt;&lt;updated&gt;2018-10-09T09:53:36.744-07:00&lt;/updated&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="NetApp"/&gt;&lt;title type='text'&gt;NetApp Cloud Insights Preview, Part 1: Installing the Acquisition Unit&lt;/title&gt;&lt;content type='html'&gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-mBJgnHnKUm0/W5lrg07MEGI/AAAAAAAATAY/IczDoXEUz5QmOjKn0_Lo8gKyq4MNVQ8AgCEwYBhgL/s1600/post-title-image.png&amp;quot; imageanchor=&amp;quot;1&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;img border=&amp;quot;0&amp;quot; data-original-height=&amp;quot;208&amp;quot; data-original-width=&amp;quot;367&amp;quot; height=&amp;quot;361&amp;quot; src=&amp;quot;https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-mBJgnHnKUm0/W5lrg07MEGI/AAAAAAAATAY/IczDoXEUz5QmOjKn0_Lo8gKyq4MNVQ8AgCEwYBhgL/s640/post-title-image.png&amp;quot; width=&amp;quot;640&amp;quot; /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;For those of you that aren&amp;#39;t familiar with NetApp Cloud Insights, it is an infrastructure monitoring tool that is currently available as a Public Preview. It is designed to provide, well, insight into the often diverse sets of storage and networking components in use across your entire environment - everything from on-premises ONTAP deployments to public cloud offerings from Amazon, Microsoft, and others.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;Recently, I registered for the preview and just received my email welcoming me into the preview last week. I am planning a series of posts to cover my experiences with Cloud Insights and share the information with other people for whom a vendor-agnostic SaaS monitoring solution might be a good fit.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;As a disclaimer: my experiences will be limited to what is in use in my environment, so the coverage of the public cloud features will likely not be covered in great detail - it will primarily be on-premises ONTAP and VMware monitoring data that I&amp;#39;m looking at.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;However, there is a lot of good information about the offering in general if you&amp;#39;d like to get more information on the things that I gloss over. If you&amp;#39;d like to sign up for the preview yourself, there is a link below as well.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://cloud.netapp.com/cloud-insights&amp;quot;&amp;gt;Cloud Insights product page&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vdiZZ4v_SkI&amp;quot;&amp;gt;Tech Field Day video with James Holden&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://www.netapp.com/us/forms/campaign/cloud-insights-exclusive-look.aspx?hsCtaTracking=52a3a960-3d77-497e-a19e-b122e03885e2%7Cc50e2f73-8d50-4757-b06e-194d83b9d6d4&amp;quot;&amp;gt;Register for Cloud Insights Preview&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;Now, with all of the introduction out of the way, onto the first step in getting your Cloud Insights deployment up and running - the Acquisition Unit (AU). It is a small application designed to run on a Linux server (CentOS 7 in my case) that connects to your various services (via Data Collectors configured in Cloud Insights) and sends inventory and performance data to the Cloud Insights servers.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;When you have been accepted into the preview program, you will get an email with instructions on how to log into your tenant environment via NetApp Cloud Central. Once you have that email, you will be able to log in and download the .zip file that contains the Acquisition Unit software.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;The installation is very straightforward and consists of unzipping a file and running the installation script contained within. You&amp;#39;ll accept a EULA which I totally read in its entirety and then be prompted for several key pieces of information - server name, port, acquisition user password - all of which are provided in your welcome email. I think the installation took me roughly 10 minutes total and was relatively painless.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;One quick note: I did not see any specific system requirements for the Acquisition Unit, but I had originally provisioned my virtual machine with 1 vCPU and 2GB of RAM, and the acquisition service would not start due to (evidently) Java failing to allocate sufficient memory to the application. I allocated 4GB of RAM to the AU instead, and all was well. So I would use 1 vCPU/4GB of RAM for your virtual machine.&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;Edit: As Rafael kindly pointed out (thank you!) in the comments section, here are the AU requirements:&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;- CPU: 4 cores&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;- RAM: 16GB&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;- Disk: 40GB&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;Once your Acquisition Unit is installed, you can make sure the service is running by issuing the &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;sudo oci-service.sh status acquisition &amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;command. You should see a message like this if all is well:&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;[<span class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="12676177605273673f617760647760">[email&#160;protected]</span> ~]# sudo oci-service.sh status acquisition&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;OnCommand (R) Insight&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;acquisition is running&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;[<span class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="cebbbdabbc8eafbbe3bdabbcb8abbc">[email&#160;protected]</span> ~]#&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;From there, you should be able to see the AU in Cloud Insights as well under Admin -&amp;amp;gt; Data Collectors -&amp;amp;gt; Acquisition Units. The status should say &amp;quot;OK&amp;quot; assuming your AU is able to communicate with the Cloud Insights servers.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;Now you can install Data Collectors, which are designed to connect to your on-premises or cloud services and collect inventory and performance data (bet you couldn&amp;#39;t have guessed their function by their name!). That is accomplished via the Admin -&amp;amp;gt; Data Collectors -&amp;amp;gt; Available Data Collectors screen. At the time of writing, there are 49 available data collectors.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-yr9RAZUsHic/W5fr-YX-RII/AAAAAAAAS_w/vS8btebV0d4QfYydtpJv5S5tMUYydT6JACLcBGAs/s1600/cloud-insights-2.png&amp;quot; imageanchor=&amp;quot;1&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;img border=&amp;quot;0&amp;quot; data-original-height=&amp;quot;496&amp;quot; data-original-width=&amp;quot;1600&amp;quot; height=&amp;quot;198&amp;quot; src=&amp;quot;https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-yr9RAZUsHic/W5fr-YX-RII/AAAAAAAAS_w/vS8btebV0d4QfYydtpJv5S5tMUYydT6JACLcBGAs/s640/cloud-insights-2.png&amp;quot; width=&amp;quot;640&amp;quot; /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;If you click on one of the boxes, you&amp;#39;ll be able to install that particular Data Collector (or be given a choice of multiple Collectors offered by the same vendor. I&amp;#39;ll be using the NetApp ONTAP Management Software collector in my example, but the logic is the same for other Data Collectors.&amp;amp;nbsp;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;I am using an existing service account with read-only access to my NetApp clusters, so if you have one of those, great. If not, you&amp;#39;ll probably want to create one to use for monitoring use cases like this one.&amp;amp;nbsp;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;Once you click on the Data Collector, you&amp;#39;ll see a screen to put in all of the relevant information for your NetApp deployment:&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-47F4BzPQt_s/W5ftSsmBTvI/AAAAAAAAS_8/i7zUM30L70gQigsvIvQBddRwLcZk4N3YgCLcBGAs/s1600/cloud-insights-3.png&amp;quot; imageanchor=&amp;quot;1&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: left; float: left; margin-bottom: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;img border=&amp;quot;0&amp;quot; data-original-height=&amp;quot;795&amp;quot; data-original-width=&amp;quot;601&amp;quot; height=&amp;quot;640&amp;quot; src=&amp;quot;https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-47F4BzPQt_s/W5ftSsmBTvI/AAAAAAAAS_8/i7zUM30L70gQigsvIvQBddRwLcZk4N3YgCLcBGAs/s640/cloud-insights-3.png&amp;quot; width=&amp;quot;482&amp;quot; /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;Once you have all the information added, click on &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;Test Configuration &amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;in order to validate that the AU is able to connect to the management IP and run a test command. You&amp;#39;ll see a message indicating whether or not the test passed.&amp;amp;nbsp;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;From there, you can see the status of all of your installed Data Collectors by going to Admin -&amp;amp;gt; Data Collectors -&amp;amp;gt; Installed Data Collectors. There you can see high-level information about the status of the polling for your Data Collectors - the default polling interval appears to be 20 minutes and is configurable on a per-Data Collector basis.&amp;amp;nbsp;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;Once the Data Collectors have been polled successfully for inventory and performance data, you can begin to build some dashboards to get some use out of all the data. I&amp;#39;ll be covering dashboards in a future blog post, so keep an eye out for a post with pretty graphs in the next few weeks.&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;So far, I&amp;#39;m pretty excited about what Cloud Insights has been able to offer, even just for on-premises ONTAP and VMware deployments. Hopefully I&amp;#39;ll get to dig in even deeper and find out how I can use it in my environment to accelerate troubleshooting and get VM-level monitoring data to correlate with storage performance data.&amp;amp;nbsp;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;Thanks for reading and as always, stay tuned for future posts!&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&lt;/content&gt;&lt;link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='https://www.blogger.com/feeds/3947691530317823276/posts/default/7257505572097371429'/&gt;&lt;link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='https://www.blogger.com/feeds/3947691530317823276/posts/default/7257505572097371429'/&gt;&lt;link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='https://www.langhq.com/2018/09/netapp-cloud-insights-preview-part-1.html' title='NetApp Cloud Insights Preview, Part 1: Installing the Acquisition Unit'/&gt;&lt;author&gt;&lt;name&gt;Donny Lang&lt;/name&gt;&lt;uri&gt;http://www.blogger.com/profile/04332684287885880604&lt;/uri&gt;&lt;email&gt;<span class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="0668697463766a7f46646a69616163742865696b">[email&#160;protected]</span>&lt;/email&gt;&lt;gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='32' height='32' src='//1.bp.blogspot.com/-JafglNogKoE/WsfNRWPGLRI/AAAAAAAAOwA/ct7A0f4IRrMkD4AQSqkjb4FXdWMmsSSYgCK4BGAYYCw/s49/2018-04-06%2B14_39_55-Donny%2BLang%2B%2528%2540DonnyLang1%2529%2B_%2BTwitter.png'/&gt;&lt;/author&gt;&lt;media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-mBJgnHnKUm0/W5lrg07MEGI/AAAAAAAATAY/IczDoXEUz5QmOjKn0_Lo8gKyq4MNVQ8AgCEwYBhgL/s72-c/post-title-image.png" height="72" width="72"/&gt;&lt;/entry&gt;&lt;entry&gt;&lt;id&gt;tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-3947691530317823276.post-8845424255856619070&lt;/id&gt;&lt;published&gt;2018-08-01T14:23:00.000-07:00&lt;/published&gt;&lt;updated&gt;2019-05-19T10:19:13.021-07:00&lt;/updated&gt;&lt;category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="NetApp"/&gt;&lt;title type='text'&gt;How To: Unjoin NetApp Nodes from a Cluster&lt;/title&gt;&lt;content type='html'&gt;Let me paint you a word picture:&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;You&amp;#39;ve upgraded to a shiny new AFF - it&amp;#39;s all racked, stacked, cabled and ready to rock. You&amp;#39;ve moved your volumes onto the new storage and your workloads are performing beautifully (of course) and it&amp;#39;s time to put your old NetApp gear out to pasture.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;We&amp;#39;re going to learn how to unjoin nodes from an existing cluster. But wait! There are several prerequisites that must be met before the actual cluster unjoin can be done.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;ul&amp;gt;&amp;lt;li&amp;gt;Ensure that you have either moved volumes to your new aggregates or offlined and deleted any unused volumes.&amp;lt;/li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;li&amp;gt;Offline and delete aggregates from old nodes.&amp;lt;/li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;li&amp;gt;Re-home data LIFs or disable/delete if they are not in use.&amp;lt;/li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;li&amp;gt;Disable and delete intercluster LIFs for the old nodes (and remove them from any Cluster Peering relationships)&amp;lt;/li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;li&amp;gt;Remove the old node&amp;#39;s ports from any Broadcast Domains or Failover Groups that they may be a member of.&amp;lt;/li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;li&amp;gt;Move &amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://library.netapp.com/ecmdocs/ECMP1196798/html/GUID-EFE1DEF4-8B87-4C4A-8E4E-C6C79F760710.html&amp;quot;&amp;gt;epsilon&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; to one of the new nodes (let&amp;#39;s assume nodes 3 and 4 are the new nodes, in this scenario).&amp;lt;/li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/ul&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;courier new&amp;amp;quot; , &amp;amp;quot;courier&amp;amp;quot; , monospace;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;labnetapp01::&amp;amp;gt; set -priv advanced&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;courier new&amp;amp;quot; , &amp;amp;quot;courier&amp;amp;quot; , monospace;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;labnetapp01::*&amp;amp;gt; cluster show -epsilon *&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;courier new&amp;amp;quot; , &amp;amp;quot;courier&amp;amp;quot; , monospace;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;Node&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;Health&amp;amp;nbsp; Eligibility&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;Epsilon&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;courier new&amp;amp;quot; , &amp;amp;quot;courier&amp;amp;quot; , monospace;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;-------------------- ------- ------------&amp;amp;nbsp; ------------&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;courier new&amp;amp;quot; , &amp;amp;quot;courier&amp;amp;quot; , monospace;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;node1&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;true&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; true&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; true&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;courier new&amp;amp;quot; , &amp;amp;quot;courier&amp;amp;quot; , monospace;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;node2&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;true&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; true&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; false&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;courier new&amp;amp;quot; , &amp;amp;quot;courier&amp;amp;quot; , monospace;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;node3&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;true&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; true&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; false&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;courier new&amp;amp;quot; , &amp;amp;quot;courier&amp;amp;quot; , monospace;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;node4&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;true&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; true&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; false&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;courier new&amp;amp;quot; , &amp;amp;quot;courier&amp;amp;quot; , monospace;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;4 entries were displayed.&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;We can see that node 1 has epsilon currently, so let&amp;#39;s disable it on node 1 and move it to one of the new nodes.&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;courier new&amp;amp;quot; , &amp;amp;quot;courier&amp;amp;quot; , monospace;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;labnetapp01::*&amp;amp;gt; cluster modify -node node1 -epsilon false&amp;amp;nbsp;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;courier new&amp;amp;quot; , &amp;amp;quot;courier&amp;amp;quot; , monospace;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;courier new&amp;amp;quot; , &amp;amp;quot;courier&amp;amp;quot; , monospace;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;labnetapp01::*&amp;amp;gt; cluster modify -node node3 -epsilon true&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;courier new&amp;amp;quot; , &amp;amp;quot;courier&amp;amp;quot; , monospace;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: inherit;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;We can verify that epsilon was moved by running the &amp;quot;cluster show -epsilon *&amp;quot; command again:&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: inherit;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;courier new&amp;amp;quot; , &amp;amp;quot;courier&amp;amp;quot; , monospace;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;labnetapp01::*&amp;amp;gt; cluster show -epsilon *&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;courier new&amp;amp;quot; , &amp;amp;quot;courier&amp;amp;quot; , monospace;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;Node&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;Health&amp;amp;nbsp; Eligibility&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;Epsilon&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;courier new&amp;amp;quot; , &amp;amp;quot;courier&amp;amp;quot; , monospace;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;-------------------- ------- ------------&amp;amp;nbsp; ------------&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;courier new&amp;amp;quot; , &amp;amp;quot;courier&amp;amp;quot; , monospace;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;node1&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;true&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; true&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; false&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;courier new&amp;amp;quot; , &amp;amp;quot;courier&amp;amp;quot; , monospace;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;node2&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;true&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; true&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; false&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;courier new&amp;amp;quot; , &amp;amp;quot;courier&amp;amp;quot; , monospace;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;node3&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;true&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; true&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; true&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;courier new&amp;amp;quot; , &amp;amp;quot;courier&amp;amp;quot; , monospace;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;node1&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;crs&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; 1&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; 1&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; 88&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;node0&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;offline&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;courier new&amp;amp;quot; , &amp;amp;quot;courier&amp;amp;quot; , monospace;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;node2&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;mgmt&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;1&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; 1&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; 1068&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;node0&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;offline&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;courier new&amp;amp;quot; , &amp;amp;quot;courier&amp;amp;quot; , monospace;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;node2&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;vldb&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;1&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; 1&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; 98&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;node0&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;offline&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;courier new&amp;amp;quot; , &amp;amp;quot;courier&amp;amp;quot; , monospace;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;node2&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;vifmgr&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;1&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; 1&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; 350&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; node0&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;offline&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;courier new&amp;amp;quot; , &amp;amp;quot;courier&amp;amp;quot; , monospace;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;node2&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;bcomd&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; 1&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; 1&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; 56&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;node0&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;offline&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;courier new&amp;amp;quot; , &amp;amp;quot;courier&amp;amp;quot; , monospace;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;node2&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;crs&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; 1&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; 1&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; 88&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;node0&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;offline&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;courier new&amp;amp;quot; , &amp;amp;quot;courier&amp;amp;quot; , monospace;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;courier new&amp;amp;quot; , &amp;amp;quot;courier&amp;amp;quot; , monospace;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;node3&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;mgmt&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;1&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; 1&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; 1068&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;node0&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;master&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;courier new&amp;amp;quot; , &amp;amp;quot;courier&amp;amp;quot; , monospace;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;courier new&amp;amp;quot; , &amp;amp;quot;courier&amp;amp;quot; , monospace;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;node3&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;vldb&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;1&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; 1&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; 98&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;node0&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;master&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;courier new&amp;amp;quot; , &amp;amp;quot;courier&amp;amp;quot; , monospace;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;node3&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;vifmgr&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;1&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; 1&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; 350&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; node0&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;master&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;node3&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;bcomd&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; 1&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; 1&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; 56&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;node0&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;master&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;node3&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;crs&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; 1&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; 1&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; 88&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;node0&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;master&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;node4&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;mgmt&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;1&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; 1&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; 1068&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;node0&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;secondary&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;node4&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;vldb&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;1&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; 1&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; 98&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;node0&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;secondary&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;node4&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;vifmgr&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;1&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; 1&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; 350&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; node0&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;secondary&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;node4&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;bcomd&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; 1&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; 1&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; 56&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;node0&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;secondary&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;node4&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;crs&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; 1&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; 1&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; 88&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;node0&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;secondary&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;courier new&amp;amp;quot; , &amp;amp;quot;courier&amp;amp;quot; , monospace;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;20 entries were displayed.&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;courier new&amp;amp;quot; , &amp;amp;quot;courier&amp;amp;quot; , monospace;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;ul&amp;gt;&amp;lt;li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: inherit;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;Now we&amp;#39;ll need to disable SFO (storage failover) for the two old nodes.&amp;amp;nbsp;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/ul&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;courier new&amp;amp;quot; , &amp;amp;quot;courier&amp;amp;quot; , monospace;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;labnetapp01::*&amp;amp;gt; storage failover modify -node node1 -enabled false&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;courier new&amp;amp;quot; , &amp;amp;quot;courier&amp;amp;quot; , monospace;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;labnetapp01::*&amp;amp;gt; storage failover modify -node node2 -enabled false&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;courier new&amp;amp;quot; , &amp;amp;quot;courier&amp;amp;quot; , monospace;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;ul&amp;gt;&amp;lt;li&amp;gt;Verify that storage failover is disabled by running &amp;quot;storage failover show&amp;quot;. You&amp;#39;ll see a value of &amp;quot;False&amp;quot; under the &amp;quot;Possible&amp;quot; column.&amp;amp;nbsp;&amp;lt;/li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;li&amp;gt;Now we&amp;#39;re finally ready to do the actual cluster unjoin! After waiting for some time, you&amp;#39;ll see a success message if nothing went catastrophically wrong.&amp;amp;nbsp;&amp;lt;/li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/ul&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;courier new&amp;amp;quot; , &amp;amp;quot;courier&amp;amp;quot; , monospace;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;labnetapp01::*&amp;amp;gt; cluster unjoin -node node1&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;courier new&amp;amp;quot; , &amp;amp;quot;courier&amp;amp;quot; , monospace;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;courier new&amp;amp;quot; , &amp;amp;quot;courier&amp;amp;quot; , monospace;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;Warning: This command will unjoin node &amp;quot;node1&amp;quot; from the cluster. You must unjoin the failover partner as well. After the node is successfully unjoined, erase its configuration and init&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;courier new&amp;amp;quot; , &amp;amp;quot;courier&amp;amp;quot; , monospace;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;(4)&amp;quot; option from the boot menu.&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;courier new&amp;amp;quot; , &amp;amp;quot;courier&amp;amp;quot; , monospace;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;Do you want to continue? {y|n}: y&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;courier new&amp;amp;quot; , &amp;amp;quot;courier&amp;amp;quot; , monospace;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;[Job 47561] Cleaning cluster database[Job 47561] Job succeeded: Cluster unjoin succeeded&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;courier new&amp;amp;quot; , &amp;amp;quot;courier&amp;amp;quot; , monospace;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;courier new&amp;amp;quot; , &amp;amp;quot;courier&amp;amp;quot; , monospace;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;labnetapp01::*&amp;amp;gt; cluster unjoin -node node2&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;courier new&amp;amp;quot; , &amp;amp;quot;courier&amp;amp;quot; , monospace;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;courier new&amp;amp;quot; , &amp;amp;quot;courier&amp;amp;quot; , monospace;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;Warning: This command will unjoin node &amp;quot;node2&amp;quot; from the cluster. You must unjoin the failover partner as well. After the node is successfully unjoined, erase its configuration and init&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;courier new&amp;amp;quot; , &amp;amp;quot;courier&amp;amp;quot; , monospace;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;(4)&amp;quot; option from the boot menu.&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;courier new&amp;amp;quot; , &amp;amp;quot;courier&amp;amp;quot; , monospace;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;Do you want to continue? {y|n}: y&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: &amp;amp;quot;courier new&amp;amp;quot; , &amp;amp;quot;courier&amp;amp;quot; , monospace;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;[Job 47561] Cleaning cluster database[Job 47561] Job succeeded: Cluster unjoin succeeded&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: inherit;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;That&amp;#39;s it for the cluster unjoin. After this process, you&amp;#39;ll be ready to power down and physically remove the old storage. Thanks for reading!&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;Disclaimer: This is a lab - I am not responsible for breaking your stuff if you run this in production and something gets borked.&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&lt;/content&gt;&lt;link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='https://www.blogger.com/feeds/3947691530317823276/posts/default/8845424255856619070'/&gt;&lt;link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='https://www.blogger.com/feeds/3947691530317823276/posts/default/8845424255856619070'/&gt;&lt;link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='https://www.langhq.com/2018/08/how-to-unjoin-netapp-nodes-from-cluster.html' title='How To: Unjoin NetApp Nodes from a Cluster'/&gt;&lt;author&gt;&lt;name&gt;Donny Lang&lt;/name&gt;&lt;uri&gt;http://www.blogger.com/profile/04332684287885880604&lt;/uri&gt;&lt;email&gt;<span class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="ea8485988f9a8693aa8886858d8d8f98c4898587">[email&#160;protected]</span>&lt;/email&gt;&lt;gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='32' height='32' src='//1.bp.blogspot.com/-JafglNogKoE/WsfNRWPGLRI/AAAAAAAAOwA/ct7A0f4IRrMkD4AQSqkjb4FXdWMmsSSYgCK4BGAYYCw/s49/2018-04-06%2B14_39_55-Donny%2BLang%2B%2528%2540DonnyLang1%2529%2B_%2BTwitter.png'/&gt;&lt;/author&gt;&lt;/entry&gt;&lt;entry&gt;&lt;id&gt;tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-3947691530317823276.post-5020916517063159042&lt;/id&gt;&lt;published&gt;2018-07-03T11:55:00.000-07:00&lt;/published&gt;&lt;updated&gt;2018-07-03T11:55:35.939-07:00&lt;/updated&gt;&lt;title type='text'&gt;Step up your HTTP security header game with NetScaler Rewrite Policies&lt;/title&gt;&lt;content type='html'&gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-_1duUCdP7YE/WzqHSV0kC7I/AAAAAAAARQ8/B_1CJrzRKZcqzUh23CfC7MWon3ABVfseACPcBGAYYCw/s1600/netscaler-logo.png&amp;quot; imageanchor=&amp;quot;1&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;img border=&amp;quot;0&amp;quot; data-original-height=&amp;quot;124&amp;quot; data-original-width=&amp;quot;315&amp;quot; src=&amp;quot;https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-_1duUCdP7YE/WzqHSV0kC7I/AAAAAAAARQ8/B_1CJrzRKZcqzUh23CfC7MWon3ABVfseACPcBGAYYCw/s1600/netscaler-logo.png&amp;quot; /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;There are a number of HTTP response headers that exist to increase web site security. If set properly, they can ensure that your site is less exposed to many common web vulnerabilities. By no means are these descriptions exhaustive, so I have included some references that can provide a more in-depth explanation at the bottom of each section. I&amp;#39;d also like to give a shout-out to the &amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://www.owasp.org/index.php/OWASP_Secure_Headers_Project&amp;quot;&amp;gt;OWASP Secure Headers Project&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;amp;nbsp;and &amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://twitter.com/Scott_Helme&amp;quot;&amp;gt;Scott Helme&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; of &amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://securityheaders.com/&amp;quot;&amp;gt;securityheaders.com&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;amp;nbsp;- thank you!&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;Note: Screenshots are from a NetScaler VPX 12.1 - if you are running a different version, the screenshots may look different, but the logic is the same. So that I have something to bind these policies to, I&amp;#39;ve also already created a load-balancing virtual server named lb_web_ssl and a Service Group for two TurnKey LAMP servers on the back-end.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;u&amp;gt;X-Frame-Options&amp;lt;/u&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;The X-Frame-Options header is designed to guard against clickjacking (an attack where malicious content is hidden beneath a clickable button or element on a web site) by preventing a site&amp;#39;s content from being displayed in other sites. There are three possible directives for this setting - DENY, SAMEORIGIN, and ALLOW FROM [domain]. We&amp;#39;ll be using the SAMEORIGIN directive, so that only frames that originate from the same page that they are being displayed are allowed.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;Create the Rewrite Action within the NetScaler GUI:&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-7wT5U7hg0bU/WzqI3MWGPBI/AAAAAAAARSU/RlVxNUN8NKYWAV4GeTV-iKLEtlN5KRq5QCEwYBhgL/s1600/xframe-action.png&amp;quot; imageanchor=&amp;quot;1&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;img border=&amp;quot;0&amp;quot; data-original-height=&amp;quot;515&amp;quot; data-original-width=&amp;quot;634&amp;quot; height=&amp;quot;516&amp;quot; src=&amp;quot;https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-7wT5U7hg0bU/WzqI3MWGPBI/AAAAAAAARSU/RlVxNUN8NKYWAV4GeTV-iKLEtlN5KRq5QCEwYBhgL/s640/xframe-action.png&amp;quot; width=&amp;quot;640&amp;quot; /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;Once the Action is created, create the Rewrite Policy as shown:&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-aF8-fTpQgZw/WzqI3xEjRiI/AAAAAAAARR8/niJuPCK9WeILXw5sLg8ZxFkUHrYQ9_dTQCEwYBhgL/s1600/xframe-policy.png&amp;quot; imageanchor=&amp;quot;1&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;img border=&amp;quot;0&amp;quot; data-original-height=&amp;quot;507&amp;quot; data-original-width=&amp;quot;386&amp;quot; height=&amp;quot;640&amp;quot; src=&amp;quot;https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-aF8-fTpQgZw/WzqI3xEjRiI/AAAAAAAARR8/niJuPCK9WeILXw5sLg8ZxFkUHrYQ9_dTQCEwYBhgL/s640/xframe-policy.png&amp;quot; width=&amp;quot;484&amp;quot; /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;From there, you can just bind your newly created Rewrite Policy to the LB vserver as a Response policy. Make sure you select the &amp;quot;NEXT&amp;quot; Goto Expression instead of&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;quot;END&amp;quot;, since we&amp;#39;ll be adding more policies after this one.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;pre style=&amp;quot;background: #f0f0f0; border: 1px dashed #cccccc; color: black; font-family: &amp;amp;quot;arial&amp;amp;quot;; font-size: 12px; height: auto; line-height: 20px; overflow: auto; padding: 0px; text-align: left; width: 99%;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;code style=&amp;quot;color: black; word-wrap: normal;&amp;quot;&amp;gt; add rewrite action rwact_insert_xframe insert_http_header X-Frame-Options &amp;quot;SAMEORIGIN&amp;quot; &nbsp;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt; add rewrite policy rwpol_insert_xframe HTTP.REQ.IS_VALID rwact_insert_xframe &nbsp;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt; bind lb vserver lb_web_ssl -policyName rwpol_insert_xframe -priority 100 -gotoPriorityExpression NEXT -type RESPONSE &nbsp;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/code&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/pre&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-size: x-small;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;References:&amp;amp;nbsp;&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7034&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-size: x-small;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7034&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/X-Frame-Options&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-size: x-small;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/X-Frame-Options&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;u&amp;gt;X-XSS-Protection&amp;lt;/u&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;u&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/u&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;The X-XSS-Protection header controls the Cross-Site-Scripting filter in your computer&amp;#39;s web browser. Setting a value of &amp;quot;1&amp;quot; will enable the filter and instruct the browser to sanitize the page if a XSS attack is detected. The &amp;quot;mode=block&amp;quot; value will cause the browser to prevent the rendering of the page entirely rather than simply sanitizing the page.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;Configure Rewrite Action:&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; bind lb vserver lb_web_ssl -policyName rwpol_insert_xss_header -priority 110 -gotoPriorityExpressi&amp;lt;/code&amp;gt;on NEXT -type RESPONSE &nbsp;&amp;lt;/pre&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;References:&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/X-XSS-Protection&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-size: x-small;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/X-XSS-Protection&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;u&amp;gt;X-Content-Type-Options&amp;lt;/u&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;When a client (such as web browser) encounters a page with a missing MIME type (a way for sites to indicate the type of content that is being displayed) or one it believes to be incorrect, it can perform MIME type sniffing, where it attempts to &amp;quot;guess&amp;quot; the MIME type. The X-Content-Type Options header&amp;#39;s function is to specify that the MIME types shouldn&amp;#39;t be changed by the browser.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;Configure Rewrite Action:&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-llQh2-Krp0c/WzqIym-Nw2I/AAAAAAAARSg/CYx9Y6XBT10paurvSJ4x8AnK7eyqZqCIgCEwYBhgL/s1600/content-type-action.png&amp;quot; imageanchor=&amp;quot;1&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;img border=&amp;quot;0&amp;quot; data-original-height=&amp;quot;484&amp;quot; data-original-width=&amp;quot;514&amp;quot; /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;Configure Rewrite Policy:&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; add rewrite policy rwpol_insert_content_type true rwact_insert_content_type_header &nbsp;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt; bind lb vserver lb_web_ssl -policyName rwpol_insert_content_type -priority 120 -gotoPriorityExpression NEXT -type RESPONSE &nbsp;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/code&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/pre&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;References:&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/X-Content-Type-Options&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-size: x-small;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/X-Content-Type-Options&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Basics_of_HTTP/MIME_types#MIME_sniffing&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-size: x-small;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Basics_of_HTTP/MIME_types#MIME_sniffing&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Basics_of_HTTP/MIME_types&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-size: x-small;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Basics_of_HTTP/MIME_types&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;u&amp;gt;X-Permitted-Cross-Domain-Policies&amp;lt;/u&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;A cross-domain policy is an XML file that determine what sort of information a site is allowed to fetch from other domains (for example, .swf or .pdf files, but not necessarily limited to those file types). The possible values for this header are as below:&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-oT8pgM44sD8/WzuRbJ-eTqI/AAAAAAAARTg/FRe44p60C3MmNnRKsGQQ6_QU_LWkZNrWQCLcBGAs/s1600/xdomain-table.png&amp;quot; imageanchor=&amp;quot;1&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;img border=&amp;quot;0&amp;quot; data-original-height=&amp;quot;164&amp;quot; data-original-width=&amp;quot;854&amp;quot; height=&amp;quot;122&amp;quot; src=&amp;quot;https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-oT8pgM44sD8/WzuRbJ-eTqI/AAAAAAAARTg/FRe44p60C3MmNnRKsGQQ6_QU_LWkZNrWQCLcBGAs/s640/xdomain-table.png&amp;quot; width=&amp;quot;640&amp;quot; /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-size: x-small;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;Source: https://owasp.org&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;The value that is correct for your site will depend heavily on the way that the site is designed. For my lab environment, I&amp;#39;ll be setting the value to &amp;quot;none&amp;quot;.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;Configure Rewrite Action:&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-JFd2dpTBMyM/WzqI2SfHpYI/AAAAAAAARSc/ojNfDkRkB4gVrZ_FW1VH6nqTSQVWN15NgCEwYBhgL/s1600/xdomain-action.png&amp;quot; word-wrap: normal;&amp;quot;&amp;gt; add rewrite action rwact_insert_xdomain_policies insert_http_header X-Permitted-Cross-Domain-Policies &amp;quot;\&amp;quot;none\&amp;quot;&amp;quot; &nbsp;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt; add rewrite policy rwpol_insert_xdomain_policies true rwact_insert_xdomain_policies &nbsp;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt; bind lb vserver lb_web_ssl -policyName rwpol_insert_xdomain_policies -priority 130 -gotoPriorityExpression NEXT -type RESPONSE &nbsp;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/code&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/pre&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;References:&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://www.owasp.org/index.php/OWASP_Secure_Headers_Project#xpcdp&amp;quot;&amp;gt;https://www.owasp.org/index.php/OWASP_Secure_Headers_Project#xpcdp&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://www.adobe.com/devnet-docs/acrobatetk/tools/AppSec/xdomain.html&amp;quot;&amp;gt;https://www.adobe.com/devnet-docs/acrobatetk/tools/AppSec/xdomain.html&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;u&amp;gt;Referrer-Policy&amp;lt;/u&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;When a user clicks on a link to another site, the Referer header conveys information to the destination site about the source URL of the request. Typically, this information is used for site analytics and tracking. The Referrer-Policy specifies what type of information is sent. There are several different options that suit many different use cases - check out the Mozilla Developer Network link below for a list of the options and also some helpful examples of the types of information that is sent based on the different options. I&amp;#39;ll be setting the &amp;quot;no-referrer&amp;quot; value, which omits the Referer header from the HTTP request entirely.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;Configure Rewrite Action:&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-5ujwpV74pVU/WzqI0mIEEtI/AAAAAAAARSY/Dkn967apQGwxj6NW53V2N7JUZKRrdMOoACEwYBhgL/s1600/referrer-policy-action.png&amp;quot; /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;Configure Rewrite Policy:&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-tLbtiwtMMiA/WzqI1L35X-I/AAAAAAAARSM/31Kdos6IfRECsFiGw3J8hYNEtxYoNKbcACEwYBhgL/s1600/referrer-policy-policy.png&amp;quot; /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;CLI commands:&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;pre style=&amp;quot;background: #f0f0f0; border: 1px dashed #cccccc; add rewrite policy rwpol_insert_referrer_policy true rwact_insert_referrer_policy &nbsp;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt; bind lb vserver lb_web_ssl -policyName rwpol_insert_referrer_policy -priority 140 -gotoPriorityExpression NEXT -type RESPONSE &nbsp;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/code&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/pre&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;References:&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://www.owasp.org/index.php/OWASP_Secure_Headers_Project#rp&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-size: x-small;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;https://www.owasp.org/index.php/OWASP_Secure_Headers_Project#rp&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://www.w3.org/TR/referrer-policy/&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-size: x-small;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;https://www.w3.org/TR/referrer-policy/&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/Referrer-Policy&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-size: x-small;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/Referrer-Policy&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;u&amp;gt;HTTP Strict Transport Security (HSTS)&amp;lt;/u&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;HTTP Strict Transport Security is a way for sites to specify that clients can only browse the site via HTTPS. The &amp;quot;max-age&amp;quot; directive determines how long a client should remember that a site should only be accessed via HTPS. The optional includeSubDomains directive determines (surprise!) whether or not the site&amp;#39;s subdomains fall under the same rule and are served by HTTPS only. Finally, the &amp;quot;preload&amp;quot; directive specifies your desire to be included in Google&amp;#39;s HSTS preload list. You can test your site&amp;#39;s eligibility for the HSTS preload list by visiting&amp;amp;nbsp;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://hstspreload.org/&amp;quot;&amp;gt;https://hstspreload.org&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; and putting in your domain. If you&amp;#39;re not eligible, the site gives you remediation steps as well.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;Note: As of version 12.0, you can also accomplish this via SSL Policies instead of Rewrite Policies - please see&amp;amp;nbsp;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://support.citrix.com/article/CTX224172&amp;quot;&amp;gt;https://support.citrix.com/article/CTX224172&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; for more information.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;Configure Rewrite Action:&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both; &nbsp;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt; add rewrite policy rwpol_insert_hsts true rwact_insert_hsts &nbsp;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt; bind lb vserver lb_web_ssl -policyName rwpol_insert_hsts -priority 150 -gotoPriorityExpression NEXT -type RESPONSE &nbsp;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/code&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/pre&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;References:&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6797&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-size: x-small;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6797&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-size: x-small;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/Strict-Transport-Security&amp;quot;&amp;gt;https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/Strict-Transport-Security&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://hstspreload.org/&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-size: x-small;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;https://hstspreload.org&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;u&amp;gt;Expect-CT&amp;lt;/u&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;The Expect-CT header is a relatively new HTTP header that allows web site owners to take advantage of the Certificate Transparency framework by rejecting connections to a site with a compromised SSL certificate -&amp;amp;nbsp; for example, if a public CA mistakenly or maliciously issues a&amp;amp;nbsp; certificate. When using the &amp;quot;enforce&amp;quot; directive, browsers will reject connections that do not meet the Certificate Transparency requirements; omitting the directive will result in a &amp;quot;report-only&amp;quot; configuration where violations are reported to the specified location, but not actively rejected.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;Configure Rewrite Action:&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;Configure Rewrite Policy:&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-5UR1Ex3K9Y8/WzqIzerkHnI/AAAAAAAARSQ/mJrtSZ7EO9Q6AuzAn7bQ0S5I477qlrN2gCEwYBhgL/s1600/expect-ct-policy.png&amp;quot;
