word-wrap: normal;&amp;quot;&amp;gt; add rewrite action rwact_insert_expect-ct insert_http_header Expect-CT &amp;quot;\&amp;quot;max-age=86400, enforce, report-uri=https://example.com/ct-report\&amp;quot;&amp;quot; &nbsp;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt; add rewrite policy rwpol_insert_expect-ct true rwact_insert_expect-ct &nbsp;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt; bind lb vserver lb_web_ssl -policyName rwpol_insert_expect-ct -priority 160 -gotoPriorityExpression NEXT -type RESPONSE &nbsp;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/code&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/pre&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;References:&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-ietf-httpbis-expect-ct-02&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-size: x-small;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-ietf-httpbis-expect-ct-02&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-size: x-small;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/Expect-CT&amp;quot;&amp;gt;https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/Expect-CT&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://www.certificate-transparency.org/&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-size: x-small;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;https://www.certificate-transparency.org/&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;u&amp;gt;Content-Security-Policy&amp;lt;/u&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;The Content-Security-Policy header&amp;#39;s primary goal is to be another layer of defense against XSS (cross-site scripting) attacks by controlling what external content is allowed to be loaded on the site. However, it can also protect you against other types of attacks by restricting which protocols are allowed to be used to load content (for example, disallowing content delivered via HTTP). There are many different directives that can be used to control what content is allowed to load - for the full list, check out the link in the references section. I&amp;#39;ll be using the default-src, script-src, style-src, and img-src directives in my example and only allowing content to load from the site itself.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;Configure Rewrite Action:&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;CLI commands:&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;pre style=&amp;quot;background: #f0f0f0; border: 1px dashed #cccccc; color: black; word-wrap: normal;&amp;quot;&amp;gt; add rewrite action rwact_insert_csp insert_http_header Content-Security-Policy &amp;quot;\&amp;quot;default-src \&amp;#39;self\&amp;#39; ; script-src \&amp;#39;self\&amp;#39; ; style-src \&amp;#39;self\&amp;#39; ; img-src \&amp;#39;self\&amp;#39; data:\&amp;quot;&amp;quot; &nbsp;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt; add rewrite policy rwpol_insert_csp true rwact_insert_csp &nbsp;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt; bind lb vserver lb_web_ssl -policyName rwpol_insert_csp -priority 170 -gotoPriorityExpression END -type RESPONSE &nbsp;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/code&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/pre&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;References:&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-size: x-small;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/CSP&amp;quot;&amp;gt;https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/CSP&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;u&amp;gt;Conclusion&amp;lt;/u&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;u&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/u&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;text-align: left;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;After all of our policies have been applied, here is what your Rewrite Policy bindings should look like. Keep in mind that if you add more policies later, be sure to change the last Goto Expression to NEXT instead of END so that policy processing works as expected.&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;text-align: left;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-8lr7csMFs8U/WzvAPK5B8iI/AAAAAAAARUQ/Eblz2lyTQaEDmNGGSlhFtaaiPm3pcENBgCLcBGAs/s1600/bound-policies.png&amp;quot; imageanchor=&amp;quot;1&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;img border=&amp;quot;0&amp;quot; data-original-height=&amp;quot;494&amp;quot; data-original-width=&amp;quot;887&amp;quot; height=&amp;quot;356&amp;quot; src=&amp;quot;https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-8lr7csMFs8U/WzvAPK5B8iI/AAAAAAAARUQ/Eblz2lyTQaEDmNGGSlhFtaaiPm3pcENBgCLcBGAs/s640/bound-policies.png&amp;quot; width=&amp;quot;640&amp;quot; /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;text-align: left;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;text-align: left;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;text-align: left;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;text-align: left;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;This is it, folks. the moment you&amp;#39;ve all been waiting for - has our hard work actually paid off? Is it even working? Enter &amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://securityheaders.com/&amp;quot;&amp;gt;securityheaders.com&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;, which is designed to rate sites based on how well they comply with the HTTP header security standards. After applying the policies we&amp;#39;ve created above, here is the Security Headers site output:&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;text-align: left;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-p-ravz69s94/WzqI1vSRv2I/AAAAAAAARSQ/2veSrLfeuWQk65OaA7iB-fR0I8uAsmeYgCEwYBhgL/s1600/securityheaders-output.png&amp;quot; imageanchor=&amp;quot;1&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;img border=&amp;quot;0&amp;quot; data-original-height=&amp;quot;763&amp;quot; data-original-width=&amp;quot;1269&amp;quot; height=&amp;quot;384&amp;quot; src=&amp;quot;https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-p-ravz69s94/WzqI1vSRv2I/AAAAAAAARSQ/2veSrLfeuWQk65OaA7iB-fR0I8uAsmeYgCEwYBhgL/s640/securityheaders-output.png&amp;quot; width=&amp;quot;640&amp;quot; /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;text-align: left;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;Success!&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;text-align: left;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;I&amp;#39;d probably also remove the Server header from the HTTP response so that it obscures the fact that there&amp;#39;s an Apache server behind the NetScaler, but it looks like it didn&amp;#39;t affect my score, so I&amp;#39;m going to leave it in.&amp;amp;nbsp;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;text-align: left;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;text-align: left;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;amp;nbsp;As I&amp;#39;ve said before, your specific site and use case may differ and will probably result in completely different values for the various directives that are outlined here. Hopefully this post will help you become familiar with what the different headers are and how their various settings will help keep your sites better protected. Thanks for reading!&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;text-align: left;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&lt;/content&gt;&lt;link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='https://www.blogger.com/feeds/3947691530317823276/posts/default/5020916517063159042'/&gt;&lt;link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='https://www.blogger.com/feeds/3947691530317823276/posts/default/5020916517063159042'/&gt;&lt;link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='https://www.langhq.com/2018/07/step-up-your-http-security-header-game.html' title='Step up your HTTP security header game with NetScaler Rewrite Policies'/&gt;&lt;author&gt;&lt;name&gt;Donny Lang&lt;/name&gt;&lt;uri&gt;http://www.blogger.com/profile/04332684287885880604&lt;/uri&gt;&lt;email&gt;<span class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="721c1d0017021e0b32101e1d151517005c111d1f">[email&#160;protected]</span>&lt;/email&gt;&lt;gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='32' height='32' src='//1.bp.blogspot.com/-JafglNogKoE/WsfNRWPGLRI/AAAAAAAAOwA/ct7A0f4IRrMkD4AQSqkjb4FXdWMmsSSYgCK4BGAYYCw/s49/2018-04-06%2B14_39_55-Donny%2BLang%2B%2528%2540DonnyLang1%2529%2B_%2BTwitter.png'/&gt;&lt;/author&gt;&lt;media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-_1duUCdP7YE/WzqHSV0kC7I/AAAAAAAARQ8/B_1CJrzRKZcqzUh23CfC7MWon3ABVfseACPcBGAYYCw/s72-c/netscaler-logo.png" height="72" width="72"/&gt;&lt;/entry&gt;&lt;entry&gt;&lt;id&gt;tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-3947691530317823276.post-4645242970633911509&lt;/id&gt;&lt;published&gt;2018-05-16T14:14:00.000-07:00&lt;/published&gt;&lt;updated&gt;2018-05-16T14:14:10.814-07:00&lt;/updated&gt;&lt;title type='text'&gt;vRealize Log Insight Overview&lt;/title&gt;&lt;content type='html'&gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-KSiH31dK5jg/WvyZ7CDn8pI/AAAAAAAAQWk/V6iv7a6Lqw8VNqpxr2ICDC9bv_r7n3CrgCLcBGAs/s1600/image3.png&amp;quot; imageanchor=&amp;quot;1&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;img border=&amp;quot;0&amp;quot; data-original-height=&amp;quot;146&amp;quot; data-original-width=&amp;quot;361&amp;quot; height=&amp;quot;257&amp;quot; src=&amp;quot;https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-KSiH31dK5jg/WvyZ7CDn8pI/AAAAAAAAQWk/V6iv7a6Lqw8VNqpxr2ICDC9bv_r7n3CrgCLcBGAs/s640/image3.png&amp;quot; width=&amp;quot;640&amp;quot; /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;vRealize Log Insight has been around for several years now, but I keep hearing people referencing the fact that many companies own it and don&amp;#39;t even realize it. Let&amp;#39;s change all that!&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;For those of you not aware, vRealize Log Insight (hereafter referred to as vRLI because I&amp;#39;m lazy and don&amp;#39;t want to type out the whole name) is a log management and analytics solution from VMware. It ingests syslog data from various sources - not just vSphere/ESXi! - and displays all that data in easy-to-understand and customizable dashboards while at the same time providing a powerful analytics engine, giving easily searchable structure to unstructured data. It&amp;#39;s a really helpful tool for me, so I will provide an overview to get you familiar at a high-level with its features.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;As a side note: while not specific to vRLI, having a centralized location for syslog data makes correlating issues between layers of the technology stack much easier than trying to remember what system logs where during an outage. Even if you don&amp;#39;t use vRLI, I believe it&amp;#39;s always a good idea to get your logs off the device that is generating said logs, for both security and ease of troubleshooting.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;u&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;color: orange; font-family: inherit; font-size: x-large;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;Available Versions&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/u&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;After that elevator pitch for why you want vRLI for centralized log management/analytics, you are probably asking yourself &amp;quot;how do I get my hands on this?&amp;quot; and you&amp;#39;ll be glad to hear that there are a few different ways you can accomplish that goal. This is (in part) what I was making mention of earlier when I said that you might already own it. At the time of this writing, there are three different &amp;quot;versions&amp;quot; of vRLI, and each will grant you different features. There is a nice feature comparison matrix over at &amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://www.vmware.com/products/vrealize-log-insight.html&amp;quot;&amp;gt;https://www.vmware.com/products/vrealize-log-insight.html&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; that describes the feature availability, so I won&amp;#39;t dive deep on ALL the differences but will cover the major ones.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: inherit;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;color: orange; font-family: inherit;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;vRealize Log Insight for vCenter Server&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;If you own vCenter Server Standard (or above), you are entitled to 25 OSI licenses of vRealize Log Insight. VMware defines an OSI, or Operating System Instance, as &amp;quot;any server, virtual or physical, with an IP address that generates logs, including network devices and storage arrays&amp;quot;. This licensing tier will get you a fully functional vRLI instance with access to Dashboards and Interactive Analytics, but you miss out on the advanced features available in the full version (clustering, high availability, event forwarding, archiving, and the ability to install custom and/or 3rd party content packs).&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;color: orange;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;vRealize Log Insight for NSX&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;When you purchase a CPU license for NSX (VMware&amp;#39;s security and network virtualization product) you will also receive a 1 CPU entitlement for vRLI. Technically, this is the full version of vRLI, but there are some limitations - namely, you are only entitled to vSphere and NSX log events, and you are supposed to only install vSphere and NSX content packs. However, it does enable you to use those advanced features not available to users of the vCenter Server-specific version.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;color: orange;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;Full vRealize Log Insight&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;A license for the full version of vRLI can be purchased per physical CPU, or granted as part of the vCloud or vRealize suite licensing. The full version offers unrestricted functionality of all features. If you are planning to use vRLI for managing more than just vSphere logs, the full version is worth seriously considering. The added features definitely make it a more &amp;quot;enterprise-ready&amp;quot; solution - especially clustering and HA.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;white-space: pre;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;color: orange;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;Interface Overview - Dashboards&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;The vRLI interface is split into two main parts - Dashboards and Interactive Analytics. We&amp;#39;ll start with the Dashboards view, which is great for viewing trends and historical information. The default dashboards are actually pretty useful out-of-the-box, but the real magic is the ability to clone and customize the dashboards to fit the use cases for your environment. As you can see from the screenshot below, there are also a wide variety of Content Packs that are available to extend vRLI&amp;#39;s log management functionality to other VMware products and vendors outside of VMware. All the available content packs can be found on VMware&amp;#39;s &amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://marketplace.vmware.com/vsx/&amp;quot;&amp;gt;Solution Exchange&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-7fO8oebxtyw/WvyP3W8P3TI/AAAAAAAAQWI/KjDEH_YGZPQ7lPvay2nfhigqHinHQb_DgCLcBGAs/s1600/image1.png&amp;quot; imageanchor=&amp;quot;1&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;img border=&amp;quot;0&amp;quot; data-original-height=&amp;quot;492&amp;quot; data-original-width=&amp;quot;955&amp;quot; src=&amp;quot;https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-7fO8oebxtyw/WvyP3W8P3TI/AAAAAAAAQWI/KjDEH_YGZPQ7lPvay2nfhigqHinHQb_DgCLcBGAs/s1600/image1.png&amp;quot; /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;color: orange;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;Interface Overview - Interactive Analytics&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;The Interactive Analytics tab is where all of the raw data is aggregated, and is really great for digging into the raw log files (all searchable via customizable fields, of course) and correlating system events or doing root cause analysis. The screen is split into a visual representation of the number of events matching a particular query over a period of time (in this case 5 minutes) and the actual log entries themselves below that in text. I&amp;#39;d have to say that I spend most of my time in vRLI in this window, unless I&amp;#39;m working on building a dashboard.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-fbsg-5zKIC0/WvyS1es36HI/AAAAAAAAQWU/jkzv-YHWgug6GI6nVeHvGQxN9HS2xGW2wCLcBGAs/s1600/image2.png&amp;quot; imageanchor=&amp;quot;1&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;img border=&amp;quot;0&amp;quot; data-original-height=&amp;quot;501&amp;quot; data-original-width=&amp;quot;958&amp;quot; src=&amp;quot;https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-fbsg-5zKIC0/WvyS1es36HI/AAAAAAAAQWU/jkzv-YHWgug6GI6nVeHvGQxN9HS2xGW2wCLcBGAs/s1600/image2.png&amp;quot; /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;One other cool thing that vRLI does is offer integration into vRealize Operations Manager (vROPS). I could (and maybe will) do a whole separate post on vRLI/vROPS integration, but it will allow you to launch vRLI from within vROPS without having to open a separate window and even perform VM-specific log data searches directly from vROPS with the click of a button. Pretty neat.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;Obviously this quick post just scratches the surface of what vRLI can do, so if you want to learn more, there are a few great resources that you use to dive a bit deeper on all of vRLI&amp;#39;s capabilities:&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;ul&amp;gt;&amp;lt;li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://docs.vmware.com/en/vRealize-Log-Insight/4.6/log-insight-users-guide.pdf&amp;quot;&amp;gt;vRealize Log Insight 4.6 User&amp;#39;s Guide - VMware Docs&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://docs.vmware.com/en/vRealize-Log-Insight/4.6/log-insight-getting-started-guide.pdf&amp;quot;&amp;gt;Getting Started with vRealize Log Insight - VMware Docs&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;http://labs.hol.vmware.com/HOL/catalogs/lab/4258&amp;quot;&amp;gt;HOL-1806-01-CMP - vRealize Suite - Getting Started - VMware Hands-On-Labs&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/li&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/ul&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;Thanks for reading!&lt;/content&gt;&lt;link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='https://www.blogger.com/feeds/3947691530317823276/posts/default/4645242970633911509'/&gt;&lt;link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='https://www.blogger.com/feeds/3947691530317823276/posts/default/4645242970633911509'/&gt;&lt;link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='https://www.langhq.com/2018/05/vrealize-log-insight-overview.html' title='vRealize Log Insight Overview'/&gt;&lt;author&gt;&lt;name&gt;Donny Lang&lt;/name&gt;&lt;uri&gt;http://www.blogger.com/profile/04332684287885880604&lt;/uri&gt;&lt;email&gt;<span class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="234d4c5146534f5a63414f4c444446510d404c4e">[email&#160;protected]</span>&lt;/email&gt;&lt;gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='32' height='32' src='//1.bp.blogspot.com/-JafglNogKoE/WsfNRWPGLRI/AAAAAAAAOwA/ct7A0f4IRrMkD4AQSqkjb4FXdWMmsSSYgCK4BGAYYCw/s49/2018-04-06%2B14_39_55-Donny%2BLang%2B%2528%2540DonnyLang1%2529%2B_%2BTwitter.png'/&gt;&lt;/author&gt;&lt;media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-KSiH31dK5jg/WvyZ7CDn8pI/AAAAAAAAQWk/V6iv7a6Lqw8VNqpxr2ICDC9bv_r7n3CrgCLcBGAs/s72-c/image3.png" height="72" width="72"/&gt;&lt;/entry&gt;&lt;entry&gt;&lt;id&gt;tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-3947691530317823276.post-8130409274475408308&lt;/id&gt;&lt;published&gt;2018-04-25T13:09:00.001-07:00&lt;/published&gt;&lt;updated&gt;2018-04-25T15:11:08.639-07:00&lt;/updated&gt;&lt;title type='text'&gt;Cisco UCS Platform Emulator Installation&lt;/title&gt;&lt;content type='html'&gt;To continue my series of posts on building the framework for a functional lab environment, I&amp;#39;d like to talk about the Cisco UCS Platform Emulator (UCSPE). It is a software appliance packaged as a vSphere OVA that approximates a UCS deployment, including the networking components (a pair of switches called the Fabric Interconnects) and both blade and rackmount UCS servers (B- and C-Series, respectively). It can be a great tool for learning and becoming more familiar with the UCS platform. I will be deploying my UCSPE on vSphere 6.7 in my lab, but it should work similarly in other recent versions.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;1. Start by downloading the UCS Platform Emulator OVA from &amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://communities.cisco.com/docs/DOC-71877&amp;quot;&amp;gt;https://communities.cisco.com/docs/DOC-71877&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; - you will need a Cisco Connection Online (CCO) login in order to begin the download. I am using version 3.1(2ePE1) of the emulator for this guide as that appeared to be the latest version available at the time of writing. Side note, I also noticed during the boot process that this version of the UCSPE was called GALVANIZED GORILLA, which I found hilarious.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;2. Deploy the OVA template from the vSphere Web Client, following the steps and filling in name and networking information that is relevant to your environment. Below are the settings I used for my emulator VM, but obviously yours will be different.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-Yptx_SH7ZgI/WuDZiyRwY-I/AAAAAAAAPZk/jgRODt9FyE0OedeuIzpHsb8ScOsutTeXgCLcBGAs/s1600/image1.png&amp;quot; imageanchor=&amp;quot;1&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: left; float: left; margin-bottom: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;img border=&amp;quot;0&amp;quot; data-original-height=&amp;quot;651&amp;quot; data-original-width=&amp;quot;871&amp;quot; height=&amp;quot;476&amp;quot; src=&amp;quot;https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-Yptx_SH7ZgI/WuDZiyRwY-I/AAAAAAAAPZk/jgRODt9FyE0OedeuIzpHsb8ScOsutTeXgCLcBGAs/s640/image1.png&amp;quot; width=&amp;quot;640&amp;quot; /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;3. Once the import is complete, you can power on the UCSPE VM. It will boot and run through its inital configuration, after which you&amp;#39;ll be presented with a login prompt. The credentials are as follows:&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;User Name: ucspe&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;Password: ucspe&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;Once you log in, you&amp;#39;ll be presented with the menu below.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-_iZAehQq4NQ/WuDZpNcz7lI/AAAAAAAAPZo/jgMrZ6m6I-oFZSsUBENpNNphTFHuK-A8gCLcBGAs/s1600/image2.png&amp;quot; imageanchor=&amp;quot;1&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: left; float: left; margin-bottom: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;img border=&amp;quot;0&amp;quot; data-original-height=&amp;quot;638&amp;quot; data-original-width=&amp;quot;611&amp;quot; height=&amp;quot;640&amp;quot; src=&amp;quot;https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-_iZAehQq4NQ/WuDZpNcz7lI/AAAAAAAAPZo/jgMrZ6m6I-oFZSsUBENpNNphTFHuK-A8gCLcBGAs/s640/image2.png&amp;quot; width=&amp;quot;611&amp;quot; /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;Note: We&amp;#39;ll be using a statically assigned address for our deployment, but the UCSPE can use DHCP addresses as well.&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;You will need three IPs for the UCSPE deployment - one for the virtual IP (VIP), and one each for the Fabric Interconnect management interfaces. We&amp;#39;ll be using the following IPs:&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;VIP: 10.20.21.115/24&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;FI A: 10.20.21.116/24&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;FI B: 10.20.21.117/24&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;Gateway IP: 10.20.21.1&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;4. Select the &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;Modify Network Settings&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt; option by pressing the &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;n&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt; key.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;5. When asked if you want to modify the network connections, press&amp;amp;nbsp;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;y&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-Fpmp3y1NzTM/WuDatIduVxI/AAAAAAAAPZ4/SBeeZlfOchAZLKY8EV2ZG7ucqwU2g5p8wCLcBGAs/s1600/image3.png&amp;quot; imageanchor=&amp;quot;1&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: left; float: left; margin-bottom: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;img border=&amp;quot;0&amp;quot; data-original-height=&amp;quot;472&amp;quot; data-original-width=&amp;quot;634&amp;quot; height=&amp;quot;476&amp;quot; src=&amp;quot;https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-Fpmp3y1NzTM/WuDatIduVxI/AAAAAAAAPZ4/SBeeZlfOchAZLKY8EV2ZG7ucqwU2g5p8wCLcBGAs/s640/image3.png&amp;quot; width=&amp;quot;640&amp;quot; /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;6. Select the &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;Custom&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt; option by hitting &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;c&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt; and then enter the IP information you&amp;#39;ve chosen for your environment. Once the gateway IP is entered and you hit &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;Enter&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;, the network interfaces will be restarted to make the configuration changes active.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-jRbiv1vTqhw/WuDcP17IB4I/AAAAAAAAPaE/tXFsuUBsITI5WruInVrv7gR57u5Yb_CiwCLcBGAs/s1600/image4.png&amp;quot; imageanchor=&amp;quot;1&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: left; float: left; margin-bottom: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;img border=&amp;quot;0&amp;quot; data-original-height=&amp;quot;581&amp;quot; data-original-width=&amp;quot;726&amp;quot; height=&amp;quot;512&amp;quot; src=&amp;quot;https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-jRbiv1vTqhw/WuDcP17IB4I/AAAAAAAAPaE/tXFsuUBsITI5WruInVrv7gR57u5Yb_CiwCLcBGAs/s640/image4.png&amp;quot; width=&amp;quot;640&amp;quot; /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;7. After that is complete, the UCSPE will restart and continue its initial configuration. This will take a few minutes (the &amp;quot;Inserting devices...&amp;quot; step in particular), so be patient. Eventually, the configuration will finish and you can return to the menu you saw before.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;8. At this point, you can open a Web browser and browse to &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;https://VIP_IP_ADDRESS&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;. You&amp;#39;ll be presented with a Hardware Inventory screen like the one below.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-0xW9DjIl9Kw/WuDcdoQidAI/AAAAAAAAPaI/oxEIWLYcxlEYRnLzErBIzO2XWPqwaX03ACLcBGAs/s1600/image5.png&amp;quot; imageanchor=&amp;quot;1&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: left; float: left; margin-bottom: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;img border=&amp;quot;0&amp;quot; data-original-height=&amp;quot;585&amp;quot; data-original-width=&amp;quot;1600&amp;quot; height=&amp;quot;233&amp;quot; src=&amp;quot;https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-0xW9DjIl9Kw/WuDcdoQidAI/AAAAAAAAPaI/oxEIWLYcxlEYRnLzErBIzO2XWPqwaX03ACLcBGAs/s640/image5.png&amp;quot; width=&amp;quot;640&amp;quot; /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;9. From there, you can click on the Triforce logo on the Hardware Inventory screen to launch UCS Manager (UCSM) and log in with the &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;ucspe &amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;user credentials.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-gc3fCVb444g/WuDc1rxv-LI/AAAAAAAAPaU/3GHqcUXJNr8_cEXY3ztI7g1SJatDI8OEgCLcBGAs/s1600/1000px-Triforce.svg.png&amp;quot; imageanchor=&amp;quot;1&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: left; float: left; margin-bottom: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;img border=&amp;quot;0&amp;quot; data-original-height=&amp;quot;869&amp;quot; data-original-width=&amp;quot;1000&amp;quot; height=&amp;quot;173&amp;quot; src=&amp;quot;https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-gc3fCVb444g/WuDc1rxv-LI/AAAAAAAAPaU/3GHqcUXJNr8_cEXY3ztI7g1SJatDI8OEgCLcBGAs/s200/1000px-Triforce.svg.png&amp;quot; width=&amp;quot;200&amp;quot; /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;I have been conditioned to hear the &amp;quot;A Link to the Past&amp;quot; SNES intro music when I see this logo.&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;10. After login, you&amp;#39;ll see a UCSM page that looks like the image below.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-SwRIm-5fMcU/WuDfrTJHnEI/AAAAAAAAPag/a79fryqMItYWHK7QPIg1esmavw2yzTr1wCLcBGAs/s1600/image6.png&amp;quot; imageanchor=&amp;quot;1&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: left; float: left; margin-bottom: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;img border=&amp;quot;0&amp;quot; data-original-height=&amp;quot;635&amp;quot; data-original-width=&amp;quot;1444&amp;quot; height=&amp;quot;280&amp;quot; src=&amp;quot;https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-SwRIm-5fMcU/WuDfrTJHnEI/AAAAAAAAPag/a79fryqMItYWHK7QPIg1esmavw2yzTr1wCLcBGAs/s640/image6.png&amp;quot; width=&amp;quot;640&amp;quot; /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;This concludes the initial UCSPE deployment. That being said, there is a LOT of functionality built into UCSM (and UCS in general) that is much different than managing a traditional rackmount server architecture. For me, the most difficult thing was getting an understanding of the policy-driven way that UCS resources are managed. Once I took the time to dig into the inner workings of Service Profiles though, it all began to make sense. Keep an eye out for future posts that discuss specific features of the UCS platform.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;As always, thanks for reading!&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&lt;/content&gt;&lt;link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='https://www.blogger.com/feeds/3947691530317823276/posts/default/8130409274475408308'/&gt;&lt;link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='https://www.blogger.com/feeds/3947691530317823276/posts/default/8130409274475408308'/&gt;&lt;link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='https://www.langhq.com/2018/04/cisco-ucs-platform-emulator-installation.html' title='Cisco UCS Platform Emulator Installation'/&gt;&lt;author&gt;&lt;name&gt;Donny Lang&lt;/name&gt;&lt;uri&gt;http://www.blogger.com/profile/04332684287885880604&lt;/uri&gt;&lt;email&gt;<span class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="543a3b263124382d1436383b333331267a373b39">[email&#160;protected]</span>&lt;/email&gt;&lt;gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='32' height='32' src='//1.bp.blogspot.com/-JafglNogKoE/WsfNRWPGLRI/AAAAAAAAOwA/ct7A0f4IRrMkD4AQSqkjb4FXdWMmsSSYgCK4BGAYYCw/s49/2018-04-06%2B14_39_55-Donny%2BLang%2B%2528%2540DonnyLang1%2529%2B_%2BTwitter.png'/&gt;&lt;/author&gt;&lt;media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-Yptx_SH7ZgI/WuDZiyRwY-I/AAAAAAAAPZk/jgRODt9FyE0OedeuIzpHsb8ScOsutTeXgCLcBGAs/s72-c/image1.png" height="72" width="72"/&gt;&lt;/entry&gt;&lt;entry&gt;&lt;id&gt;tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-3947691530317823276.post-4888170969466240912&lt;/id&gt;&lt;published&gt;2018-04-18T15:53:00.000-07:00&lt;/published&gt;&lt;updated&gt;2018-04-18T15:53:00.632-07:00&lt;/updated&gt;&lt;title type='text'&gt;NetApp ONTAP 9.3 Simulator Deployment – Part 2&lt;/title&gt;&lt;content type='html'&gt;&amp;lt;style type=&amp;quot;text/css&amp;quot;&amp;gt; &nbsp;@page { margin: 0.79in } &nbsp; p { margin-bottom: 0.1in; line-height: 120% } &nbsp;&amp;lt;/style&amp;gt; &nbsp;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;line-height: 100%; margin-bottom: 0in;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: inherit;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;In&amp;amp;nbsp;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://www.langhq.com/2018/04/netapp-simulate-ontap-93-deployment.html&amp;quot;&amp;gt;Part 1 of the deployment guide&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: inherit;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;, we learned how to deploy a single NetApp simulator on ESXi. For this post, I’d like to detail the process of adding a second simulator to the cluster. We did a lot of the legwork for the first node’s deployment, so adding the second node is a much shorter process.&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;line-height: 100%; margin-bottom: 0in;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: inherit;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;line-height: 100%; margin-bottom: 0in;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;line-height: 100%; margin-bottom: 0in;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: inherit;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;line-height: 100%; margin-bottom: 0in;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: inherit;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;1. Go through the steps to deploy the OVA package again just like the first simulator (refer to Part 1 steps 7-11 if needed)&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;line-height: 100%; margin-bottom: 0in;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: inherit;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;line-height: 100%; margin-bottom: 0in;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: inherit;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;2. Once the OVA has been deployed, boot the second simulator. This time, however, we’ll need to interrupt the boot process to access the LOADER prompt in order to change the system ID and serial number of the second simulator (two systems can’t have the same serial/system ID).&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: inherit;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: inherit;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;Press &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;Space Bar &amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;when you see the Hit [Enter] to boot immediately, or any other key for command prompt. Booting in 10 seconds... message. You’ll see a VLOADER&amp;amp;gt; prompt.&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;line-height: 100%; margin-bottom: 0in;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: inherit;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;line-height: 100%; margin-bottom: 0in;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: inherit;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;3. Run the &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;setenv SYS_SERIAL_NUM 4034389-06-2&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;amp;nbsp;and &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;setenv bootarg.nvram.sysid 4034389062&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;amp;nbsp;commands to set the serial number and system ID, respectively.&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;line-height: 100%; margin-bottom: 0in;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: inherit;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;line-height: 100%; margin-bottom: 0in;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-eaF-0fUC40A/WteuP0WN1GI/AAAAAAAAPRg/6NHAClhHzLQvH6rF4zpbWORt9pfdd08twCLcBGAs/s1600/image1.png&amp;quot; imageanchor=&amp;quot;1&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: left; float: left; margin-bottom: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: inherit;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;img border=&amp;quot;0&amp;quot; data-original-height=&amp;quot;92&amp;quot; data-original-width=&amp;quot;423&amp;quot; height=&amp;quot;137&amp;quot; src=&amp;quot;https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-eaF-0fUC40A/WteuP0WN1GI/AAAAAAAAPRg/6NHAClhHzLQvH6rF4zpbWORt9pfdd08twCLcBGAs/s640/image1.png&amp;quot; width=&amp;quot;640&amp;quot; /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: inherit;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;line-height: 100%; margin-bottom: 0in;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: inherit;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;line-height: 100%; margin-bottom: 0in;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: inherit;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: inherit;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: inherit;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: inherit;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: inherit;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: inherit;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: inherit;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: inherit;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: inherit;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;You can run the &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;printenv SYS_SERIAL_NUM&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;amp;nbsp;and &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;printenv bootarg.nvram.sysid&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt; commands to verify that the values were updated accordingly.&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;line-height: 100%; margin-bottom: 0in;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: inherit;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;line-height: 100%; margin-bottom: 0in;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: inherit;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;4. Enter the &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;boot&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt; command at the VLOADER prompt to boot the node.&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;line-height: 100%; margin-bottom: 0in;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: inherit;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;line-height: 100%; margin-bottom: 0in;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: inherit;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;5. When you see “Press Ctrl-C for Boot Menu”, press &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;Ctrl-C&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;. &nbsp;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;line-height: 100%; margin-bottom: 0in;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: inherit;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;line-height: 100%; margin-bottom: 0in;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: inherit;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;6. At the Boot Menu, choose option &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;4&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;.&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;line-height: 100%; margin-bottom: 0in;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: inherit;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;line-height: 100%; margin-bottom: 0in;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: inherit;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;line-height: 100%; Hit &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;y&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt; when asked if you want to zero the disks, reset the config, and install a new filesystem. Hit &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;y&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt; again to confirm. The node will reboot. As with the first node, this process will take several minutes.&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;line-height: 100%; margin-bottom: 0in;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: inherit;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div style=&amp;quot;line-height: 100%; margin-bottom: 0in;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: inherit;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;8. Type &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;yes&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;amp;nbsp;to enable AutoSupport and hit &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;Enter&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;.&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: inherit;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; Hit &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;Enter&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;amp;nbsp;to accept e0c as the node management interface and fill in the IP/netmask details for the second node.&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: inherit;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; Type &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;join&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;amp;nbsp;when asked whether you want to create a new cluster or join an existing cluster.&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: inherit;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-JRrvADJNtoA/WteuTXVhxEI/AAAAAAAAPRw/yd2nT3dUuUQhV6VIP_SPdLaR1z9l1Cj5gCEwYBhgL/s1600/image5.png&amp;quot; imageanchor=&amp;quot;1&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: left; float: left; margin-bottom: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: inherit;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;img border=&amp;quot;0&amp;quot; data-original-height=&amp;quot;64&amp;quot; data-original-width=&amp;quot;1169&amp;quot; height=&amp;quot;34&amp;quot; src=&amp;quot;https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-JRrvADJNtoA/WteuTXVhxEI/AAAAAAAAPRw/yd2nT3dUuUQhV6VIP_SPdLaR1z9l1Cj5gCEwYBhgL/s640/image5.png&amp;quot; width=&amp;quot;640&amp;quot; /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: inherit;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: inherit;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: inherit;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: inherit;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;11. Accept the system defaults at the next screen. The cluster interfaces will be created.&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: inherit;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-ojBHnwq0gSE/WteuTgTWqDI/AAAAAAAAPR0/LN0BPMpzhh88cfO92DIKqsDL9fKj3tO8gCEwYBhgL/s1600/image6.png&amp;quot; imageanchor=&amp;quot;1&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: left; float: left; margin-bottom: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: inherit;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;img border=&amp;quot;0&amp;quot; data-original-height=&amp;quot;167&amp;quot; data-original-width=&amp;quot;917&amp;quot; height=&amp;quot;116&amp;quot; src=&amp;quot;https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-ojBHnwq0gSE/WteuTgTWqDI/AAAAAAAAPR0/LN0BPMpzhh88cfO92DIKqsDL9fKj3tO8gCEwYBhgL/s640/image6.png&amp;quot; width=&amp;quot;640&amp;quot; /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: inherit;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: inherit;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: inherit;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: inherit;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: inherit;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: inherit;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: inherit;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: inherit;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;12. Hit &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;Enter &amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;to join the existing cluster (in my environment, the cluster name is labcluster1).&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: inherit;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: inherit;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;13. Assign all unowned disks to the second node by running the &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;storage disk assign -all true -node &amp;amp;lt;second node name&amp;amp;gt; &amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;command.&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: inherit;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: inherit;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;14. Assign the secondary node licenses from the text file that you used during the setup of the first node.&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: inherit;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: inherit;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;15. The setup of the second node is complete. Run a &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;cluster show&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;amp;nbsp;command to verify that the cluster is healthy.&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: inherit;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: inherit;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-FIbn0lVBn4c/WteuUOvJOqI/AAAAAAAAPR4/CLovsVr7CE8ec1uAfCvDsBwZwFghl9g5wCEwYBhgL/s1600/image7.png&amp;quot;
