My simulators are running the GA version of 9.3 at the moment, but there have been some updates to 9.3 since its release - I&amp;#39;ll cover upgrading the cluster to the latest 9.3 release in a future post.&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: inherit;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;span style=&amp;quot;font-family: inherit;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;Thanks for reading!&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&lt;/content&gt;&lt;link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='https://www.blogger.com/feeds/3947691530317823276/posts/default/4888170969466240912'/&gt;&lt;link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='https://www.blogger.com/feeds/3947691530317823276/posts/default/4888170969466240912'/&gt;&lt;link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='https://www.langhq.com/2018/04/netapp-ontap-93-simulator-deployment.html' title='NetApp ONTAP 9.3 Simulator Deployment – Part 2'/&gt;&lt;author&gt;&lt;name&gt;Donny Lang&lt;/name&gt;&lt;uri&gt;http://www.blogger.com/profile/04332684287885880604&lt;/uri&gt;&lt;email&gt;<span class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="4927263b2c392530092b25262e2e2c3b672a2624">[email&#160;protected]</span>&lt;/email&gt;&lt;gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='32' height='32' src='//1.bp.blogspot.com/-JafglNogKoE/WsfNRWPGLRI/AAAAAAAAOwA/ct7A0f4IRrMkD4AQSqkjb4FXdWMmsSSYgCK4BGAYYCw/s49/2018-04-06%2B14_39_55-Donny%2BLang%2B%2528%2540DonnyLang1%2529%2B_%2BTwitter.png'/&gt;&lt;/author&gt;&lt;media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-eaF-0fUC40A/WteuP0WN1GI/AAAAAAAAPRg/6NHAClhHzLQvH6rF4zpbWORt9pfdd08twCLcBGAs/s72-c/image1.png" height="72" width="72"/&gt;&lt;/entry&gt;&lt;entry&gt;&lt;id&gt;tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-3947691530317823276.post-2086209977167690924&lt;/id&gt;&lt;published&gt;2018-04-15T13:44:00.000-07:00&lt;/published&gt;&lt;updated&gt;2018-04-16T13:51:32.603-07:00&lt;/updated&gt;&lt;title type='text'&gt;NetApp ONTAP 9.3 Simulator Deployment - Part 1&lt;/title&gt;&lt;content type='html'&gt;I am going to be doing a few of these simulator/lab posts in an effort to set up an environment that will pave the way for future guides and blog posts. Hopefully it&amp;#39;ll also be a good resource for folks that want to set up their own labs to test out new features and software versions. Today I&amp;#39;m going to show the steps required to deploy Netapp&amp;#39;s ONTAP Simulator 9.3 on vSphere 6.5.&amp;amp;nbsp; I&amp;#39;ll also be doing a follow-up article that will detail the process of clustering a second node with this first one.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;Note: My lab has vCenter 6.5 deployed along with a Distributed vSwitch, so the steps will be specific to that deployment. I will also assume that you already have basic networking and storage for your virtual machines in place.&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;u&amp;gt;Step 1: Deploying the Simulator&amp;lt;/u&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;1. Browse out to https://mysupport.netapp.com, click on &amp;quot;Sign In&amp;quot; in the upper right-hand corner and log in using your NetApp account credentials.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;2. Click on the Downloads drop-down at the top of the screen and click on Software.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-7Y5LIS6R__Q/WtOwzuGaE-I/AAAAAAAAO24/aKXdmzfok8kVSAVIw32vjRxCz2Q7HVDEwCLcBGAs/s1600/image1.png&amp;quot; imageanchor=&amp;quot;1&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: left; float: left; margin-bottom: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;img border=&amp;quot;0&amp;quot; data-original-height=&amp;quot;223&amp;quot; data-original-width=&amp;quot;1423&amp;quot; height=&amp;quot;100&amp;quot; src=&amp;quot;https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-7Y5LIS6R__Q/WtOwzuGaE-I/AAAAAAAAO24/aKXdmzfok8kVSAVIw32vjRxCz2Q7HVDEwCLcBGAs/s640/image1.png&amp;quot; width=&amp;quot;640&amp;quot; /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;3. Click on the Data ONTAP Simulator link under the ToolChest heading.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;4. Download the &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;Simulate ONTAP 9.3 for VMWare ESX OVA&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt; image. Also download the &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;VSIM Licenses&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt; file, which we&amp;#39;ll need during the cluster setup.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;5. Before we actually deploy the simulator, we will need to first create a dedicated cluster network (separate from data traffic), so let&amp;#39;s create a new DPG for that purpose. In the vSphere Web Client, click on the &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;Networking&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt; icon, drill down to your dvSwitch, right-click and select &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;Distributed Port Group -&amp;amp;gt; New Distributed Port Group.&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-Bkn8CPte0jY/WtOxRQL_Q4I/AAAAAAAAO28/DvL4DkQ8sok20mFTfq-DHhAlBvNTK388QCLcBGAs/s1600/image2.png&amp;quot; imageanchor=&amp;quot;1&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: left; float: left; margin-bottom: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;img border=&amp;quot;0&amp;quot; data-original-height=&amp;quot;565&amp;quot; data-original-width=&amp;quot;692&amp;quot; height=&amp;quot;325&amp;quot; src=&amp;quot;https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-Bkn8CPte0jY/WtOxRQL_Q4I/AAAAAAAAO28/DvL4DkQ8sok20mFTfq-DHhAlBvNTK388QCLcBGAs/s400/image2.png&amp;quot; width=&amp;quot;400&amp;quot; /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;6. Select a name (I&amp;#39;ve used Lab_ClusterNet_dvSwitch for mine) and keep the default settings for the next screen. When complete, the settings should look like the below image.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-7cj9r1U0uvw/WtOxbc77a4I/AAAAAAAAO3E/FSuqffsl3FkvzF7e9n4vcOUNFacgBIjhQCLcBGAs/s1600/image3.png&amp;quot; imageanchor=&amp;quot;1&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: left; float: left; margin-bottom: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;img border=&amp;quot;0&amp;quot; data-original-height=&amp;quot;551&amp;quot; data-original-width=&amp;quot;869&amp;quot; height=&amp;quot;251&amp;quot; src=&amp;quot;https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-7cj9r1U0uvw/WtOxbc77a4I/AAAAAAAAO3E/FSuqffsl3FkvzF7e9n4vcOUNFacgBIjhQCLcBGAs/s400/image3.png&amp;quot; width=&amp;quot;400&amp;quot; /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;Quick side note: when I attempted to import the OVA into my environment, I received an error message that &amp;quot;OVF Package with compressed disks is currently not supported for OVF import&amp;quot;. A quick Google search yielded many useful results on how to fix this (for example, this one from &amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://twitter.com/anthonyspiteri&amp;quot;&amp;gt;@anthonyspiteri&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;: &amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://anthonyspiteri.net/quick-fix-ovf-package-with-compressed-disks-is-currently-not-supported/&amp;quot;&amp;gt;https://anthonyspiteri.net/quick-fix-ovf-package-with-compressed-disks-is-currently-not-supported/&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;)&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;7. Log into the vSphere Web Client and select the target cluster or host for the OVA deployment, right-click on it and select &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;Deploy OVF Template.&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-xxUZUUpwsBk/WtOyYSBBEhI/AAAAAAAAO3U/gznk2nyTVnceDVtBOWnFCDcwDtiUPyB2QCLcBGAs/s1600/image4.png&amp;quot; imageanchor=&amp;quot;1&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: left; float: left; margin-bottom: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;img border=&amp;quot;0&amp;quot; data-original-height=&amp;quot;236&amp;quot; data-original-width=&amp;quot;335&amp;quot; height=&amp;quot;225&amp;quot; src=&amp;quot;https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-xxUZUUpwsBk/WtOyYSBBEhI/AAAAAAAAO3U/gznk2nyTVnceDVtBOWnFCDcwDtiUPyB2QCLcBGAs/s320/image4.png&amp;quot; width=&amp;quot;320&amp;quot; /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;8. Select the OVA that we just downloaded and click Next.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;9. Choose a name and location for the sim that makes sense for your environment (I would recommend appending it with a -01 or something since we&amp;#39;ll be deploying a second one next).&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;10. Choose a compute resource, select storage, and then select networks, mapping the VM network to the appropriate port group and the cluster network to the DPG we created earlier.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-_SSS3L-zOAk/WtOygvtZJqI/AAAAAAAAO3Y/d602oPWbyXwQ1Ejni1g3wAVMKg9XrrpogCLcBGAs/s1600/image5.png&amp;quot; imageanchor=&amp;quot;1&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: left; float: left; margin-bottom: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;img border=&amp;quot;0&amp;quot; data-original-height=&amp;quot;695&amp;quot; data-original-width=&amp;quot;858&amp;quot; height=&amp;quot;259&amp;quot; src=&amp;quot;https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-_SSS3L-zOAk/WtOygvtZJqI/AAAAAAAAO3Y/d602oPWbyXwQ1Ejni1g3wAVMKg9XrrpogCLcBGAs/s320/image5.png&amp;quot; width=&amp;quot;320&amp;quot; /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;11. Review the settings and then click Finish when everything looks correct. The OVA will start to import - it&amp;#39;ll take a little while, so just be patient.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;u&amp;gt;Step 2: Initial Cluster Setup&amp;lt;/u&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;1. Boot the newly deployed VM&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;2. Open the console and watch the boot process - there will be an opportunity to interrupt the boot process by pressing Ctrl-C - do that and the boot menu will be displayed&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-_ArTo1MEfmg/WtOyv6SJyrI/AAAAAAAAO3c/Dzwk-HK4Et0AgVcp8ebXWMBieBlg2TOAwCLcBGAs/s1600/image6.png&amp;quot; imageanchor=&amp;quot;1&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: left; float: left; margin-bottom: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;img border=&amp;quot;0&amp;quot; data-original-height=&amp;quot;132&amp;quot; data-original-width=&amp;quot;354&amp;quot; height=&amp;quot;119&amp;quot; src=&amp;quot;https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-_ArTo1MEfmg/WtOyv6SJyrI/AAAAAAAAO3c/Dzwk-HK4Et0AgVcp8ebXWMBieBlg2TOAwCLcBGAs/s320/image6.png&amp;quot; width=&amp;quot;320&amp;quot; /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-1e3e42WwIKk/WtOy1G4MZ0I/AAAAAAAAO3g/kVvrEQXe56krRJsrnitVg69HhkK5vG5MgCLcBGAs/s1600/image7.png&amp;quot; imageanchor=&amp;quot;1&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: left; float: left; margin-bottom: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;img border=&amp;quot;0&amp;quot; data-original-height=&amp;quot;206&amp;quot; data-original-width=&amp;quot;453&amp;quot; height=&amp;quot;145&amp;quot; src=&amp;quot;https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-1e3e42WwIKk/WtOy1G4MZ0I/AAAAAAAAO3g/kVvrEQXe56krRJsrnitVg69HhkK5vG5MgCLcBGAs/s320/image7.png&amp;quot; width=&amp;quot;320&amp;quot; /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;3. Select option &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;4 &amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;and hit &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;Enter&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;4. When prompted to zero disks, reset config and install a new file system, type &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;y&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt; and hit &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;Enter&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;. Hit &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;y&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt; again at the confirmation prompt. The virtual machine will reboot at this point to complete the request.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;5. Once the VM reboots, the node setup wizard is displayed. This will take several minutes.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-ZnMsU4IhIPY/WtOzEC4V8NI/AAAAAAAAO3o/N5HQnWEOwRADorElFlZIiTzV2jXoRnoMQCLcBGAs/s1600/image8.png&amp;quot; imageanchor=&amp;quot;1&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: left; float: left; margin-bottom: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;img border=&amp;quot;0&amp;quot; data-original-height=&amp;quot;360&amp;quot; data-original-width=&amp;quot;704&amp;quot; height=&amp;quot;202&amp;quot; src=&amp;quot;https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-ZnMsU4IhIPY/WtOzEC4V8NI/AAAAAAAAO3o/N5HQnWEOwRADorElFlZIiTzV2jXoRnoMQCLcBGAs/s400/image8.png&amp;quot; width=&amp;quot;400&amp;quot; /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;6. Type &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;yes&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt; to enable AutoSupport and hit &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;Enter&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;7. Hit&amp;amp;nbsp;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;Enter&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt; to accept e0c as the node management interface, and fill in the IP/netmask/gateway details for your environment.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-Zz6LUBaGYAs/WtOzNX8SkyI/AAAAAAAAO3s/3CvEghKSIFs_4Ep4hpRtrM6Vb_g1xsmCACLcBGAs/s1600/image9.png&amp;quot; imageanchor=&amp;quot;1&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: left; float: left; margin-bottom: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;img border=&amp;quot;0&amp;quot; data-original-height=&amp;quot;163&amp;quot; data-original-width=&amp;quot;719&amp;quot; height=&amp;quot;90&amp;quot; src=&amp;quot;https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-Zz6LUBaGYAs/WtOzNX8SkyI/AAAAAAAAO3s/3CvEghKSIFs_4Ep4hpRtrM6Vb_g1xsmCACLcBGAs/s400/image9.png&amp;quot; width=&amp;quot;400&amp;quot; /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;Note: this guide will show the CLI method for configuring the cluster, but you can also browse to the node management IP you just set and configure it using the Guided Setup method if you prefer the GUI.&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;8. Hit &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;Enter&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt; to complete the setup via the CLI, and then type&amp;lt;b&amp;gt; create&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt; when asked if you want to create a new cluster or join an existing one.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-CvWfeym1kHU/WtOzccLvEGI/AAAAAAAAO30/Yy0MCrqUZ8ke6umNj3vnahv8AcwfqhCqgCLcBGAs/s1600/image10.png&amp;quot; imageanchor=&amp;quot;1&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: left; float: left; margin-bottom: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;img border=&amp;quot;0&amp;quot; data-original-height=&amp;quot;51&amp;quot; data-original-width=&amp;quot;720&amp;quot; height=&amp;quot;43&amp;quot; src=&amp;quot;https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-CvWfeym1kHU/WtOzccLvEGI/AAAAAAAAO30/Yy0MCrqUZ8ke6umNj3vnahv8AcwfqhCqgCLcBGAs/s640/image10.png&amp;quot; width=&amp;quot;640&amp;quot; /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;9. Hit &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;Enter&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt; or type &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;no&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;amp;nbsp;to specify that we intend this to (eventually) be a two-node cluster.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;10. Accept the system defaults for the next prompt.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-UTfafgWyvgU/WtOzlB2VqaI/AAAAAAAAO38/uWcNlLZwCtQSORbQraE0tvtRaiEJ2w9OwCLcBGAs/s1600/image11.png&amp;quot; imageanchor=&amp;quot;1&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: left; float: left; margin-bottom: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;img border=&amp;quot;0&amp;quot; data-original-height=&amp;quot;103&amp;quot; data-original-width=&amp;quot;572&amp;quot; height=&amp;quot;71&amp;quot; src=&amp;quot;https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-UTfafgWyvgU/WtOzlB2VqaI/AAAAAAAAO38/uWcNlLZwCtQSORbQraE0tvtRaiEJ2w9OwCLcBGAs/s400/image11.png&amp;quot; width=&amp;quot;400&amp;quot; /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;11. Enter the cluster admin password and put it into a secure password manager for safekeeping.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;12. Enter the cluster name and hit &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;Enter&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt; (I used &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;labcluster1&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt; for my cluster name).&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;13. After the cluster has been created, you have the option to add Feature Licenses. I recommend waiting since it&amp;#39;ll be easier to copy and paste them into Systems Manager than to type them manually into a vSphere console window.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;14. Select the e0c interface for the cluster management interface port, and input an IP adress scheme that is appropriate for your environment. Here are the settings I used for mine:&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-kLRz0f5V5Oo/WtOzu8r-qwI/AAAAAAAAO4E/DPJxWdekpAMd5AmmNz8Cgeazo99BzFi0gCLcBGAs/s1600/image12.png&amp;quot; imageanchor=&amp;quot;1&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: left; float: left; margin-bottom: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;img border=&amp;quot;0&amp;quot; data-original-height=&amp;quot;96&amp;quot; data-original-width=&amp;quot;632&amp;quot; height=&amp;quot;60&amp;quot; src=&amp;quot;https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-kLRz0f5V5Oo/WtOzu8r-qwI/AAAAAAAAO4E/DPJxWdekpAMd5AmmNz8Cgeazo99BzFi0gCLcBGAs/s400/image12.png&amp;quot; width=&amp;quot;400&amp;quot; /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;15. Enter a DNS domain name if you wish; otherwise, hit &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;Enter&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;16. When prompted for the location of the controller, type &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;lab&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;amp;nbsp;and hit &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;Enter.&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;17. A login prompt is displayed - log in with the admin credentials you created during setup.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;18. Run the &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;cluster show&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt; command to verify that the cluster/node is healthy.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-zrTX7Gv94S4/WtOz8upCG5I/AAAAAAAAO4M/wYOzT0ypvYs30WJ4mos0Q-u0Mzshpu3gACLcBGAs/s1600/image13.png&amp;quot; imageanchor=&amp;quot;1&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: left; float: left; margin-bottom: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;img border=&amp;quot;0&amp;quot; data-original-height=&amp;quot;164&amp;quot; data-original-width=&amp;quot;399&amp;quot; height=&amp;quot;131&amp;quot; src=&amp;quot;https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-zrTX7Gv94S4/WtOz8upCG5I/AAAAAAAAO4M/wYOzT0ypvYs30WJ4mos0Q-u0Mzshpu3gACLcBGAs/s320/image13.png&amp;quot; width=&amp;quot;320&amp;quot; /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;19. Assign all of the disks to the node by running &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;storage disk assign -all true -node &amp;amp;lt;your node name&amp;amp;gt;.&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;20. Log into Systems Manager using the cluster management IP and browse to &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;Configuration -&amp;amp;gt; Licenses.&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-rg4XeUCjwW0/WtO0FjvGjeI/AAAAAAAAO4U/yGc3S7hHeEYCHAxCwf0aWgY3py_u4enCwCLcBGAs/s1600/image16.png&amp;quot; imageanchor=&amp;quot;1&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: left; float: left; margin-bottom: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;img border=&amp;quot;0&amp;quot; data-original-height=&amp;quot;496&amp;quot; data-original-width=&amp;quot;179&amp;quot; height=&amp;quot;320&amp;quot; src=&amp;quot;https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-rg4XeUCjwW0/WtO0FjvGjeI/AAAAAAAAO4U/yGc3S7hHeEYCHAxCwf0aWgY3py_u4enCwCLcBGAs/s320/image16.png&amp;quot; width=&amp;quot;115&amp;quot; /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;21. Click on &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;Add&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt; and paste the Feature License keys from the text file you downloaded earlier.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;And just like that, initial cluster setup is complete - stay tuned for a future post to learn how to add a second node to the cluster and other neat storage things!&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;Thank you for reading!&lt;/content&gt;&lt;link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='https://www.blogger.com/feeds/3947691530317823276/posts/default/2086209977167690924'/&gt;&lt;link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='https://www.blogger.com/feeds/3947691530317823276/posts/default/2086209977167690924'/&gt;&lt;link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='https://www.langhq.com/2018/04/netapp-simulate-ontap-93-deployment.html' title='NetApp ONTAP 9.3 Simulator Deployment - Part 1'/&gt;&lt;author&gt;&lt;name&gt;Donny Lang&lt;/name&gt;&lt;uri&gt;http://www.blogger.com/profile/04332684287885880604&lt;/uri&gt;&lt;email&gt;<span class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="d3bdbca1b6a3bfaa93b1bfbcb4b4b6a1fdb0bcbe">[email&#160;protected]</span>&lt;/email&gt;&lt;gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='32' height='32' src='//1.bp.blogspot.com/-JafglNogKoE/WsfNRWPGLRI/AAAAAAAAOwA/ct7A0f4IRrMkD4AQSqkjb4FXdWMmsSSYgCK4BGAYYCw/s49/2018-04-06%2B14_39_55-Donny%2BLang%2B%2528%2540DonnyLang1%2529%2B_%2BTwitter.png'/&gt;&lt;/author&gt;&lt;media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-7Y5LIS6R__Q/WtOwzuGaE-I/AAAAAAAAO24/aKXdmzfok8kVSAVIw32vjRxCz2Q7HVDEwCLcBGAs/s72-c/image1.png" height="72" width="72"/&gt;&lt;/entry&gt;&lt;entry&gt;&lt;id&gt;tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-3947691530317823276.post-4183856612083107925&lt;/id&gt;&lt;published&gt;2018-04-14T11:30:00.002-07:00&lt;/published&gt;&lt;updated&gt;2018-04-14T11:41:29.810-07:00&lt;/updated&gt;&lt;title type='text'&gt;Cisco UCS LACP Port Channel Flapping &lt;/title&gt;&lt;content type='html'&gt;I recently encountered this issue during a deployment and wasn&amp;#39;t able to find much information about it on the Internet, so I figured I&amp;#39;d make a quick blog post to document the issue and the solution in case other people encounter the same issue.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;When connecting UCS Fabric Interconnects to non-Cisco switches (in this case Juniper EX series) we noticed some strange behavior: once every 30 minutes or so, the Uplink port-channel members would go down briefly and then come back up and then everything would be fine until the next occurrence. This would generate an intermittent F0727 error - UCS complaining that its port channels had no operational members.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;I turned up LACP traceoptions logging on the Juniper side to see if it might be an issue with the LACP protocol itself, but it did not yield any useful information as to the root cause of the issue.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;I turned to the UCS logs to see if I could get any further information, and noticed these log entries repeated many times:&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;2018 Apr 11 13:25:51 ucscluster-A&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt; %LLDP-1-NO_DCBX_ACKS_RECV_FOR_LAST_10_PDUs&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;2018 Apr 11 13:28:07 ucsclster-A&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt; %LLDP-1-NO_DCBX_ACKS_RECV_FOR_LAST_10_PDUs&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;2018 Apr 11 13:30:21 ucscluster-A&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt; %LLDP-1-NO_DCBX_ACKS_RECV_FOR_LAST_10_PDUs&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;A Google search then turned up this Cisco article - &amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/switches/nexus-5000-series-switches/116249-troubleshoot-nexus-00.html&amp;quot;&amp;gt;https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/switches/nexus-5000-series-switches/116249-troubleshoot-nexus-00.html&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; - which explains that LLDP was the actual root cause of the issue I was seeing.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;u&amp;gt;From the Cisco.com Support article:&amp;lt;/u&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;&amp;quot;Data Center Bridging Capability Exchange (DCBX) Type Length Values (TLV) are packaged within a Link Layer Discovery Protocol (LLDP) frame that is exchanged between the switch and the converged network adapter (CNA). One such Control Sub-TLV is used for acknowledgement (ACK), which is sequence-based. For example, the switch sends a Control Sub-TLV with a SeqNo of 1 and an AckNo of 2. The host is supposed to inverse this, and send an LLDP frame with a Control Sub-TLV with a SeqNo of 2 and an AckNo of 1. Refer to the Packet Captures section of this article for more details.&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;The switch expects this exchange from the host every 30 seconds. If the switch does not see this exchange for 100 Protocol Data Units (PDUs) , which is 3000 seconds or 50 minutes, the switch disables with this error.&amp;quot;&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;Okay, so now I knew what the issue was, I started looking around for a way to disable LLDP within UCSM and came up empty. I Googled some more and wasn&amp;#39;t able to find anything definitive on how to actually do it. So I finally admitted defeat and opened a Cisco TAC case - and the engineer very quickly responded that the reason I couldn&amp;#39;t find a way to disable LLDP on the FIs is because the capability was not exposed via UCSM or the CLI and would have to be done via debug plugin (dplug). He also linked me to an enhancement request that would enable customers to enable/disable LLDP (you&amp;#39;ll need a Cisco account to read it):&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://bst.cloudapps.cisco.com/bugsearch/bug/CSCue05053&amp;quot;&amp;gt;https://bst.cloudapps.cisco.com/bugsearch/bug/CSCue05053&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;A 15-minute call later the dplug was loaded and we verified that LLDP was indeed disabled - further monitoring confirmed that disabling LLDP had resolved the flapping portchannels.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;An alternative option would be to disable LLDP on the upstream switches instead of the UCS, but I elected to make the configuration change on the UCS side to keep our switches&amp;#39; LLDP configuration standardized.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;Hopefully this will help someone else out there having the same issue - thanks for reading!&lt;/content&gt;&lt;link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='https://www.blogger.com/feeds/3947691530317823276/posts/default/4183856612083107925'/&gt;&lt;link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='https://www.blogger.com/feeds/3947691530317823276/posts/default/4183856612083107925'/&gt;&lt;link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='https://www.langhq.com/2018/04/cisco-ucs-lacp-portchannel-flapping.html' title='Cisco UCS LACP Port Channel Flapping '/&gt;&lt;author&gt;&lt;name&gt;Donny Lang&lt;/name&gt;&lt;uri&gt;http://www.blogger.com/profile/04332684287885880604&lt;/uri&gt;&lt;email&gt;<span class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="7f11100d1a0f13063f1d131018181a0d511c1012">[email&#160;protected]</span>&lt;/email&gt;&lt;gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='32' height='32' src='//1.bp.blogspot.com/-JafglNogKoE/WsfNRWPGLRI/AAAAAAAAOwA/ct7A0f4IRrMkD4AQSqkjb4FXdWMmsSSYgCK4BGAYYCw/s49/2018-04-06%2B14_39_55-Donny%2BLang%2B%2528%2540DonnyLang1%2529%2B_%2BTwitter.png'/&gt;&lt;/author&gt;&lt;/entry&gt;&lt;entry&gt;&lt;id&gt;tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-3947691530317823276.post-7362852317449922401&lt;/id&gt;&lt;published&gt;2018-04-08T19:04:00.000-07:00&lt;/published&gt;&lt;updated&gt;2018-04-16T13:52:37.606-07:00&lt;/updated&gt;&lt;title type='text'&gt;The Evolution of my Home Lab&lt;/title&gt;&lt;content type='html'&gt;For my inaugural blog post, I figured it made some sort of sense to talk about something that I did early on in my career that had a lasting impact on me, professionally - the creation of my home lab and its evolution over the years. It&amp;#39;s seen MANY small iterations over the years since I first had anything you could call a lab, but in the interest of time I&amp;#39;ll just cover a few major ones and talk about how I use the lab today. Let me paint you a word picture...&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;The Early Days&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;Like a lot of IT professionals, I&amp;#39;ve always been predisposed to exploring how computers worked ever since we got our first hand-me-down 286 from my Grandma. Yes, my Grandma always had a better computer than I did, she was cool like that. In fact, I loved to tinker so much that I distinctly remember that I had tinkered with our &amp;quot;family&amp;quot; computer&amp;#39;s operating system (MS-DOS 6.22, if I recall correctly) a little too much one day and it was no longer working properly. As a Christmas present, some of my relatives got together and paid a local computer repair shop to fix it for me. My uncle told me that the PC technician told him that - and this is a direct quote - &amp;quot;he had never seen a computer more messed up than yours&amp;quot;. Clearly I was destined for greatness! As time went on, I always had a couple of old computers kicking around and would mess with them from time to time if I saw something that interested me, but I never really took my home lab seriously until after I graduated from the Network Specialist program at NWTC (Northeast Wisconsin Technical College)&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;The First &amp;quot;Real&amp;quot; Home Lab (A.K.A the Basement Auxiliary Heater)&amp;amp;nbsp;&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;After I graduated from NWTC, I no longer had access to their lab equipment. It was mid-to-late 2010 at this point, and I had gotten a job at a local MSP as an intern doing PC support, although the roles were rather unstructured and I did server and application support too pretty much right from the beginning. Very quickly, I realized that if I wanted to learn more about how all this stuff worked (Virtualization? What&amp;#39;s that?) I would need an environment that I could build up and break repeatedly. One other thing that became abundantly clear was that I would need to put in some time after hours if I wanted to learn new things. So I began the hunt for some lab equipment and headed to eBay.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;I eventually found a pretty decent deal on a pair of used Dell PowerEdge 2950s, so I put in a bid on them and won. At this point, my home lab consisted of:&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;2x Dell PowerEdge 2950&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;Random whitebox running Openfiler for shared storage&amp;amp;nbsp;&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;Linksys L2 managed switch scrounged from a client who had upgraded&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;Untangle firewall&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;I honestly don&amp;#39;t even remember the specifications and sadly no pictures exist, but I think they only had 8GB of RAM each or something like that, so I couldn&amp;#39;t run a lot of VMs on them concurrently. The storage was also just comprised of SATA drives, so I definitely wasn&amp;#39;t running any demanding workloads either. It also had the added side effect of making my basement about 15 degrees warmer and making my wife angry about the increased electricity bill (in the present day, she just resignedly accepts my pile of gear in the basement).&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;By this time though, I was supporting some small ESXi 4.0 and 4.1 installations at client sites and this lab became a great way for me to understand ESXi installs/troubleshooting, virtual networking components/cabling, and get an introduction to vCenter and other management components. This ultimately led to being assigned a fair number of projects wherein we would move our clients from a physical server model to a virtualized one - including scoping the project, designing the solution, and implementing it once it was accepted by the client.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;Time to Upgrade&amp;amp;nbsp;&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;I ran the 2950s for a year, maybe a year and a half (RIP my energy bills) before I decided that I would need to upgrade if I wanted to continue to learn. By this point I had transitioned to the Professional Services Team at my employer at the time, and was working on larger and more varied projects. I decided on some whitebox servers this time instead of going with an existing rack mount server platform like the PowerEdge. I wound up with a pair of hosts running AMD-FX8120 8-core processors and 16GB of RAM each. ESXi 5.0 booted from a USB flash drive. I had switched to a Debian-based Linux distribution called OpenMediaVault for my storage (and some other plugins), but other than that, it pretty much stayed the same hardware-wise. I managed to find a picture of my daughter (who was two at the time) &amp;quot;helping&amp;quot; me build one of the hosts:&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div class=&amp;quot;separator&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;a href=&amp;quot;https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-pXlbzdy73ak/WsrIDg2JagI/AAAAAAAAOzw/wXzc0HRbl2I8pTw0oChuy_FsfJPwIj3TwCLcBGAs/s1600/304671_10151152569549470_496202765_n.jpg&amp;quot; imageanchor=&amp;quot;1&amp;quot; style=&amp;quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&amp;quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;img border=&amp;quot;0&amp;quot; data-original-height=&amp;quot;960&amp;quot; data-original-width=&amp;quot;574&amp;quot; height=&amp;quot;320&amp;quot; src=&amp;quot;https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-pXlbzdy73ak/WsrIDg2JagI/AAAAAAAAOzw/wXzc0HRbl2I8pTw0oChuy_FsfJPwIj3TwCLcBGAs/s320/304671_10151152569549470_496202765_n.jpg&amp;quot; width=&amp;quot;191&amp;quot; /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;I kept this configuration until we moved in November of 2012. When we bought a house, I decided that I wanted to simplify my lab setup because I felt like managing it took up too much of my free time. I was also attending UW-Stout almost full-time with two young kids at home and a full-time job, so my ability to spend time on home lab pursuits was...somewhat diminished, to say the least. I moved from two physical ESXi hosts to zero, used the case/motherboard/CPU/etc from one of the hosts, crammed all the hard drives from my OpenMediaVault server into it, and just ran all the services I needed to either on that machine or on the firewall. It was truly a dark time for the LangHQ home lab.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;b&amp;gt;Present Day&amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;Today, I don&amp;#39;t really have a VMware-focused home lab simply because I am fortunate enough to have gotten the approval to have a dedicated lab environment at work with 24/7 remote access. We use it primarily to test new ESXi releases and features, put together PoCs for new configurations with other teams in our IT Operations department, and also test new software/firmware for switches, firewalls, etc. At home, I have moved storage-focused distributions once again to FreeNAS - and I&amp;#39;m confident that I will actually stay with it for the forseeable future. I run a few Ubuntu VMs on FreeNAS as Docker hosts that handle the majority of the services. I have also moved to PFSense (I seem to have an affinity for FreeBSD-based distributions) for my firewall, which handles the inter-VLAN routing between my internal, secure, and guest wireless networks and is my perimeter firewall as well.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;In closing, I will say that building, operating and maintaining a home lab has been a really great experience for me overall, especially when getting to know a new technology. I think that the money that you will spend on one, whatever your goal, is a solid investment in your future. If you want to get started building your own home lab, I can heartily recommend Reddit&amp;#39;s /r/homelab subreddit for all things home lab related and of course VMware&amp;#39;s own Hands on Labs for when you are light on cash but still want to learn about a VMware technology in a FREE lab environment.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;Thanks for reading!&lt;/content&gt;&lt;link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='https://www.blogger.com/feeds/3947691530317823276/posts/default/7362852317449922401'/&gt;&lt;link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='https://www.blogger.com/feeds/3947691530317823276/posts/default/7362852317449922401'/&gt;&lt;link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='https://www.langhq.com/2018/04/the-evolution-of-my-home-lab-for-my.html' title='The Evolution of my Home Lab'/&gt;&lt;author&gt;&lt;name&gt;Donny Lang&lt;/name&gt;&lt;uri&gt;http://www.blogger.com/profile/04332684287885880604&lt;/uri&gt;&lt;email&gt;<span class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="82ecedf0e7f2eefbc2e0eeede5e5e7f0ace1edef">[email&#160;protected]</span>&lt;/email&gt;&lt;gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='32' height='32' src='//1.bp.blogspot.com/-JafglNogKoE/WsfNRWPGLRI/AAAAAAAAOwA/ct7A0f4IRrMkD4AQSqkjb4FXdWMmsSSYgCK4BGAYYCw/s49/2018-04-06%2B14_39_55-Donny%2BLang%2B%2528%2540DonnyLang1%2529%2B_%2BTwitter.png'/&gt;&lt;/author&gt;&lt;media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-pXlbzdy73ak/WsrIDg2JagI/AAAAAAAAOzw/wXzc0HRbl2I8pTw0oChuy_FsfJPwIj3TwCLcBGAs/s72-c/304671_10151152569549470_496202765_n.jpg" height="72" width="72"/&gt;&lt;/entry&gt;&lt;entry&gt;&lt;id&gt;tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-3947691530317823276.post-4805100811060730143&lt;/id&gt;&lt;published&gt;2018-04-07T20:01:00.001-07:00&lt;/published&gt;&lt;updated&gt;2018-04-07T20:08:14.972-07:00&lt;/updated&gt;&lt;title type='text'&gt;Welcome to my blog!&lt;/title&gt;&lt;content type='html'&gt;First off, let me say thank you for visiting my blog and I hope that you will find some useful information contained within. I have the good fortune (most days I consider it good fortune, anyways) of having a relatively broad area of responsibility in my current job role - it covers a wide range of data center infrastructure components. My hope is that will lead to the production of a variety of content that will benefit people involved in various areas of data center administration.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;One of the major projects that I am working on this year is to expand our secondary data center, which includes a new compute environment, storage implementation, new load balancers, new firewalls, and other networking equipment. I plan on creating some posts focused on the deployment, initial configuration and/or just cool ways we&amp;#39;re solving business problems with technology.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;I have also set some IT certification goals for myself in 2018, as follows:&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;Citrix Certified Associate - Networking (end of June)&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;NetApp Certified Data Administrator (end of October)&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;i&amp;gt;Undecided VMware certification (my VCP6-DCV expires next February, so I&amp;#39;m on the fence if I want to just renew it on 6.5 or push for one of the VCAP exams).&amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;I am going to be creating some content during the course of my studies to share studying and training resources with other people looking to earn the same certifications.&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;Keep your eyes out for future posts, and thanks again for reading!&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;Donny&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;div&amp;gt;&amp;lt;br /&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;&lt;/content&gt;&lt;link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='https://www.blogger.com/feeds/3947691530317823276/posts/default/4805100811060730143'/&gt;&lt;link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='https://www.blogger.com/feeds/3947691530317823276/posts/default/4805100811060730143'/&gt;&lt;link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='https://www.langhq.com/2018/04/welcome-to-blog.html' title='Welcome to my blog!'/&gt;&lt;author&gt;&lt;name&gt;Donny Lang&lt;/name&gt;&lt;uri&gt;http://www.blogger.com/profile/04332684287885880604&lt;/uri&gt;&lt;email&gt;<span class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="3957564b5c495540795b55565e5e5c4b175a5654">[email&#160;protected]</span>&lt;/email&gt;&lt;gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='32' height='32' src='//1.bp.blogspot.com/-JafglNogKoE/WsfNRWPGLRI/AAAAAAAAOwA/ct7A0f4IRrMkD4AQSqkjb4FXdWMmsSSYgCK4BGAYYCw/s49/2018-04-06%2B14_39_55-Donny%2BLang%2B%2528%2540DonnyLang1%2529%2B_%2BTwitter.png'/&gt;&lt;/author&gt;&lt;/entry&gt;&lt;/feed&gt;</code></a></li>

JYVBee" style="text-align: left;" tabindex="-1"&gt;&lt;div jscontroller="Ae65rd" jsaction="touchstart:UrsOsc; click:KjsqPd; focusout:QZoaZ; mouseover:y0pDld; jscontroller="mxS5xe" jsaction="click:cOuCgd; mousedown:UX7yZ; mouseup:lbsD7e; mouseenter:tfO1Yc; mouseleave:JywGue; focus:AHmuwe; blur:O22p3e; contextmenu:mg9Pef;" jsshadow Experience&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/h2&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class="oKdM2c"&gt;&lt;div id="h.p_Z9Yg8H-jitWD" class="hJDwNd-AhqUyc-EehZO jXK9ad D2fZ2 wHaque GNzUNc"&gt;&lt;div class="jXK9ad-SmKAyb"&gt;&lt;div class="tyJCtd mGzaTb baZpAe"&gt;&lt;p id="h.p_IpdGMjnMitWF" class="zfr3Q" style="text-align: left;"&gt;09/15/2019 | by &lt;a class="dhtgD aw5Odc" href="/about"&gt;Clayton Skaggs&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p id="h.p_8VH1vFaOitWF" class="zfr3Q" style="text-align: left;"&gt;Following my trip to VMworld, I scheduled and sat for the 3V0-21.18, Advanced Deploy vSphere Exam. I originally schedule the exam for VMworld, but was given a voucher to take it at an authorized testing center instead. This exam really tests your ability to configure and troubleshoot common vSphere problems through a variety of complex questions.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p id="h.p_8oJl2nOWitWF" class="zfr3Q" style="text-align: left;"&gt;If you are familiar with the VMware Hands on Labs (HOL), you will feel comfortable with the test environment&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p id="h.p_ZwnJTC8eoS1v" class="zfr3Q" style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;a class="dhtgD aw5Odc" href="/certification/vcap-dcv-deploy-2019"&gt;Continue Reading...&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/section&gt;&lt;section id="h.p_RcqorgdymSQz" Experience&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/h2&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class="oKdM2c"&gt;&lt;div id="h.p_4DWeB2oemSRF" class="hJDwNd-AhqUyc-EehZO jXK9ad D2fZ2 wHaque GNzUNc"&gt;&lt;div class="jXK9ad-SmKAyb"&gt;&lt;div class="tyJCtd mGzaTb baZpAe"&gt;&lt;p id="h.p_-37Y80d9mSRG" class="zfr3Q" style="text-align: left;"&gt;09/07/2019 | by &lt;a class="dhtgD aw5Odc" href="/about"&gt;Clayton Skaggs&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p id="h.p_GW_8w4PVIASM" class="zfr3Q" style="text-align: left;"&gt;VMworld 2019 US has come and gone. It was a busy place with so many events and sessions taking place. This was my first VMworld and my first time in San Francisco. There was so much going on that at times it was hard to keep track of all the events. &lt;/p&gt;&lt;p id="h.p_LDnivcBLSm4b" class="zfr3Q" style="text-align: left;"&gt;Prior to the event the content catalog became live. I wasn&amp;#39;t able to look through the content catalog until 48 hours after it went live and by that time many of the breakout sessions that I wanted to attend were full.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p id="h.p_bM-dRZcCocRn" class="zfr3Q" style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;a class="dhtgD aw5Odc" href="/vmworld/vmworld-2019-us"&gt;Continue Reading...&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/section&gt;&lt;section id="h.p_EDnUNpyDnot_" class="yaqOZd" style=""&gt;&lt;div class="yaqOZd IFuOkc"&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class="mYVXT"&gt;&lt;div class="LS81yb VICjCf" tabindex="-1"&gt;&lt;div class="hJDwNd-AhqUyc-ibL1re purZT-AhqUyc-ibL1re pSzOP-AhqUyc-ibL1re JNdkSc"&gt;&lt;div class="JNdkSc-SmKAyb"&gt;&lt;div class="" jscontroller="sGwD4d" jsaction="zXBUYb:zTPCnb;oc1XGd:Qxe3nd;" jsname="F57UId"&gt;&lt;div class="oKdM2c Kzv0Me"&gt;&lt;div id="h.p_KDL42PXzpNzd" class="hJDwNd-AhqUyc-ibL1re purZT-AhqUyc-ibL1re pSzOP-AhqUyc-ibL1re jXK9ad D2fZ2 OjCsFc wHaque"&gt;&lt;div class="jXK9ad-SmKAyb"&gt;&lt;div class="tyJCtd baZpAe"&gt;&lt;div class="t3iYD"&gt;&lt;img src="https://lh4.googleusercontent.com/023vWyHYwTGYoekTdgH8aey_V2A-R-99FCRfQizkyG_pbSUnUvC5SAPFpnBzhCdPGJ2MIJ3QsDWBKiF-Zc8UqiWVsWci4c831f9pyfUtmJ_JCklrtQo=w1280" class="CENy8b" role="img"/&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class="hJDwNd-AhqUyc-EehZO purZT-AhqUyc-II5mzb pSzOP-AhqUyc-qWD73c JNdkSc yYI8W "&gt;&lt;div class="JNdkSc-SmKAyb"&gt;&lt;div class="" jscontroller="sGwD4d" jsaction="zXBUYb:zTPCnb;oc1XGd:Qxe3nd;" jsname="F57UId"&gt;&lt;div class="oKdM2c Kzv0Me"&gt;&lt;div id="h.p_aokGilTanouB" class="hJDwNd-AhqUyc-EehZO jXK9ad D2fZ2 OjCsFc GNzUNc"&gt;&lt;div class="jXK9ad-SmKAyb"&gt;&lt;div class="tyJCtd mGzaTb baZpAe"&gt;&lt;h2 id="h.p_EUb_zG2AnouC" class="zfr3Q JYVBee" style="text-align: left;" tabindex="-1"&gt;&lt;div jscontroller="Ae65rd" jsaction="touchstart:UrsOsc; click:KjsqPd; focusout:QZoaZ; mouseover:y0pDld; mouseout:dq0hvd;fv1Rjc:jbFSOd;CrfLRd:SzACGe;" class="CjVfdc"&gt;&lt;div class="PPhIP rviiZ" jsname="haAclf"&gt;&lt;div role="presentation" class="U26fgb mUbCce fKz7Od LRAOtb rm120e" jscontroller="mxS5xe" jsaction="click:cOuCgd; mousedown:UX7yZ; mouseup:lbsD7e; mouseenter:tfO1Yc; mouseleave:JywGue; focus:AHmuwe; blur:O22p3e; contextmenu:mg9Pef;" jsshadow aria-describedby="h.p_EUb_zG2AnouC" aria-label="Copy heading link" aria-disabled="false" data-tooltip="Copy heading link" aria-hidden="true" data-tooltip-position="top" data-tooltip-vertical-offset="12" data-tooltip-horizontal-offset="0"&gt;&lt;a class="FKF6mc TpQm9d" href="#h.p_EUb_zG2AnouC" aria-label="Copy heading link" jsname="hiK3ld" role="button" aria-describedby="h.p_EUb_zG2AnouC"&gt;&lt;div class="VTBa7b MbhUzd" jsname="ksKsZd"&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;span jsslot class="xjKiLb"&gt;&lt;span class="Ce1Y1c" style="top: -11px"&gt;&lt;svg class="OUGEr uav4k" width="22px" height="22px" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="currentColor" focusable="false"&gt;&lt;path d="M0 0h24v24H0z" fill="none"/&gt;&lt;path d="M3.9 12c0-1.71 1.39-3.1 3.1-3.1h4V7H7c-2.76 0-5 2.24-5 5s2.24 5 5 5h4v-1.9H7c-1.71 0-3.1-1.39-3.1-3.1zM8 13h8v-2H8v2zm9-6h-4v1.9h4c1.71 0 3.1 1.39 3.1 3.1s-1.39 3.1-3.1 3.1h-4V17h4c2.76 0 5-2.24 5-5s-2.24-5-5-5z"/&gt;&lt;/svg&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;a class="dhtgD aw5Odc" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.vclay.net%2Fpowercli%23h.p_17ThdqPqHaHQ&amp;amp;sa=D&amp;amp;sntz=1&amp;amp;usg=AFQjCNGbvD1XTOnyPw3Y9vJ2W2LWJ8O-VQ" target="_blank"&gt;POWERCLI - SNAPSHOT CONSOLIDATION&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/h2&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class="oKdM2c"&gt;&lt;div id="h.p_y70oEj3XnouE" class="hJDwNd-AhqUyc-EehZO jXK9ad D2fZ2 wHaque GNzUNc"&gt;&lt;div class="jXK9ad-SmKAyb"&gt;&lt;div class="tyJCtd mGzaTb baZpAe"&gt;&lt;p id="h.p_sGUY19pDnouE" class="zfr3Q" style="text-align: left;"&gt;08/20/2019 | by &lt;a class="dhtgD aw5Odc" href="/about"&gt;Clayton Skaggs&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p id="h.p_KDIcN6yEuYKY" class="zfr3Q" style="text-align: left;"&gt;Snapshots are great to have. They make life easy if you need to roll back a change, but they can also cause issues if not properly maintained. Snapshots that are not cleaned up can cause performance issues and possibly fill datastores. Here is a simple script to clean up all snapshots after 72 hours:&lt;/p&gt;&lt;div class="s1gOZb"&gt;&lt;pre id="h.p_viBgxzgB-gL-" class="zfr3Q FVr0A" style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;code&gt;&lt;em&gt;connect-viserver &amp;quot;vcenter name&amp;quot;&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/code&gt;&lt;/pre&gt;&lt;pre id="h.p_3tLadqBX-kb0" class="zfr3Q FVr0A" style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;code&gt;&lt;em&gt;Get-VM * | Get-Snapshot | Where {$_.Created -lt (Get-Date).AddDays(-3)} | Remove-Snapshot -Confirm:$false&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/code&gt;&lt;/pre&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;p id="h.p_int2_lTJ-mRM" class="zfr3Q" style="text-align: left;"&gt;This will consolidate snapshots one VM at a time. So what if you have multiple vCenters that you want lingering snapshots cleaned up after 72 hours? This script will accomplish the task:&lt;/p&gt;&lt;div class="s1gOZb"&gt;&lt;pre id="h.p_K-0fKWmtAB0u" class="zfr3Q FVr0A" style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;code&gt;&lt;em&gt;$hosts = @(&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/code&gt;&lt;/pre&gt;&lt;pre id="h.p_uSlerlWNACN_" class="zfr3Q FVr0A" style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;code&gt;&lt;em&gt; &nbsp; &nbsp;&amp;quot;vCenter1&amp;quot;,&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/code&gt;&lt;/pre&gt;&lt;pre id="h.p_bA7JSFUTACOA" class="zfr3Q FVr0A" style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;code&gt;&lt;em&gt; &nbsp; &nbsp;&amp;quot; vCenter2&amp;quot;,&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/code&gt;&lt;/pre&gt;&lt;pre id="h.p_f27ZZ-DyACOA" class="zfr3Q FVr0A" style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;code&gt;&lt;em&gt; &nbsp; &nbsp;&amp;quot; vCenter3&amp;quot;&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/code&gt;&lt;/pre&gt;&lt;pre id="h.p_S_-1lA9uACOA" class="zfr3Q FVr0A" style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;code&gt;&lt;em&gt;);&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/code&gt;&lt;/pre&gt;&lt;pre id="h.p_LE8KDdqLAMro" class="zfr3Q FVr0A" style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/pre&gt;&lt;pre id="h.p_PVsPKenCACOB" class="zfr3Q FVr0A" style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;code&gt;&lt;em&gt;Connect-VIServer -Server $hosts&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/code&gt;&lt;/pre&gt;&lt;pre id="h.p_kNaY7gP_AL_K" class="zfr3Q FVr0A" style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/pre&gt;&lt;pre id="h.p_kzkSw1fDAHKU" class="zfr3Q FVr0A" style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;code&gt;&lt;em&gt;Get-VM * | Get-Snapshot | Where {$_.Created -lt (Get-Date).AddDays(-3)} | Remove-Snapshot -Confirm:$false&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/code&gt;&lt;/pre&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;p id="h.p_HqGOLsnFACu2" class="zfr3Q" style="text-align: left;"&gt;I use task scheduler and run this one after business hours for the environments that I maintain. It really makes the task of cleaning up snapshots easy.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/section&gt;&lt;section id="h.p_7VVOUvQq8O6y" class="yaqOZd" style=""&gt;&lt;div class="yaqOZd IFuOkc"&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class="mYVXT"&gt;&lt;div class="LS81yb VICjCf" tabindex="-1"&gt;&lt;div class="hJDwNd-AhqUyc-ibL1re purZT-AhqUyc-ibL1re pSzOP-AhqUyc-ibL1re JNdkSc"&gt;&lt;div class="JNdkSc-SmKAyb"&gt;&lt;div class="" jscontroller="sGwD4d" jsaction="zXBUYb:zTPCnb;oc1XGd:Qxe3nd;" jsname="F57UId"&gt;&lt;div class="oKdM2c Kzv0Me"&gt;&lt;div id="h.p_T25Sx58d8O6y" class="hJDwNd-AhqUyc-ibL1re purZT-AhqUyc-ibL1re pSzOP-AhqUyc-ibL1re jXK9ad D2fZ2 OjCsFc wHaque"&gt;&lt;div class="jXK9ad-SmKAyb"&gt;&lt;div class="tyJCtd baZpAe"&gt;&lt;div class="t3iYD"&gt;&lt;a href="/powercli"&gt;&lt;img src="https://lh4.googleusercontent.com/Uq1aPxdu2egnW8NqOuNNrpFv7oTcZ9NEVD-ybUa_3pqpJ_PcODcKVRMfsTdwyEAp_-Wx00GvNmiCfbRXF9CC1XirQG9wneEf_tmXQJQXE5WIiGM6nCs=w1280" class="CENy8b"/&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class="hJDwNd-AhqUyc-EehZO purZT-AhqUyc-II5mzb pSzOP-AhqUyc-qWD73c JNdkSc yYI8W "&gt;&lt;div class="JNdkSc-SmKAyb"&gt;&lt;div class="" jscontroller="sGwD4d" jsaction="zXBUYb:zTPCnb;oc1XGd:Qxe3nd;" jsname="F57UId"&gt;&lt;div class="oKdM2c Kzv0Me"&gt;&lt;div id="h.p_d8GxErux8O6z" class="hJDwNd-AhqUyc-EehZO jXK9ad D2fZ2 OjCsFc GNzUNc"&gt;&lt;div class="jXK9ad-SmKAyb"&gt;&lt;div class="tyJCtd mGzaTb baZpAe"&gt;&lt;h2 id="h.p_c9XIP1Gw8O6z" class="zfr3Q JYVBee" style="text-align: left;" tabindex="-1"&gt;&lt;div jscontroller="Ae65rd" jsaction="touchstart:UrsOsc; click:KjsqPd; focusout:QZoaZ; mouseover:y0pDld; mouseout:dq0hvd;fv1Rjc:jbFSOd;CrfLRd:SzACGe;" class="CjVfdc"&gt;&lt;div class="PPhIP rviiZ" jsname="haAclf"&gt;&lt;div role="presentation" class="U26fgb mUbCce fKz7Od LRAOtb rm120e" jscontroller="mxS5xe" jsaction="click:cOuCgd; mousedown:UX7yZ; mouseup:lbsD7e; mouseenter:tfO1Yc; mouseleave:JywGue; focus:AHmuwe; blur:O22p3e; contextmenu:mg9Pef;" jsshadow aria-describedby="h.p_c9XIP1Gw8O6z" aria-label="Copy heading link" aria-disabled="false" data-tooltip="Copy heading link" aria-hidden="true" data-tooltip-position="top" data-tooltip-vertical-offset="12" data-tooltip-horizontal-offset="0"&gt;&lt;a class="FKF6mc TpQm9d" href="#h.p_c9XIP1Gw8O6z" aria-label="Copy heading link" jsname="hiK3ld" role="button" aria-describedby="h.p_c9XIP1Gw8O6z"&gt;&lt;div class="VTBa7b MbhUzd" jsname="ksKsZd"&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;span jsslot class="xjKiLb"&gt;&lt;span class="Ce1Y1c" style="top: -11px"&gt;&lt;svg class="OUGEr uav4k" width="22px" height="22px" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="currentColor" focusable="false"&gt;&lt;path d="M0 0h24v24H0z" fill="none"/&gt;&lt;path d="M3.9 12c0-1.71 1.39-3.1 3.1-3.1h4V7H7c-2.76 0-5 2.24-5 5s2.24 5 5 5h4v-1.9H7c-1.71 0-3.1-1.39-3.1-3.1zM8 13h8v-2H8v2zm9-6h-4v1.9h4c1.71 0 3.1 1.39 3.1 3.1s-1.39 3.1-3.1 3.1h-4V17h4c2.76 0 5-2.24 5-5s-2.24-5-5-5z"/&gt;&lt;/svg&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;a class="dhtgD aw5Odc" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.vclay.net%2Fpowercli%23h.p_gFymyr0AH3Kp&amp;amp;sa=D&amp;amp;sntz=1&amp;amp;usg=AFQjCNHAaBthhE4CYShPyLzV-fbOr1U-Sg" target="_blank"&gt;POWERCLI - DAILY SCSI BUS SHARING REPORT&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/h2&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class="oKdM2c"&gt;&lt;div id="h.p_jjNBk_GT8O6z" class="hJDwNd-AhqUyc-EehZO jXK9ad D2fZ2 wHaque GNzUNc"&gt;&lt;div class="jXK9ad-SmKAyb"&gt;&lt;div class="tyJCtd mGzaTb baZpAe"&gt;&lt;p id="h.p_hJgTncwX8O60" class="zfr3Q" style="text-align: left;"&gt;07/15/2019 | by &lt;a class="dhtgD aw5Odc" href="/about"&gt;Clayton Skaggs&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p id="h.p_IyhTmGGbITxE" class="zfr3Q" style="text-align: left;"&gt;Sometimes you need to know the VMs that are using SCSI bus sharing. Maybe you are planning patching for your hosts, but notice when you attempt to vMotion them off, you see the following error:&lt;/p&gt;&lt;div class="s1gOZb"&gt;&lt;pre id="h.p_kvLTGSLnExbX" class="zfr3Q FVr0A" style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;code&gt;&lt;em&gt;Unable to migrate from &amp;lt;source server&amp;gt; to &amp;lt;destination server&amp;gt;: Virtual machine is configured to use a device that prevents migration: Device &amp;#39;&amp;lt;device&amp;gt;&amp;#39; is a SCSI controller engaged in bus-sharing. &lt;/em&gt;&lt;/code&gt;&lt;/pre&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;p id="h.p_yXrdXeymG01y" class="zfr3Q" style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;a class="dhtgD aw5Odc" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fkb.vmware.com%2Fs%2Farticle%2F1003797&amp;amp;sa=D&amp;amp;sntz=1&amp;amp;usg=AFQjCNE2P9sMYjXPcXhNEaHLnhiTO4mGXQ" target="_blank"&gt;https://kb.vmware.com/s/article/1003797&lt;/a&gt; &lt;/p&gt;&lt;p id="h.p_d3_RvFRbEs8M" class="zfr3Q" style="text-align: left;"&gt;The VMs cannot be vacated because they are engaged in SCSI bus sharing. I typically see this with Microsoft Cluster Services (MSCS) VMs. Avoid situations like this by generating a report to see what VMs are using SCSI bus sharing and plan ahead. Here is the script I use:&lt;/p&gt;&lt;div class="s1gOZb"&gt;&lt;pre id="h.p_foKfgQFzD-re" class="zfr3Q FVr0A" style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;code&gt;&lt;em&gt;#vCenters to connect to&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/code&gt;&lt;/pre&gt;&lt;pre id="h.p_K4RUD_PgDtPg" class="zfr3Q FVr0A" style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;code&gt;&lt;em&gt;$hosts = @(&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/code&gt;&lt;/pre&gt;&lt;pre id="h.p_gLsrkhMgDntc" class="zfr3Q FVr0A" style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;code&gt;&lt;em&gt; &nbsp; &nbsp;&amp;quot;vCenter1&amp;quot;,&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/code&gt;&lt;/pre&gt;&lt;pre id="h.p_kRrk_ZMeDntc" class="zfr3Q FVr0A" style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;code&gt;&lt;em&gt; &nbsp; &nbsp;&amp;quot; vCenter2&amp;quot;,&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/code&gt;&lt;/pre&gt;&lt;pre id="h.p_5R-DABg8Dntc" class="zfr3Q FVr0A" style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;code&gt;&lt;em&gt; &nbsp; &nbsp;&amp;quot; vCenter3&amp;quot;&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/code&gt;&lt;/pre&gt;&lt;pre id="h.p_oYQuC2fPDntd" class="zfr3Q FVr0A" style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;code&gt;&lt;em&gt;);&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/code&gt;&lt;/pre&gt;&lt;pre id="h.p_TuHKfY4LDntd" class="zfr3Q FVr0A" style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;code&gt;&lt;em&gt; &lt;/em&gt;&lt;/code&gt;&lt;/pre&gt;&lt;pre id="h.p_uHmPZ9-hDntf" class="zfr3Q FVr0A" style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;code&gt;&lt;em&gt;Connect-VIServer -Server $hosts&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/code&gt;&lt;/pre&gt;&lt;pre id="h.p_31zpnWeuDI3b" class="zfr3Q FVr0A" style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/pre&gt;&lt;pre id="h.p_kiYZ86jiDwa3" class="zfr3Q FVr0A" style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;code&gt;&lt;em&gt;#Find all VMs using SCSI bus sharing&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/code&gt;&lt;/pre&gt;&lt;pre id="h.p_-Gmy5QBZDI3b" class="zfr3Q FVr0A" style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;code&gt;&lt;em&gt;Get-VMHost | Get-VM * | Get-ScsiController | Where-Object {$_.BusSharingMode -eq &amp;quot;Physical&amp;quot; -or $_.BusSharingMode -eq &amp;quot;Virtual&amp;quot;} | Select @{N=&amp;#39;Name&amp;#39;;E={$_.Parent.Name}}, @{N=&amp;#39;VMHost&amp;#39;;E={$_.Parent.VMHost}}, BusSharingMode | Sort VMHost | Export-csv -Path &amp;quot;D:\reports\export\#custom\SCSI_bus_sharing_VMs\SCSI.csv&amp;quot; -NoTypeInformation -UseCulture&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/code&gt;&lt;/pre&gt;&lt;pre id="h.p_A4CIum4BD0xK" class="zfr3Q FVr0A" style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/pre&gt;&lt;pre id="h.p_HC5pQ7GYDI3b" class="zfr3Q FVr0A" style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;code&gt;&lt;em&gt;#Modify the report to include today&amp;#39;s date &lt;/em&gt;&lt;/code&gt;&lt;/pre&gt;&lt;pre id="h.p_OomP7U24DI3c" class="zfr3Q FVr0A" style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;code&gt;&lt;em&gt;$datetime = get-date -f yyyyMMdd&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/code&gt;&lt;/pre&gt;&lt;pre id="h.p_sYl7bENTDI3c" class="zfr3Q FVr0A" style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;code&gt;&lt;em&gt;rename-item &amp;quot;D:\reports\export\#custom\SCSI_bus_sharing_VMs\SCSI.csv&amp;quot; &nbsp;-newname ($datetime + &amp;quot;_SCSI.csv&amp;quot;)&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/code&gt;&lt;/pre&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;p id="h.p_OnU3CECYEfZj" class="zfr3Q" style="text-align: left;"&gt;I run this one in a scheduled task as well. It is great for keeping track of VMs that might cause issues if you are needing to do maintenance on a particular ESXi host.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/section&gt;&lt;section id="h.p_mAdHo9xLibeL" class="yaqOZd" style=""&gt;&lt;div class="yaqOZd IFuOkc"&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class="mYVXT"&gt;&lt;div class="LS81yb VICjCf" tabindex="-1"&gt;&lt;div class="hJDwNd-AhqUyc-ibL1re purZT-AhqUyc-ibL1re pSzOP-AhqUyc-ibL1re JNdkSc"&gt;&lt;div class="JNdkSc-SmKAyb"&gt;&lt;div class="" jscontroller="sGwD4d" jsaction="zXBUYb:zTPCnb;oc1XGd:Qxe3nd;" jsname="F57UId"&gt;&lt;div class="oKdM2c Kzv0Me"&gt;&lt;div id="h.p_HJEm5pQDibeM" class="hJDwNd-AhqUyc-ibL1re purZT-AhqUyc-ibL1re pSzOP-AhqUyc-ibL1re jXK9ad D2fZ2 OjCsFc wHaque"&gt;&lt;div class="jXK9ad-SmKAyb"&gt;&lt;div class="tyJCtd baZpAe"&gt;&lt;div class="t3iYD"&gt;&lt;a href="/powercli"&gt;&lt;img src="https://lh5.googleusercontent.com/AvgTAYQN2yi-n1gnM-YZzg5AyV5arZt936rnnzfmg5TO5z0NeD6RyUlZ9f5ieIK_2ZOgl5hxpgrKZOuk8E_8k2o5va1pUaiDZ83EqqKI0RU7GG02bA=w1280" class="CENy8b"/&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class="hJDwNd-AhqUyc-EehZO purZT-AhqUyc-II5mzb pSzOP-AhqUyc-qWD73c JNdkSc yYI8W "&gt;&lt;div class="JNdkSc-SmKAyb"&gt;&lt;div class="" jscontroller="sGwD4d" jsaction="zXBUYb:zTPCnb;oc1XGd:Qxe3nd;" jsname="F57UId"&gt;&lt;div class="oKdM2c Kzv0Me"&gt;&lt;div id="h.p_V6U0N-R1ibeN" class="hJDwNd-AhqUyc-EehZO jXK9ad D2fZ2 OjCsFc GNzUNc"&gt;&lt;div class="jXK9ad-SmKAyb"&gt;&lt;div class="tyJCtd mGzaTb baZpAe"&gt;&lt;h2 id="h.p_hT_dFcb4ibeP" class="zfr3Q JYVBee" style="text-align: left;" tabindex="-1"&gt;&lt;div jscontroller="Ae65rd" jsaction="touchstart:UrsOsc; click:KjsqPd; focusout:QZoaZ; mouseover:y0pDld; mouseout:dq0hvd;fv1Rjc:jbFSOd;CrfLRd:SzACGe;" class="CjVfdc"&gt;&lt;div class="PPhIP rviiZ" jsname="haAclf"&gt;&lt;div role="presentation" class="U26fgb mUbCce fKz7Od LRAOtb rm120e" jscontroller="mxS5xe" jsaction="click:cOuCgd; mousedown:UX7yZ; mouseup:lbsD7e; mouseenter:tfO1Yc; mouseleave:JywGue; focus:AHmuwe; blur:O22p3e; contextmenu:mg9Pef;" jsshadow aria-describedby="h.p_hT_dFcb4ibeP" aria-label="Copy heading link" aria-disabled="false" data-tooltip="Copy heading link" aria-hidden="true" data-tooltip-position="top" data-tooltip-vertical-offset="12" data-tooltip-horizontal-offset="0"&gt;&lt;a class="FKF6mc TpQm9d" href="#h.p_hT_dFcb4ibeP" aria-label="Copy heading link" jsname="hiK3ld" role="button" aria-describedby="h.p_hT_dFcb4ibeP"&gt;&lt;div class="VTBa7b MbhUzd" jsname="ksKsZd"&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;span jsslot class="xjKiLb"&gt;&lt;span class="Ce1Y1c" style="top: -11px"&gt;&lt;svg class="OUGEr uav4k" width="22px" height="22px" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="currentColor" focusable="false"&gt;&lt;path d="M0 0h24v24H0z" fill="none"/&gt;&lt;path d="M3.9 12c0-1.71 1.39-3.1 3.1-3.1h4V7H7c-2.76 0-5 2.24-5 5s2.24 5 5 5h4v-1.9H7c-1.71 0-3.1-1.39-3.1-3.1zM8 13h8v-2H8v2zm9-6h-4v1.9h4c1.71 0 3.1 1.39 3.1 3.1s-1.39 3.1-3.1 3.1h-4V17h4c2.76 0 5-2.24 5-5s-2.24-5-5-5z"/&gt;&lt;/svg&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;a class="dhtgD aw5Odc" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.vclay.net%2Fpowercli%23h.p_V1SK7ToHJRcq&amp;amp;sa=D&amp;amp;sntz=1&amp;amp;usg=AFQjCNENPv3ofeGCwJ0DoQD7YnhqNT_zGg" target="_blank"&gt;POWERCLI - VM BULK CHange vNIC PORTGROUP&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/h2&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class="oKdM2c"&gt;&lt;div id="h.p_pkWtgkaEibeP" class="hJDwNd-AhqUyc-EehZO jXK9ad D2fZ2 GNzUNc"&gt;&lt;div class="jXK9ad-SmKAyb"&gt;&lt;div class="tyJCtd mGzaTb baZpAe"&gt;&lt;p id="h.p_0R31BMIEibeU" class="zfr3Q" style="text-align: left;"&gt;06/30/2019 | by &lt;a class="dhtgD aw5Odc" href="/about"&gt;Clayton Skaggs&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p id="h.p_CxPH5i97ibeV" class="zfr3Q" style="text-align: left;"&gt;This is a great little script for changing the portgroup association of several VMs at once. It works with standard and distributed switches.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;div class="s1gOZb"&gt;&lt;pre id="h.p_BTCsgh2NibeU" class="zfr3Q FVr0A" style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;code&gt;&lt;em&gt;$OldNetwork = &amp;quot;PG1&amp;quot; &lt;/em&gt;&lt;/code&gt;&lt;/pre&gt;&lt;pre id="h.p_nXlcC-xVibeU" class="zfr3Q FVr0A" style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;code&gt;&lt;em&gt;$NewNetwork = &amp;quot;PG2&amp;quot;&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/code&gt;&lt;/pre&gt;&lt;pre id="h.p_Hz_5Yt-xQROn" class="zfr3Q FVr0A" style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/pre&gt;&lt;pre id="h.p_ZDTDpaI_QRSL" class="zfr3Q FVr0A" style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;code&gt;&lt;em&gt;vc &amp;quot;vCenter Name&amp;quot;&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/code&gt;&lt;/pre&gt;&lt;pre id="h.p_yPedk2DNibeU" class="zfr3Q FVr0A" style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;code&gt;&lt;em&gt;Get-VM |Get-NetworkAdapter |Where {$_.NetworkName -eq $OldNetwork } |Set-NetworkAdapter -NetworkName $NewNetwork -Confirm:$false&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/code&gt;&lt;/pre&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;p id="h.p_OtFEHM_xibeV" class="zfr3Q" style="text-align: left;"&gt;As an example, I have several VMs attached to portgroup &amp;quot;VLAN_30&amp;quot;:&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class="oKdM2c"&gt;&lt;div id="h.p_hDZ66lzVibeV" class="hJDwNd-AhqUyc-EehZO jXK9ad D2fZ2"&gt;&lt;div class="jXK9ad-SmKAyb"&gt;&lt;div class="tyJCtd baZpAe"&gt;&lt;div class="t3iYD"&gt;&lt;img src="https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/5Oz6d5BYlgWvYATSfkFZLtohhERkIuXgY4x2lCIpiyr52v175NFYT5L5uOJB2GqMIST_roUGdlKUvDDxYgFolHsNX-2y0ntwMIqFmWgwH90AK7GLaQs=w1280" class="CENy8b" role="img" style="width: 100%; margin: -0.0000000504% 0 -0.0000000504% 0%"/&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class="oKdM2c"&gt;&lt;div id="h.p_FnAtYSvAibeW" class="hJDwNd-AhqUyc-EehZO jXK9ad D2fZ2 GNzUNc"&gt;&lt;div class="jXK9ad-SmKAyb"&gt;&lt;div class="tyJCtd mGzaTb baZpAe"&gt;&lt;p id="h.p_Q8UHoGHOibeW" class="zfr3Q"&gt;Using the code above, we&amp;#39;ll move them to VLAN_40:&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class="oKdM2c"&gt;&lt;div id="h.p_qdZJvkT4ibeX" class="hJDwNd-AhqUyc-EehZO jXK9ad D2fZ2"&gt;&lt;div class="jXK9ad-SmKAyb"&gt;&lt;div class="tyJCtd baZpAe"&gt;&lt;div class="t3iYD"&gt;&lt;img src="https://lh5.googleusercontent.com/z5HLCuOl6AJ1nu9VmY_Zk-4zSAJBMdlY6aI3bK5n3njcb1hjvGCAkAqGvReyx6DhE99vfb-uQQG32B4kdPmzO6o8nZtoc9DtKRrJeALxH76DUnCEook=w1280" class="CENy8b" role="img" style="width: 100.0000032002%; margin: 0% 0 0% -0.0000016001%"/&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class="oKdM2c"&gt;&lt;div id="h.p_NMAhW_NeibeX" class="hJDwNd-AhqUyc-EehZO jXK9ad D2fZ2 wHaque GNzUNc"&gt;&lt;div class="jXK9ad-SmKAyb"&gt;&lt;div class="tyJCtd mGzaTb baZpAe"&gt;&lt;p id="h.p_1fyDZocribeX" class="zfr3Q"&gt;Simple as that! From the OS side, just make sure your IPs are able to talk on the destination VLAN.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p id="h.p_ep_5u4ja2hfO" class="zfr3Q"&gt;Source: &lt;a class="dhtgD aw5Odc" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fcommunities.vmware.com%2Fthread%2F541575&amp;amp;sa=D&amp;amp;sntz=1&amp;amp;usg=AFQjCNH2nn7pg355aC_wXIbv8P5n2-JQig" target="_blank"&gt;https://communities.vmware.com/thread/541575&lt;/a&gt;
